Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

posts.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

posts.com: The base of the hinges that attach to the toilet bowl can rotate, and I'm guessing that the hinge pins themselves can also rotate independently of the base. Since the hinge pins are attached near the side of the bases rather than at the center, they are moved closer together and further apart by rotating the bases. So rotate the bases and the hinge pins will get further apart. Which direction you rotate them depends on whether you want the seat to move further forward or further backward.

>>2536571
Shad has a few videos on this type of thing - usually timber frames with stone veneer.
But stone would be prohibitively expensive. Not all stone is created equal - for example while I have granite in my land, there's enough schist mixed in that it won't split the way you want it to. Cutting stone is time-consuming (rotary hammer and feather wedges). Then of course the logistics of quarrying - do you have a cliff you can quarry into, or are you going to do a pit? If so how will you keep it drained? Depending on where you live you may run afoul of regulations. Once you have the stone, how will you build with it? Stones are heavy.
Unless you are a richfag and can afford to buy suitable land, pay off the local bureaucrats, buy all the necessary equipment, your best bet is probably to build with cinder block then put decorative stones on the outside like they do with chimneys.

posts.com:
Gotta hurt your feelings here a bit but I gotta say it: You're pretty naive and don't know shit about building trades but at least you ask.

Bricklaying/Masons work is a very old and hard craft. In Europe there have been craftsmans guilds for almost a thousand years. It takes a bunch of years to properly learn it and you gotta be very precise. Building walls is more than just putting a bunch of rocks ontop. You need to measure stuff, plan it, know what tools there are and how to use them and know alot about material. There are probably more than 20 different types or wall stones, natural ones, artifical ones and 100 different types or mortar.

For example, there are mason world championships every year. Picture related. You wouldn't believe how hard it is and how much time it takes to do something like picture related - and those guys have time limits.

And if you think "a bunch of peason built castles with their hands" you don't know shit about history. Cathedrals and castles and shit have been built over generations.

Greetings OP,

I am the Master Mason. I've spent the past 6 years of my life researching everything there is to know about masonry and stone buildings.

You presented us with the question of whether or not this is feasible. I am happy to inform you that yes, this is 100% feasible and could easily be done. You are a citizen located in New England, this area of the US is almost completely earthquake free, so the option of making a traditional stone tower is possible.

There are pros and cons to this idea of yours. The biggest con is that to make a traditional tower, you'll need to shape each and every stone. Without going into it too much, you're not equipped nor skillful enough to make a traditional stone tower, nor would I advise you do so.

Your best and only hope is to create this stone tower using the slip form masonry technique. Utilizing this technique, you can simply gather stones of varying size, place them within your form, and apply cement to bond it all together. You'll also be using rebar throughout the entire structure to keep it held structurally sound. Now as you're beginning to build, you'll want a strong and wide foundation, and each layer of stone should be smaller than the previous layer. This will give your tower a strong base, and it will be reinforced with steel. Will your tower last for 150 years? No, but with simple repairs, it can last indefinitely. The mortar can be replaced, stones can be put back in. You can do this if you put your mind to it.

The floorboards and supporting wood can either rest directly on the stone wall of the tower, or you can build a wooden frame inside the tower, and build your interior that way. I'm not sure which I'd prefer, but these are choices you alone must make.

You'll want knowledge of concrete, and you'll want to understand loads and a bit of symmetry. The proportions if this tower must be equal. Consider also the drainage for your tower. When water runs off it, it should not collect at the foundation.

>>2535432
>I'm looking at getting a vacuum casting thing for making jewelry but I don't even think they make them in Australia so it's going to run me like 3k aud. Ideally I'd like to start selling the pieces I make but that's a ways off and I don't really know if a 3k gamble is worth it.

I built one myself and I shit you not it looks like this. Also in Australia. Not sure your use case exactly but I use mine for removing bubbles in resin during curing.

1) Get a oil vaccuum pump. Can be difficult to get hold of and you might get asked weird questions as apparently they are used in backyard drug manufacture. Mine cost around $600 maybe a few years ago.

2) find a plastic transparent thing like the dome in your pic.

3) Get a nice thick sheet of Perspex/Acrylic.

4) cut two concentric rings, and fill the gap between them with silicone sealant from bunnings, this is your seal for the plastic dome.

5) buy cheap bunnings air connectors and drill a hole in your thick perspex sheet to put the intake valve on, connect to your vacc pump

6) your seal goes on top of the perspex sheet, your 'stuff' goes on the perspex sheet inside your seal and your bowl goes over the top so you can see physical effects.

7) For added fun, put a gauge between your device and the vaccuum pump.

Boom, you got yourself a vaccuum chamber. Bunnings costs <$80. The most expensive part is the vacuum pump, i don't know how you can cheap out on that unless you find a good second hand one.

Welcome to the woodworking general, here we discuss the working of wood and the tools and techniques of working wood. So far we tend to be mostly hand tool folk with a slant towards cabinetry and carving but all are welcome and we have some capable power tool folk amount our ranks. General carpentry question such as framing/decking/general construction seems to get a better response in the /qtddtot/ or /sqt/.

>essential /wwg/ books
Tage Frid Teaches Woodworking, gives you everything you need and shows you how to do it multiple ways from hand tools to power tools and gives you the knowledge to determine which is best, and then he teaches you how to apply what you learned. The PDF of the second book can be found in the usual places, but the other two are MIA.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561588261

Christopher Schwarz tells you everything you need to know about planes and saws and their use
Handplane Essentials
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440332983
Handsaw Essentials
Best to find this one in PDF from the usual sources, out of print and pricey!

Chris Pye wrote the book on carving and keeps on writing them.
https://www.chrispye-woodcarving.com/

The eastern tradtion, Japanese Woodworking Tools: Their Tradition, Spirit and Use by Toshio Odate
https://www.amazon.com/dp/0941936465

Leonard Lee The Complete Guide to Sharpeninig, how to sharpen most everything.
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1561581259

Bob Flexner - Finishing 101, covers the common stuff, his other books cover the uncommon and go into more depth
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1440308454/

Illustrated Cabinet Making by Bill Hylton, learn to design furniture that won't fall apart
https://www.amazon.com/dp/1565233697/

>essential /wwg/ tv
https://www.pbs.org/show/woodwrights-shop/
https://www.newyankee.com/

previous thread >>2514390

Beginner's guide to tools https://www.thecrucible.org/guides/woodworking/

Show us your mallet!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532202
>toxic sawdust and septic splinters
Some woods present more danger than others but fwiw all wood dust can be dangerous to aspirated in the kinds of concentrations seen in woodworking, and almost any plant material injected subcutaneous will decompose and fester.
Be safe and all that, just saying that the precautions and related labels attached to working with certain wood species don't necessarily apply to using items made from them, even for eating off of.
Oak splinters are also intensely painful compared to other woods and fester quickly, but oak is used all the time for aging and storing food.
Almost any wood is a potential allergen/ irritant and very few trees are directly toxic...weed out the ones that aren't used for commercial lumber like oleander and the list of truly poisonous lumber sources is tiny

https://www.wood-database.com/wood-articles/wood-allergies-and-toxicity/

That said any commercially made wood product from China carries thecrisk of having been treated with or exposed to God knows what.

>>2532243
I don't know how much you already have and know how to do, but I can recommend looking through Rex Krueger's "Woodwork for humans" video series on youtube, especially if you're starting out with nothing.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLR_8ISkKkV7ky1wbbBUkE3-kwH6LRRWY1
Theres enough in there to start a handtool workshop with a japanese saw, a bit-brace with auger bits, a knife, a clamp, and some measuring and marking tools, but you gotta make your own watch-order cause the whole thing is a bit too disjointed to be a clear starter guide. I'd suggest going Japanese sawhorses, Chopping-block workbench, make a mallet with 3 tools, then pick some of the simple projects like milking stool or tool tote to get started. Then you can look into making a proper workbench and take on bigger projects once you have a bit of experience.
Alternative, his book "Everyday Woodworking - A beginner's guide to woodcraft with 12 hand tools" is also a good intro, it is basically the same as the videos but ordered and condensed.

You'll probably eventually want to advance to powertools, especially if you're gonna be building something large like a cabin. But getting started with handtools is a great way to learn, and as it says in the book;
>"Once you understand wood and know the basic techniques, you can still buy those machines. They're not going anywhere."

Eventually you will need a decent bench.

3 essentials:
Correct height for you
Stable
Perfectly flat surface.

No shame in buying one if you want, HF has a hardwood one that is quite reasonably priced and last I looked, good quality for the cost.
If you choose to make one, consider using MDF for the top.

I don't really like MDF, but it is dimensionally stable and perfectly flat.

Cheap, too. Some people make it so they can replace the top piece of MDF every year or so when they bang up the surface.

I would make it a modest size so that if and when you build a fancier one later, you don't need to get rid of it.


https://www.finewoodworking.com/2013/03/13/a-basic-bench-thats-quick-to-make

https://www.woodchoppintime.com/beginners-woodworking-bench/

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2533020
With linseed oil you traditionally apply one coat per day for a week, one coat per week for a month, one coat per month for a year and one coat per year for the rest of your life. It's a drying oil so you don't seal it. If you want it to seal the traditional solution is danish oil, which used to be 1/3rd boiled linseed oil, 1/3rd turpentine and 1/3rd varnish but can apparently be anything now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533056
Mahagony has a natural anti-rot resistance, as does teak. That's why it's use for fine furniture and boats. For Mahogany it's the tight grain, for teak it's the grain and a high level of oils and silica in the wood. There are species that are hard woods that are durable and resist rot naturally. Cedar is rot resistant, but it's too soft for furniture or boats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532691
Drying oil is bad for a table surface, there's too much wear. Poly is fine if it's not something formal, like if you game a lot, and use the desk every day.

I helped my dad finish an oak kitchen table when I was a kid, and put mulitple coats of poly on it, sanding between each one. 30 years later, it's still looks good.

Finish can be aesthic, or function. Any surface you're going to use daily, shellac or poly. Tung oil looks great, but doesn't wear as well. And, will be more sensitive to things like water rings, scratches, etc. It's a nice finish, for sure, but you'll be redoing it a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533573
PVA glue doesn't really work if there's any kind of gap. That's why you want to get it perfectly flat. If they're flat enough to give you the strength you need and look how you want then it's fine. Filing just sounds like a shitload of work for not much gain. There's also Gorilla Glue which is gap filling but weaker than PVA in general and not much stronger when filling gaps. You could also buy a router plane which will allow you to get perfect flatness, though with current retard pricing on old Stanley planes it's not even worth it to restore an old one over buying a fucking Veritas where I live.

While the oils are toxic even eating the chopsticks themselves would not be enough to cause issues unless you are allergic and if you are you probably will not manage to make them. Brazilian seems less an issue as far as allergies go but allergies will not be an issue once they are made, pretty much need to inhale the dust or be exposed to the sap for it to be an issue, contact with the dried wood is not enough to trigger a reaction. You can also use acetone to remove the oils, which is what I have to do when I work Indian since I am allergic to it and often have to deal with it since luthier.
>black limba
Little experience with it, probably would do well.

Main thing you want for chopsticks is dense and tiny pored, hard/rock maple, ebony, boxwood, fruitwoods, etc.

>>2532264
All wood dust is carcinogenic if you inhale enough. Making some chopsticks will not cause cancer.
>>2532414
Flaxseed (raw linseed) is about as good as it gets here, it dries faster than most common non-drying oils, mild enough in flavor to not impart flavors into your food, and generally dries before going rancid. Give them a feeding after every washing until washing no longer saps the oil out, after that give them a coat anytime the surface looks dry.

>American specialty glues
Look at what wood glues are available, look for one that is a aliphatic resin emulsion, this is what Titebond is and it is a common wood glue around the world.
>>2533659
>Also, Titebond isn't better than generic PVA
Original Titebond is an aliphatic resin emulsion and much better than PVAs for wood, exhibits far less creep and has enough flexibility to hold up to seasonal wood movement. PVA is fine if that is all you have (Titebond II or III is PVA) but aliphatic resin emulsions are far better than polyvinyl acetates for wood.

posts.name: Anonymous

I was just talking about strength, where the determining factor invariably ends up being the wood itself because all the glues are stronger anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533684
>where the determining factor invariably ends up being the wood itself because all the glues are stronger anyway.
PVA is not really the equal of Titebond here either, its brittleness is a massive drawback and PVA joints can be cleanly separated with a well directed mallet blow, the glue will just shatter at the joint. This and the creep are the primary reason for aliphatic resin emulsion based glues to become the standard wood glue. Even hide glues do better than PVA thanks to their far greater flexibility. Hide glues have a similar weakness to shock as PVAs but only release when shear forces are in the mix, drawback is poor moisture resistance which PVA is one of the best for. The saving grace for hide glues is high heat resistance and repairability better than any other common glue.

tbc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533713
cont.

The tests for glue strength commonly seen on youtube and the like are terrible and do not really represent how most joints fail over time. These supposed tests put the force primarily on the wood and not on the joint leaving the physical properties of the wood the primary determiner of strength, really they demonstrate the peel strength and resistance to splitting of the wood more than anything. Below is relative to the glues listed, for example; ARE is not actually good on water resistance but it is better than hide in that regard.

Aliphatic Resin Emulsion
Poor - gap filling, heat resistance, repairability, and reversibility
Good - water and creep resistance
Great - Shock resistance

Polyvinyl Acetate/PVA
Poor - shock, gap filling, flexibility, creep, heat, and repairability
Good - reverseability
Great - water resistance

Hide
Poor - water resistance and gap filling
Good - shock resistance but only if that force is not perpendicular to the joint.
Great - flexibility, creep, heat, repairability and reversibility

Polyurethane/PU
Poor - Heat, reversibility and probably repairability
Good - gap filling
Great - shock water and creep resistance

Epoxy
Poor - reversibility, repairability and heat resistance
Good - gap filling, this can be great with the addition of fillers at the cost of sacrificing other things
Great - shock, water, creep

With repairability I referring to how well it can repaired after the glue fails, as in after 40 years of wood movement has sheared the wood fibers from the glue and it just separates. PVA and ARE do not stick to themselves so the old glue must be removed before regluing or a glue which will stick to them must be used but that is generally a short lived repair. Hide glue and epoxy are the only common glues which happily stick to themselves, PU might but I do not know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533721
> Hide glue and epoxy are the only common glues which happily stick to themselves, PU might but I do not know
PU glue doesn’t stick wel to dried PU glue at all. It can be repaired with CA glue fairly well though.

Epoxy does btw - it will readily stick to itself and the new bond will be about as strong as the original one. But epoxy and PU both have additional drawbacks in handling (you need gloves) where PVA is non toxic

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533922
>a rectangular sound port?
Sure, the sound waves don't care much about the shape. There are probably more guitars with rectangular sound ports than oval or round out there, it is a common solution to no longer needed electronics. Rectangular also has the advantage of being easy to bind so it does not look like a hole just carved into the guitar without care. Binding is not a must for you since you say it has laminated sides but it will help keep the finish from getting chipped around the opening if you do add it.
>coping saw
Threading that through the sound hole will not be fun and you will have a short and awkward stroke. I would probably just whittle it away with a knife if I had nothing more suited to the task, slow but it will leave a good edge as long as you take it slow and don't try and take too large of a bite. Rasp or even a round bastard file will do as well, rasp will splinter things out bad on the inside, bastard will do better here but be slower. All of these would not hurt from having some tape applied to the inside, green painters masking tape will do, helps reduce the splintering. If you go the coping saw route make sure it cuts on the push and not the pull or it will leave things a mess on the outside, splintering and chipped finish.
>>2533932
It takes months, dries quicker in the winter assuming you are somewhere that winter means the heat is on, dry air and all that. I just give such things a daily coat for the first week or so, as much as the wood will absorb, and then put it to use, giving it a fresh coat after each washing (after it has dried from that washing). As long as the wood is good and saturated with the oil then food will not soak in much and what does will wash out. Just don't leave it in that pot of simmering marinara unless you want to turn it red. If you really want to make sure it does not get stained then give it a good coat of oil before use as well for that first month or so.

>>2534075
Layout is 90% of the job, cutting the joint is simply cutting to the line. Don't listen to the pocket hole crowd, the mortise and tenon is the most important joint in wood working and good to learn early. Learn to do tenons on the table saw and by hand with saw and chisel, learn to both chop and drill and square your mortises. And invest in layout tool, trysquare, dividers, mortise gauge, marking gauge, cutting gauge, etc, the layout tools are often left off of essential tool lists but are rather important.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534366
Dedicated pore fillers are the common way, so or like wood putty but only capable of filling tiny holes. Sandpaper and BLO/Tung is another way, just apply the thinned oil with wet dry sandpaper, repeat until finished. This is a fairly tricky technique to get down since you need to learn how thin to mix the oil and how fine the dust needs to be to get a proper mix of oil and dust in the pores.
>>2534367
I don't think you can get it all out, I thought I had it all out and then one day the light hit it just right and after that I never could not see it. I do not think enough oxygen makes it under the finish for it to be an issue, maybe after a century. I would highly recommend filling the pores before sanding the brass flush. A few coats of thin shellac might be enough in a wood like walnut, do the shellac the day before sanding flush, wipe down with alcohol to remove the shellac on the surface along with the brass dust. Any finish can over shellac so need to worry and all that will remain is the stuff beneath the surface. I still would just fill the pores.

>>2534493

You could reduce the thickness and the width of the tenon of that side member so that it won't weaken that corner so much. Alternatively you could increase its width, which would increase the distance between the tenons for a similar effect. Probably more important is to just reduce the thickness. You'll get a pretty good amount of strength by virtue of glueing the side to the bottom so that side member's tenon is almost superfluous.

The USDA publishes the Wood Handbook: Wood as an Engineering Material, has some good info in it but the bulk of it is beyond what most woodworkers need and it is primarily concerned with wood used in construction so most of the info dealing with strength and the like would result in massive overkill. PDF is free to download from their site but getting an old edition for a couple dollars used is probably a better idea for most, less of the old editions is dedicated to things of no use to the woodworker, 1980s editions have a good balance. wood-database.com is useful and may be all you need.

>>2535186
Softwoods are just fine for practice and carry over completely, fir would be best for learning, avoid the pines since the massive difference between summer and winter wood makes them difficult to work.

You never stop doing tests completely and it is good practice anytime you are working an unfamilar wood. How long it takes to become competent varies a great deal especially when they are going the self taught way. Main thing to remember is most of the work is done during layout, the rest is just cutting to a line. Learn to do proper layout, learn to cut to a line and you will be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't have a jointer or planer. If I buy S4S lumber do I still need to let it acclimate to my space and what do I do if it warps?

Every video on youtube seems to finish pieces with a sandpaper series. Is a hand planed surface fine too? Are there any stains/oils/waxes that don't work as well on that?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535845
> If I buy S4S lumber do I still need to let it acclimate to my space
Yes but if pine/fir chances are it’s already warped a lot anyway. If you’re buying s4s hardwood you should be okay, but you still need to let it acclimatise/dry to prevent it from warping later (and ruining whatever you built from it)

> what do I do if it warps
You plane off the warped part with a plane/planer so that it’s straight again. Most electric planers will just make warped boards thinner and still warped though (unless you support it while planing).

> Is a hand planed surface fine too?
Depends on how you’re going to finish it but generally yes, planing when done right can give a better surface than sanding, plus it’s a lot faster for big pieces

> Are there any stains/oils/waxes that don't work as well on that?
Yes and no. Most hand planes tend to burnish the wood a bit with the sole which prevents it from taking a stain or finish later. But in my experience for most woods you can just use some 320 grit sandpaper on hand planed surfaces, and they will be as good as a progressively sanded 320 surface.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535845
All lumber needs to acclimate and S4S does not mean it's flat and square across its whole length. No matter how you slice it, you will have to plane it. A properly sharpened iron in a hand plane will produce a finish much smoother than sandpaper will. Lots of old furniture was just finished with a light planing or scraping, then oiled.
If you're gonna plane by hand, get yourself an old plane (preferably Stanley #3 sized) and aggressively camber the iron and file open the mouth to make a scrub plane. It will make your life a million times easier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535868
>Most hand planes tend to burnish the wood a bit with the sole which prevents it from taking a stain or finish later.
That would have to be a rather soft wood, even poplar and mahogany do not get burnished enough to affect finishing. Not sure you can actually burnish a wood to the point it will not take a finish, the moisture from the finish generally undoes most of that burning anyways which is why people who want a burnished finish generally go with wax or burnish after the first coat.

>>2536777
Looks like it is trying to follow the grain? Still not bad at all.
>>2536804
I would say part of your issue is your saw, if that is the one you are using, looks to be a hardware store special with impulse hardened teeth? These tend not to be great, as can be seen by the roughness of your cuts. They generally have too much set and are sharpened all from one side so the burr is all on ones side of the saw which causes tracking issues. If it always pulls to the same side you can lightly stone that side, just a pass or two, then test again, may solve your issue, use a cheap fine/extra fine stone that you do not care about,those impulse hardened teeth will put a grove in the stone.

I always cut such joints to be a bit proud, much easier to make them flush with a plane or flush cut saw after the fact than get them perfect. Pine is generally best done with a flush cut saw but a finely set low angle block plane will do the job as well but make sure it is set as fine as you can, pine end grain does not take well to planes. Using a back saw to make them flush will probably not work well since the spine will prevent the saw from laying flush, you will end up cutting into the the other board as well. Flush cut saw are cheap, even good ones and well worth the investment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536804
Forgot to say, a note about stoning saws with impulse hardened teeth, you want to be sure it needs it and not take off too much, impulse hardened teeth often do no take well to being reset, they are too hard, so if you remove to much you may not be able to reset them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536818
Impulse hardened saws are not really worth sharpening, too much work. The following the grain and the rough cut suggests the saw is not actually all that sharp, that fine of a tooth count should leave things pretty smooth on the end grain of pine. The Japanese saws are the best of the cheap saws, I like RazorSaw but Silky and Z-Saw look good as well. But I would just save up and make do in the meantime, $150 for a saw that will last your lifetime is not exactly expensive.

I somewhat disagree with the other anon about wanting two saws, with the fine tooth count it does not really matter much and a rip tooth does just fine on cross cuts. I use my LN rip tooth dovetail for almost all my joinery cuts just because it is far less of a pain to sharpen then cross cuts, I only grab the cross cut carcass when I the extra length and depth of cut is needed. I file all of my back saws rip except that one carcass saw. It is nice to have a cross cut backsaw but far from a must. Picrel, sawed halfway through with my rip dovetail and then switched to the crosscut carcass, rip actually came out better but both are more than good enough and would require the same amount of clean up, in hardwoods they are indistinguishable by cut.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537216
It is more that it is the only one of our domestics which is both suitable for quality furniture and showy. Cherry, white oak and black walnut became the standards for better furniture in the US because they are hard enough to hold up well, fine enough grained to keep their details, work well and are stable, cherry and white oak are fairly plain by comparison to air dried black walnut with all its subtle coloring in the grain. The only other showy woods we have in enough quantity to sustain th Chinese thirst for exotics are the figured maples but they are not particularly stable, work poorly and were already in high demand by other markets.

Elm is a good dark wood and cheap alternative to walnut, not as dark but it will darken and is quite nice looking. Its big issues are the interlocked grain makes it not so fun to work and it smells like pee but the smell mostly goes away once the wood has been dried and completely gone once finished. Elm will sadly become difficult to get soon since all those overplanted elms which have become a victim of dutch elm are running out and their tendencies to grow in mixed forests surrounded by other low market value species means not many of them get harvested outside the city trees with the dutch elm.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537271
This is one spot pocket screw are actually good for. Dowels mean gluing across the grain which is weak and do not allow for wood movement, which is actually one of the weaknesses of pocket screws as well in this use. Standard ways are corner blocks or cross pieces with oversized holes for the screws so the top can move. Figure eights table top fasteners are about as simple as it gets and do a good job. Ultimately the best way depends on the overall table design.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537245
>a new material.

Epoxy manufacture began in the 1940s and its been used to stabilize and homogenize loose/ brittle materials like raw wood slabs and porous stone that could then be used for table tops since the 1950s.

That's also about the time that George Nakashima developed his signature style of live edge furniture that highlighted what would traditionally be seen as inferior lumber and didn't attempt to hide the methods used to keep those pieces intact.
Absolutely none of this is new, but neither is it some sacreligious affront to woodworking. The original point of using epoxy this way was functional and an act of conservation; the more you do it for its own sake the more it just becomes trendy kitsch.

You have two options here. I'm a professional mechanic and small gas engines are also something I do on the side.

Electric chain saws are shit. They just are. Unless you're prepared to be able to split that battery pack open when the cells don't hold any more power then forget it. Corded? Get real.

Chainsaws? Stihl. I've seen a Husqvarna weed Wacker burn out in a summer, one per year according to my roommate. I pulled it all apart, 30psi. compression. They need 90 on the spec sheet just to fire. Poulan, Craftsman, anything else, forget it. Stihl holds value and is one of the best saws out there. Just take care of it like you would a Lambo. You'll really be in for a good time then.

With regard to oil mixing, Walmart has bottles with all kinds of ratio measurements near the outdoor/sports section near the marine 2 cycle oil. May be some near the regular PMV oil as well. Take care now.

Look for gas stations with Rec90. Do you have Wawa or Sunoco around you? Rec90 is 0% ethanol, get that and the 2-smoke oil and you won’t have to worry about it. Costs about as much per gallon as premium. Gas stations near popular boating spots or any off roading places often have it.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2531754
He’s reciting second hand some myth from an old man who repairs small engines and has no idea what he’s talking about. Pretty sure alcohol burns cooler than gasoline, and ethanol is alcohol.

The reason people like to run 0% ethanol
like Rec 90 or overpriced TrueFuel is because ethanol degrades fairly quick and regular E10 gas will clog up those tiny carbs when you let it sit in there for weeks in between use. I’ve also heard it’s not good for some older style fuel lines, the rubber and plastic, but any engine made in the past few decades is designed to be run on gas with minimum 10% ethanol.

>>2529822
I know the idea of amateur radio dying or new technology/changes to regulations killing amateur radio was already cliche before I was born, but is the current situation with digital voice modes and internet linking becoming a threat to future amateur radio use of the VHF and higher frequency bands? Consider:
>a significant portion of VHF/UHF activity these days is digital voice modes or other internet linking like AllStar, with most activity by users of those being radio -> repeater/node -> a server somewhere on the internet with no one else on that repeater/node at the time, rather than radio -> repeater -> radio
>a large number of people who use these digital modes do so via low power hotspots (normally running bluetooth level TX power) that they run themselves via their computer, reducing their radio to a fancy wireless microphone and speaker for their computer, with MMDVM hotspots that allow for people with analog radios to join in driving this point home even harder
>with few exceptions like DMR-MARC and small private servers that don't allow for hotspots, you can even communicate from end to end on many of these networks using a PC/phone client like DUDE-Star or DroidStar, without either party even touching amateur radio bands
How are amateur radio enthusiasts supposed to defend the bands from corporations wanting to gobble them up if this is how these bands are being used these days? Companies can just say lol put your smartphone in a fancy case like pic related to a lot people who use digital voice modes and internet linking at this point, or point them to one of those Zello radios or whichever CB radio manufacturer that was that let you link your CB radio to your phone via bluetooth if they want something more "authentic".

posts.com: Considering this anon's post: >>2532294. What's FM activity like in your guy's area? Prior to 2020, traffic in my area used to be evenly split between 2 meter and 70cm for analog, non internet linked traffic, but now days there's basically zero activity on the 70cm band in my area that doesn't involve digital modes or internet linking. Looking on Repeater Book, about 40%-50% of the 70cm repeaters in my state and the surrounding states are digital mode or internet linked as well. Part of me is tempted to get some older single band 2 meter gear now because I love the aesthetic, after deciding against it in the past because doing so would lock me out of half the local traffic in my area.

If you can’t afford the $100 try another hobby glassblowing is very expensive and the market has gone to shit post Covid fuckery no one has $ for several hundred dollar pipes or glass art and the ones that do have a long list of established artists to buy from. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Why does everyone omit the +1 then calculating darlington gain?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533478
Fundamental theorem of engineering: approximation. There is no point in trying to get the exact figure when gain is varying by 400% due to manufacturing process variations. We're not doing science or math, it's perfectly fine to use methods that would make physicists or mathematicians cringe. No need to be autistic about analytical expressions - throw that shit in excel, copy over formulas from reference books/app notes, add some solver magic and then fudge values a bit more with simulator, real circuit will be off by a few percent anyways because of parasitics you didn't account for and model limitations. The trick is to understand when you can simplify without sacrificing required precision/predictive power.

posts.com: Is clock jitter to a DAC/ADC just some audiophile thing? Is it actually audible? How do you prevent it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535219
Entomb everything in epoxy like the youtube fags. Put a small sign inside that says nigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535231
it manifests as broad-band phase noise or errant harmonics in the signal, depending on if it's random or periodic. It also effectively reduces the resolution of the signal. It's for similar reasons that we use windowing functions when taking the fourier transform of a signal on a spectral analyzer.
Depending on how shit the clock jitter is, yes it can definitely be audible. You decrease it by getting discrete high-quality ADC/DAC ICs with high slew rates, and by supplying them a clean clock signal. Use a precise clock source like a PLL, don't use something like an RC oscillator subject to all kinds of variation. Avoid anything that would incur parasitics like long traces or poor multilayer layout. This will prevent your clock from getting skewed in transit.

>>2535565
>>2535703
A BD139 only has ~0.5V maximum drop from collector to emitter when saturated, it's feasible to make a regulator with that and a RRIO op-amp that's pretty low dropout. You'd just have to use it in the common-emitter configuration, and use a sufficiently low current sense resistor (e.g. for a 0.1V drop), possibly requiring a current sense amplifier if the op-amp won't run well that low. Using a power MOSFET would probably doable too so long as you avoid linear thermal issues. The only issue with common-emitter and common-source topologies for linear regulation is it's harder to get them stable, but since an LED is such a simple load and the feedback path is so direct I think it will be fine, perhaps just with a small cap from inverting input to output.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536218
Technically yes, but in practice you’ll find that to pump any significant current through your load, the RI^2 power dissipation in your current-set/sense resistor/pot will get really high. Because the input voltage to the feedback pin will equal the reference voltage during normal operation. It’s common practice to use a much smaller resistor (milliohms) and add an op-amp differential amplifier with a gain of 100 or so. Just ensure that your op-amps can sense and output close to he ground rail. This is what those LM2596 modules with more than one trimpot do, though they’re bucks.

Another modification is to add external error amplifiers And an external reference voltage that you can adjust by hand (or via a DAC) for current or voltage control. Especially for a buck converter, this lets the voltage or current output be lower than what would equal the reference voltage.

You can also have both current and voltage feedback by using diodes to combine the signals from both a voltage divider and a current sense amplifier, such that the higher of the two voltages will enter the feedback pin. It’s also an option to use a diode to implement overtemperature protection from a thermistor voltage divider. This kind of diode-combining circuit is already included in the TL494 switching control IC. It also has accessible error amplifiers and a fixed reference, that you can either use or replace with your own.

>>2536559
Make a capacitive water sensor by covering the raw copper in epoxy. Hook it up to a 74HC14 (or 74LVC1G14 if you're feeling fancy) with a sensible resistor to make an RC relaxation oscillator, and use a 555 to detect when it goes below a certain frequency. Might be too low a capacitance to use another 555 to make the oscillator, but it might be fine. A CMOS one would likely work.

You can also prolong the corrosion by using it with a really high value pull-down resistor (1-10M) to switch a MOSFET that switches the relay. Plating it with tin or nickel is also a good idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537092
As I think you have already established, the original is a rapid start ballast. This can be confirmed by the photograph that shows only two output leads. A rapid start ballast for a single lamp will have just 2 output leads. A rapid start ballast will have a more or less constant current into the lamp. The exact power delivered will depend on the lamp. for instance, more voltage will appear across a longer lamp. More voltage at same current gives higher power, which is why the ballast can be used with the variety of lamps of differing power listed in the ballast specs. You may have more ballast choices than it seems. I could be wrong, but I think a sure thing would be to find a ballast with 2 output leads having a compatible power level when used with a compact lamp like you have.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537206
Resin 3D printer works well, ~50 micron resolution out of the cheap ones, fancier ones now push <30 microns.
Scale your shit appropriately and bring it into UVTools, slap your board down into the vat, expose it.
Depending on your printer, it might be easier to stick the board directly to build plate with some hot glue.
Works as solder mask, works to add a silkscreen, pretty versatile process.
If you pick up a spare vat cheap, you can use actual UV solder mask, but don't do it in your normal vat.
It's a massive bitch to clean out, it'll tint or otherwise fuck with your resin for actual printing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537358
A note unrelated to the replacement problem: many 4 pin lamps can also be used with a rapid start ballast. In this case the pins at the lamp ends are shorted together and tied to a single ballast output. Not doing so will create uneven current in the lamp electrode and shorten the life of the lamp. Also, in general, use of rapid start ballasts will shorten lamp life when compared to programmed start ballasts that preheat the electrodes before ignition (two wires per lamp end). A rapid start ballast can have more than two leads if it is designed for use with more than 2 rapid start lamps, but the lamps still connect to only one ballast output on each end.

posts.sub: Old ass fuse box in my garage
posts.com:
Bought a house this summer and this is the fuse box in my garage. I was not thinking the other day and ran my old table saw and an electric heater on the same circuit and popped one of the glass fuses. I replaced the blue 15 amp fuse that was visually blown but the outlet and entire circuit that I wanted to use was still dead. I pulled the main and range boxes and tested the continuity of the shotgun shell looking fuses and they all worked fine. I then took my tick tracer and saw that the red 20 amp glass fuse had no power to it, but the other three blue ones were fine. The red 20 amp fuse doesn't look blown like the one I replaced did.
I'm confused. I'm a low volt guy so I know a little, but not a lot about higher voltages.
1. What's going on here?
2. Can I pull these glass fuses and main/range boxes without walking back to my house and killing the power to my shop, or will I get zapped? I'm not super scared of 120, but I'd like to avoid it if possible.
3. The guy before me left a more modern used panel in the garage, seems like he intended to switch it out and never got to it. I have a buddy who is a licensed electrician but lives about an hour away, is this something I could safely swap out with some facetime help from my buddy?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537372
>the red 20 amp glass fuse had no power to it
Can still be bad even if it looks good. Its pretty simple shit. If there is power going to the fuse, but none coming out, it's a bad fuse, otherwise its further downstream.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537372
pulling out main fuses will keep you from getting zapped without killing power at the main house panel, as long as you aren't touching the lugs or wires upstream of the main/range fuses thatcome in from the top. Sometimes the little round fuses just need to be tightened counterclockwise slightly. They aren't blown, but they loosen just enough to break the circuit sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2537378
I'm a professional architectural engineer, specializing in elec design, as well as former electrician and this is the answer. just put a multi on either end of the fuse to rule it out. do not use a voltage detector or tracer. It will pick up anything near an electric field, and they are unreliable.

2. please do no work on this until you kill the power to it... theoretically you should be able to just pull the fuse. But this shit looks jank, and old, and you're already having problems.
Be safe not dead.

3. As far as you swapping out the panel - I'm hesitant to say yes if you don't understand how fuses work. No offense. Sub feeds get tricky, don't know where you're at but it could require a permit. and by the looks of that old ass feeder no licensed electrician in their right mind would land that shit back on a new panel. So maybe just do it anyway so you can learn and get him to make final connections and inspect?

It's still industry standard. This whole "stick is obsolete lol" myth is one of many I want to dispel.
Reality is flux core doesn't perform anywhere near as well as a low hydrogen rod. It isn't anwhere near as portable and creates chalky welds that are prone to shearing. To get good performance from flux core you still need to run shielding gas & high amps, which means you can kiss doing it out in the field goodbye.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535824
If you're a demonstrably good welder nobody asks about qualifications. Big companies have in-house engineers that sign off your work, once you've proven yourself they don't even check before signing.
If you can stick weld decently, you're a useful bastard almost anywhere, see: farmeranon itt.
I'd put my welding experience on a CV for a job at Google.
>how do i get peelers consistently?
Good temp, right rods, clean material. Having somewhere for your slag to escape helps a lot too, welding inside channels is a bitch because the slag seems to fuse to the weld, whereas doing an up the impurities fall away and I get nice, glassy slag that falls right off.
Clean material is probably #1 though. You might be able to burn through that rust or paint, but it still ends up inside your weld

is 1C generally the best rate to charge lipos? I've seen some spec sheets that say they can charge 2-3C.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: >>2527385

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527464
1C is like going the speed limit. Best to stick to it whenever convenient, but not a big problem to break it by even 3x when in a hurry.

I charge at 1C at home and at 2-3C in the field. You DO shorten the lifespan, but it's a trade I'm willing to make. Also, my lipos die a horrible firey death before they get chemically exhausted from charging a bit too fast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527464
1C is only necessary to max the life of the battery, or if you probably/possibly have bad cells. Otherwise the manufacturer recommended charging rate should be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528681
I think the quality varies rather from model to model rather than the manufacturer, the only real difference would be lesser support for less common models. It would be best to watch reviews of a given model and see what features it has that you would need. The models in one price range are generally very similar with slight variation of features. Once you get to higher price ranges there will be better gimbals, more switches, color screens, support for more external modules and such, at least with OpenTX/EdgeTX radios. With that Betafpv radio you would need to upgrade when/if you get something else that runs on a different protocol, or needs a long range module.
Here's a list of radios that run on and are supported by Edge/OpenTX.
https://edgetx.org/faq.html
https://www.open-tx.org/radios

Actually all of the filtering in betaflight/iNav that makes acro flight so smooth is way more CPU/RAM intensive than autonomous flight. You can run waypoint missions on an 8-bit APM (ATmega 2560), but you can’t run any of Betaflight’s modern filtering features on anything less than a 32-bit F4.

>>2536160
My GPS placement was very deliberate. In the back, it had to compete with its wires running next to nearly every other wire, and the video+telemetry signals were blasting it terribly. Used to get 7 sats if I was lucky. In the front, it's 16-24.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536160
> APM is EOL since years and not supported for a long time. newer FW versions of ardupilot do have those filters

I know. My point was that the automation itself (in the sense of waypoint navigation, etc.) isn’t computationally expensive, as drone logic goes. If you compare Betaflight with stock settings against Arducopter with stock settings, on exactly the same FC, the former will have a much higher CPU load during flight because the default loop rate is much higher & far more of the filters are enabled by default.

>cams are the most common source of RF noise

HD cams with built-in wireless features maybe, but I’ve literally never heard of anybody experiencing issues with RF noise from a FPV camera.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2537294
The general thoughts people have had on Remote ID is that they think it's worthless to public safety, dangerous to personal safety, and a financial burden on the end user. The system cranks out a WiFi or BLE signal to the public to tell lots of info about a UAV and pilot, omitting only the name of the user. It's been speculated to be generated out of either lobbying from congress/DHS, or big businesses wanting to do autonomous deliveries.

Most people are saying that they do not plan to comply, and will tell the FAA to kick rocks. To this day, there are still no recreational UAV caused deaths, but they keep screeching about safety. Basically, just show up, fly, and leave. Law enforcement has better things to do than check to see if your toy helicopter is following rules more strict than automobiles.

>>2514747
Thats a pretty vague descriptor; personally the ones that make my eye start to twitch are when people take quality materials and apply them to garbage structures in ways that render them useless even for recycling.
Extreme deterioration can be repaired, good architecture that's been butchered or otherwise defiled can be restored, but something like exquisitely turned exotic hardwood balusters or flooring or amazing natural stone that's been hacked up to go into some tract house shitbox in a failed attempt to make it appear "grand" and "luxurious" is usually not worth the effort to try reclaiming it.
In my experience Persians are some of the worst offenders and will projectile vomit money and precious materials all over the lowliest and most structurally questionable houses, and then when the 24×24 exotic imported marble quarry tile flooring cracks because the cheap ass stucco tract house they put it in is sliding down the hill and they call you to "fix it", they act like you are trying to scam them by suggesting a real repair and not just doing a cosmetic bandaid.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530159
Artificially aging your tools is pretty cringey. That's the equivalent of "distressed jeans," which is something no decent tradesman owns.
>Exception: hard hats. If you buy a new hard hat, drag it through the sand to take the shine off it. At least where I work, guys will actively harass other guys on site if their hard hats or hi-viz look too new.

You're not asking about this, but CONDITIONING your tools increases their lifespan and is a mark of professionalism. Rusty, splintery, poorly cared for tools are the mark of either a fucktard or a poser and you need to steer clear of them.

To condition your wooden tools, use a plane to take off the varnish and apply linseed oil. If your tool handle is oversized, you can use your plane to give it an octagonal shape which many old trades guys swear by for comfort. Allow it to cure completely, then apply at least one layer of Walrus Brand tool oil, both to the handle and to the steel head of whatever tool it is. If your tool (or PPE) has leather components, use Obenauf's leather oil and conditioner. If the tool is rusted, use steel wool or another abrasive to remove excess rust and restore remaining rust with 30% vinegar. If you're going to paint your tools, use the highest quality enamel paint you can get your hands on and follow the instructions else it will not last. Should your tool have moving internal parts, the manufacturer likely recommends specific products to lubricate with, and there are many different kinds of lubrication and grease that vary in their intended use (temperature/climate, use severity, etc).

So why am I telling you about restoring and conditioning your tools if you're interested in being a poser? Because you'll have tools that look like someone cares for them, even if nobody's using them for their intended purpose, and that will make them "more characterful" than any amount of fake patina or artificial aging could ever achieve.

>>2530271
Should do lug nuts 90% of the time. I had a 450lb rated brushed corded guy and it would do lugs on passenger cars as long as they weren’t rusted on or way overtorqued by a tire shop. Also impacts in general are handy for shit that’s difficult with hand tools, like stuff that wants to move or spin when you put torque into it, mower blades being a common example and now you can remove lugs while the car is in the air.

The thing with the new brushless ones is they’re way more compact. You can get more torque in something half the size and the big ones will break loose shit that has you bending breaker bars and yelling like a sailor.

Being able to pull off wheels without cracking the lugs loose on the ground will make you love it. Saves a bunch of time whenever you need to remove and reinstall 4 wheels.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2531775
It will probably work for the grinder. That’s exactly the situation where impacts shine, when you’re having a hard time keeping something in place. Like I was watching my boomer neighbors struggling with the blade on an edger for an hour because it’s hard to jam the blade up and the bolt holding the blade hadn’t been removed in years, but wasn’t like super tight or rusted. I grabbed the little 3/8” stubby which isn’t any more powerful than what you can do by hand with a 1/2” ratchet, but I held the blade of the edger with one hand and spun the bolt out in 2 seconds.

If you end up with a real big truck, the high torque 1/2” cordless guns will normally do those, but most truck shops with Class 8 shit use a 1” impact wrench. I’ve talked to diesel mechanics who use the big 1/2” on truck lugs and it works most of the time but makes the wrenches die a premature death because it’s a struggle for them.

>>2529669
>45 degree
Not sure about that. The higher on the pole the guy wires the stronger the leverage, but also the further on a 45° angle. Leverage works two ways, so the stronger, the stronger wire is required. The further on each the more stretch is introduced. Ground space and wire length are not usually unlimited. I think something around 60% up would be more efficient as you're dealing with inertia as well. It's a second year engineering problem, maybe pt6 it to /sci/

Do you have a detent pin or hog ring?

Other anon mentioned the HF sockets, they’re ok but the cheap ones don’t fit in certain tight spots because the walls are real thick to compensate for shitty metal. I think it comes down to CR-V vs CrMo.

Pic related. The bigger one is a cheaper socket, you can see the goofy taper on top and it looks like a dong and has thicker walls. Sometimes they don’t fit in spots that a chrome socket will fit.

Gearwrench and Sunex will both sell you nice impact sockets for a reasonable price. If you go on Amazon, SATA is basically an Amazon house brand made by GW and there are some deals to be had on those sets. People shill Tekton, and their stuff is decent but their cheaper impact sockets have the shitty taper. The work 95%+ of the time, but when they don’t fit, you will be mad at yourself for being a cheapass.

posts.com: so why couldn't this be a thing? water from public water main fill a big underground container then moved into your home? my thoughts being, in emergency events where water isn't available you have a 500-1000 gallon tank of it that could be accessed with a hand pump. i hear old folks talk about fucking fill your bathtub when there's an emergency so when the water turns off you can just dip out bathtub water and boil it, why doesn't anyone do this?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536008
>why doesn't anyone do this?
millions of people do this around the globe; that's basically how the public water supply systems work in a lot of countries. Often the public supply main pipe is only run at a very low pressure, so it's not enough to get up to the second story of a building etc
So instead you have a small basin at or below ground level which fills up and then a pump which moves the water to a tank on the roof--- this provides a gravity feed with enough decent pressure for your showers etc.

This has the advantages of allowing a cheaper and less robust supply system while also giving people a reserve that allows them to use water during outages, or in third world countries where the water pressure only happens once a day during pumping hours

Technically, all you need is an appropriately sized file and some patience.

>your budget
>your machine(s) (if any)
>the fixturing and indexing you have available on the machine(s) we have no way of knowing that you own
>the type of gear to be made
>the material you want to make the gear out of
>the gear's size
>the number of teeth
>and so on

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2514282
Depends on the type of gear and the tooth profile. For simple spur gears the best options are shaper and horizontal milling machine. A vertical mill could also do the job, but the set up would be a bit awkward and a lot less rigid than a horizontal. In all cases you need an indexing fixture. For milling processes you would need to purchase the correct cutter for your desired pitch. With a shaper you just need a single point tool, which you could probably grind by hand.

posts.name: Anonymous

During the month he was off, me and the manager were tweaking programs and there was HUGE room for improvement with little work. Our boss told us to leave it alone to not stir up trouble though. On one hand he wanted us to be the guys to try and push efficiency and better work out of the old guys, but at the same time didnt have the balls to really do it.
He wanted to start slow and put your foot in the door sort of thing.
Manager wanted everything to be at hands reach, instead of running around in circles etc etc.
So he gave directions to think about ways they can improve their work areas and maybe move stuff if they wanted.
Time and time again, asking them to find something they can improve, allowing them to take initiative. They always did nothing, its as good as it can be. Not sure if it was laziness, or retardedness, stubbornness. Pure incompetency regardless.

One thing that I remember the most, learning the cylindrical grinder. Torque wrench set to like 20ftlbs for a CBN wheel, the bottom lock was loose.
Seemed low and I asked why, he had no answer.
I looked it up in the manual, it was like 60ftlb or something.
Said "well lets just put it where it needs to be" and I tightened wrench to 60 and he just blew up screaming at me. Said it was done for an explicit reason and that im going to fuck something up and he wont have it or get blamed for it.
Took it from me and loosened wrench it all the way back down to 20.

I left after 2 years. It was an ongoing battle between the new guys vs the old guys. We had enough work to do of our own, but we were also tasked with a looming "dont let the company fail if one of those machines break and you arent ready to take on the work"

It taught me early on, just because someone has done something for 20 years, doesnt mean they know what they are talking about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528713
>I've got a decent background with CNC programming/operation from work/schooling

Is there any reason why your limiting yourself to manual machines then?

IMO the only reason someone should go for manual machines in a home shop is because they've got absolutely no desire to learn CAD/CAM/CNC. The main advantage of CNC for the home shop is that it allows you to get away with significantly less tooling, no longer do you need a comprehensive set of drills and reamers, just drill to a nominal size and interpolate the rest with a endmill, with a couple of threadmills you can replace 90% of taps, radii become trivial, etc. All of the little extra bits and pieces you need to be capable with manual machines really add up quickly, manual mills are a false economy if you go beyond using it as a precision drill press.

That being said I still keep a manual lathe and small drill press around, the latter for small (<0.093") drilled holes where feel is important, and the former because I rarely do anything too complicated on a lathe.

>>2528974
>>2528957
>hell of a lot cheaper than even a low end cnc like a haas or even a tormach

I'm not taking about a brand new VMC with all the bells and whistles, if you're buying new for a home shop you're making a mistake. What you want to keep an eye out for is for one of the older knee type CNC mills, think like a Proto-Trak, Tree Journeyman, Bridgeport BOSS series I/II, etc.

You can usually pick these machines up for a song as most people are scared of electronics and they're not economical for real shops, plus the iron is better than anything you could buy new. I'd prioritize something with a 40 taper spindle because it's way easier to find tooling.

We're in an era where homebrew CNC systems have gotten pretty well developed and cheap, if you can keep an older machine going on it's original controller/drives, great, but don't hesitate to swap it out for modern electronics if issues crop up. I've personally got a BOSS 5 Bridgeport that I picked up for $2500, I threw another 1K at a computer, motion controller, stepper drives, VFD, and a Mach license. Within a couple of weeks of tinkering I had it up and running, it'll do everything a manual mill can and it'll run circles around a manual if you have a moderately complex profile or repeat work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529838
I wouldn't even be sure where to point you to get started, this is one of those subjects that can be both very simple and insanely complicated at the same time, you can't really learn without just doing it.

In my case I'm a full time CNC Programmer during the day, so the actual CAD/CAM/Operation side of things wasn't a real concern. I initially bought one of those eBay special 3018 routers which I used to get familiar with Mach and the electrical hardware side of the deal. I figured if I crashed or bricked it it wouldn't be a huge write-off, I also found it was useful for debugging purposes while doing the conversion on the Bridgeport. From there it's really just a matter of making sure you size everything correctly for the machine you're intending to drive, it's all more or less Legos, just read the manuals and take it one step at a time.

I would not attempt anything with a full sized machine as a first project unless you're a fairly competent tinkerer/fabricator and have a bit of cash. I'm not trying to say it's crazy expensive, but there's a very real possibility that you make a mistake and smoke a $2-300 motion controller/BOB/VFD/ect, if that would sink the project this might not be for you. That being said, because everything is off the shelf it's generally way cheaper than "Proper" CNC components, my entire setup cost less than the replacement servo drive for one of the horizontals I used to run.

>>2529957
For the CAD/CAM side of things just downloading a cheap software to play around with is a good start. If you learn one software and are competent with it you've practically learned them all. Fusion 360 is free for hobbiests if I remember correctly, which comes with free basic CAM functionality as well. To play around with it I would get a cheap router like >>2529933 did. Just play around with plastics and wood with increasingly complex parts and such. Good way to practice too is to learn the g code by manually coding it yourself at first, then using CAM once you start getting into 3D toolpaths. Gives you actual appreciation for the software and let's you know what the hell you're looking at if you have to edit the code it spits out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529252
>What you want to keep an eye out for is for one of the older knee type CNC mills, think like a Proto-Trak

Golden advice.^ I strongly recommend taking a community college machining course BEFORE buying a machine tool and while there go beyond the curriculum and volunteer which is a great way to get personal machine time. I did that with machining and welding programs and worked for the school afterwards. If I didn't have severe chronic pain I'd still be there. Many schools hire from within like they did my bro who I encouraged to take the course.

Don't be afraid to train formally for anything. I've decades in mechanics, aviation, and much more. I've taken and taught classes and learned a shitload both ways. Machining training gives you a serious edge and profoundly changes the way you relate to metal, machines and the world around you.

My pro machinistbro is rich in no small part due to two CNC open knee mills. They're amazingly versatile.

I suggest taking CAD first unless you're already proficient since once you know CAD you can think in CAD.

>>2529957
I would visit local machine shops and ask what they want to see in an ideal student or apprentice. I promise you'll surprise the shit out of them which can open doors. That way you can study what they use which may get you a job one day. If not it never hurts to network. I fix computers for my bros shop and get all sorts of leftovers for my home shop. He let me use his manual machines after I'd gone to school and hired several people from it.

Machining is a mentoring culture where they understand only true enthusiasts should be machinists. Stop by some Friday afternoon and if they're busy offer to come back because determination is so rare these days. Be chill, friendly but listen more than talk. If you hit it off perhaps you can do chores like cleaning up the shop (which is everybody's job, not hard at all and lets you get up close to get a visual and some tactile appreciation of the equipment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536081

I'd just run an air hose up the wall, personally. Alternately, scrounge around for deals on anything that basically amounts to a small, oilless compressor and some spare parts. Airbrush kits, O2 concentrators, reciprocating vacuum pumps, etc.

If you're looking for a project, you could get the cheapest 12V tire inflator you can find and modify it for longevity. Cleaning up/polishing the bore, fitting PTFE seals, and swapping the motor out wouldn't be too hard.

Your best option is probably just to buy a bare compressor pump, though. Something like:

https://www.ebay.com/itm/403994727816

They're frequently used on a small air compressors, but you don't really need the tank, regulator, pressure switch, or associated hardware to connect them all together. Just a switch (and/or contactor) to turn it on. A pressure relief valve on a T-fitting would be cheap, smart insurance, and I'd definitely recommend doing that.


As an aside, I am astounded by how quiet these pumps are. I'm used to the roar of the everyday 2-cylinder compressor pump in the shed, which can pretty easily be heard through two walls when it comes to life. I got a small, much more portable compressor and, just for a moment, wondered if it was broken when I turned it on. The thing's like casual conversation volume, maybe even less.

>>2536525
>any tips?
Long term goals, and realistic roadmaps to get there.
Once a long term NEET, always a long term NEET. You became NEET because of your personality, and you cant run away forever.
What does "going beyond the clutches of wageslavery" mean to you exactly?
So obviously you want to live a NEET lifestyle still, or at least a less structred more freeing life?
How are you going to do that by... being a wagecuck in a shop?
Whats your exit plan?
Whatever magical opportunity you want wont happen on its own, you actively have to make it happen.

Everyone who wants to break free of the 9-5 wants to own a small business, or a bunch of rental houses, or something else similar like that.
How are you going to do that?
Who is going to fund it? Why would they fund you?
If a bank were somehow to hand you that cash tomorrow, are you equipped to actually run whatever business you want? Could you manage the money?
When exactly would you be ready?

If you dont plan on working in a machine shop the rest of your life, you need to be doing this work right NOW.
You should be studying business, and finances, and whatever else is relevant

Go to the bank or credit union and talk to a counselor RIGHT NOW about building your credit. Learn about their roadmaps for getting a business loan. Think 3-4-5 years down the line.

Get your job, live at home with mom, save all your money, work towards your goals.
Buy a house the second you can, but RENT IT OUT, acquire assets.

You have to do the legwork now, not start thinking about it 5 years after getting a job. You arent going to save money if your are personally paying a mortgage, and all your own bills, and a big car loan every month.

It may not feel like it, but there is a small bit of fortune in the fact you have a mother who allows you to live at home forever, and you havent knocked a bitch up. You are a clean slate.
Be smart about it

>>2517577
Tempered, untempered or laminate?
I know fuckall about construction stuff but my understanding is that there is a considerable difference between the properties of those three glasses.
Tempered even though it may feel sturdy it's vulnerable to stress concentration and may fail spectacularly due to a compromised edge or stress at the mounting point.
Untempered will cause the hollywood death shards but won't break off all at once. Your wife might even prick her finger when picking up the shards.
And laminate will flop over if ever broken. which can happen much more easily than the other two as it's softer for any given thickness.
Glass bannisters just seem like an overall unnecessary pain for the privilege of having visitors seeing my hairy ankles.

>>2535612
>polish rocks
Same process as polishing anything: start coarsest you have down to finest you have. Have some way to remove the material from the surface as you go, whether it be air or water or oil.
The only quirk that may arise from doing rocks is the issue of relative hardness. Silicon carbide (the abrasive that's very likely on your sandpapers) comes in at about 9.2 mohs. So there's stuff it won't scratch. But more importantly, it will remove less hard materials at different rates.
So, if you have a sedimentary rock with, like, limestone with quartz intrusions, that limestone will melt while the quartz will barely dent. So your surface may be polished but not flat.

Get protective glasses. The cheapo cutting discs that come with a chink dremel break the moment you apply any lateral force. When that happens it will fire those shards at your face 100%. It's not painful if one hits the skin but you do not want a shard embedded in your eye. Maybe invest in a few better ones. They have a grid structure and you'll get like five for the same price you can get 30 shitty ones. It's worth it, though.

Also the rock could contain particles that could be launched. You need something for the rock dust, ideally wear a FFP2 mask too.

Tobacco Leaf Tips
(1) If the leaf is too dry, lower the heat, too wet raise the heat to max 130f. If still too wet lower the humidity.

(2) If the leaves are moist, they will mold in about two or three days. If you put a hygrometer in the chamber you will find that at 70 percent relative humidity they will be very pliable but dry. That is about what you'll want.

(3) Remember, aging will always improve tobacco, and any tobacco leaves can be kiln cured if it has been properly stored (humidity no lower than 50% to 65%). Smoking uncured tobacco is unpleasant and dangerous as the nicotine and ammonia contained can be fatally high, not to mention it will taste like your smoking leaves from your front yard.

Source:
https://www.leafonly.com/tobacco-harvesting-curing-fermenting.php

You might wanna to invest in a humidifier and a wood stove that you can keep on slow burn for a week OP. You could also try out the same method people use curing weed, where you put a small amount of you tobacco in a sealed glass jar and let it sit, but I don't know how tobacco will react to that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532989

Your leaf is too green, it wont work right. It should be completely yellow/brown. You let it dry too fast.

If you want to proceed anyway, you need to look up "kilning" tobacco. Most people use a purpose built kiln/hotbox. Others use a stove or crockpot and mason jars.

I let mine fully dry slowly, then rehydrate it with a spray bottle. Then its packed into a vacuum bag and put in a ~140*F sous vide bath for a while. This basically pasteurizes it but doesn't denature the enzymes responsible for aging.

However, one bag did wind up doing some gross anaerobic stuff, and wound up smelling like a dog poop on a hot summer day. Your mileage may vary.

Good luck and post results

>>2518885
It was the combination of a few factors, but the biggest one is called "dot gain". Colors are made by mixing size and location of dots in 4 different colors. Sort of like how digital screens mix RGB pixels together to create colors.

When you print those dots, there are factors that can make the dots larger or smaller than intended. In this case the paper it was printed on absorbed the ink more, creating larger dots. There might have been other factors, I don't know.

The ad was already very dark and moody looking to begin with. I did one quick pre-press at a local printer, and it came out dark... I had them lighten it a bit and due to time/money had to send the files right away.

I was really proud of the ad. It was my first "big" print ad, and I also handled the photography and design from top to bottom. Like, I was planning on framing a copy of it lol.

In another life when i worked in IT as an admin and coder, i mistakenly connected a standard null modem rs232 cable to a UPS. it shut itself down. Since a lot of loads were not load balanced to another source, they went dark, and there was probably write back cache enabled without bbu on some some servers. bringing everything back took 12 hours. there was a SAN but fortunately it did not suffer too much. Some backups had to be restored. file system integrity checks had to be performed. some files were lost and had to roll back to a day prior from backups. Always use the original APC serial cable. its written on the connector. Management took it well because fuck ups were extremely rare and I performed well.

ah hospitals... it reminds me one day when I worked at a large hospital network admin center some years ago. the fuck up was not my fault, but basically the fm200 fire extinguisher went off and the overpressure and accoustic and thermal shock fried a bunch of SAN disks and server disks. VMs had to be restored and some standalone servers for the radiology department were tricky to restore to functionality (they had too old backups) and dlls and what not had to be restored using the windows recovery console. it took a week or more to go back to normal. I then advised to use an hypoxic fire protection. the datacenter was inside the hospital campus so they could route some nitrogen if they really wanted to. I am not sure though if hypoxic fire prevention is as reliable to prevent all fire scenarii.

>>2535330
https://www.weldpundit.com/vertical-welding/

Vert for vertical
Stove for downhill
A vert weld deeply penetrates & is naturally slower to lay with far more operator skill required.
A stove or downhill can be 'proper', but is quite likely to sit on top of the metal joint with negligible fusion. Not important in thin shit, very important in thick, load bearing members, right :)
A muppet can make a stove weld look good, even a gnarly vert is probably stronger than the parent metal around it.
