I'm a machine operator at a large glass company which mostly provides machined blanks of very specialized glass types.
>company is headquartered in Europe so we use the metric system for consistency even though my plant is in the US
>few days after coming back from some time off, got an order to cut up a large casting on our wire saw
>these castings are big, several feet cubic in dimension and weigh about as much as your car
>saw uses a big, moving table about 3 feet off the ground, and since glass is non-magnetic we lift these big castings there with a vacuum-powered suction cup on the end of a gantry crane
>since the vacuum company is American, all the vacuum pads are rated in lbs
>biggest one is about 3 feet in diameter and is rated for about 5,000lbs
>this particular casting was too thin to lift with that pad, and I had recently found a tear in the gasket of our smaller 2,500lb vacuum pad
>the work orders have the weight of the material on the page, but sometimes we'll cut part of a casting for one thing and have a chunk remaining that has to be split another way, so it's not always accurate
>this particular block was listed as being ~1,000 kgs, but looked a bit small so I got out my tape measure to double check

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536513
>very familiar with this glass type and I know it's density so I can calculate the approximate weight
>take the length x width x height in cm, multiply by density in g/cm^3 and multiply by 1,000 to get the weight in kgs
>answer comes out to about 1,000, and I'm right b a 1000lb vacuum pad
>need to multiply by 2.2 to convert to lbs, but am spaced out thinking I already did
>tell coworker (shift lead) the block is only 1k lbs so this vacuum pad will work (it was also the biggest one I knew of at the time which would fit)
>still raise it up on a forklift beside the table so we just have to pick it up and move it a few feet to load it. both of us are sketched about it because the block looks big and we don't really have the right equipment
>use the remote, suction the block, lift it up, start moving it slowly, and 3/4ths to the table it drops right off the pad
>we're both standing right beside it with our hands on it to stop it from swinging (this is common practice)
>lands squarely on the wiresaw table, doesn't fall off, doesn't hit the forklift, doesn't squish me or my shift lead's toes, doesn't even chip the glass
>he nervously cusses me out for not moving fast enough with the crane, like that would have helped much
>very lucky it didn't land worse, but that's why we treat weight with respect and don't stand under it
>never told management and they never checked the cameras, so got off free
>group lead eventually went to some other corner of the building and found a pad rated for 1,800lbs to finish the job

>>2532756
I don't have a good background to base any job recommendations off of. The tl;dr is I'm someone that can solve problems in an effective manner.
I work in a fabrication shop that is mainly B2B, we do literally anything and everything, and most of my job is telling my boss, and therefore the client, to fuck off, or figuring out how to do it on a bare bones budget.
I went to school for computer science. I enjoy programming, but not the industry at large, so I left so I could work with my hands again.
I do CNC/machining work, general fabrication. Basically I take a design document and work to make it a reality.
I have almost absolute freedom in my job, my boss trusts me to get the project made, and I have basically no micro managing as a result.
I love the problem solving aspect of this type of work, I love figuring out processes, building jigs, improving inefficiencies, but none of this was taught to me, it was always something I've been interested in since I was very young.
If you like problem solving, esp for someone else, fabrication work is good.
I enjoy problem solving too much to the point that I'll probably leave my job soon to pursue my own prospects. But I still love what I do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not the best at story telling...
Was working doing house renovations for a "certified" contractor friend. I was helping with demo on a slab house so we had a sonar/survey company come in to mark out all the important stuff in the slab like electrical, air ducts, and water.

>Running the jackhammer to run new bathroom plumbing
>Getting closer to the safety "stop" line before a marked electrical conduit, about 12" of space, just doing what I was told
>Suddenly all lights go out and jackhammer stops
>Pull jackhammer out of concrete and huge arc flash erupts
>Was an arc fire for 20 LONG minutes as it burned thru the concrete slab to the exterior
>Meter explodes off exterior wall and starts on fire
>Fire department saves house after power company cuts power

Turned out it was an unmarked conduit that had the houses 200amp main feed. Somehow didn't become a crispy critter on the spot but had to explain what happened to the homeowner and lead contractor. An inspector after the incident found most of the house electrical was unsafe and a fire hazard so homeowner wasn't mad at all. I finished the demo, did the repairs and then was let go because the contractor hired some junkie friends for cheap.

I was a municipal inspector for six months to complete my education. I mainly monitored commercial service installation (sewer/water). My tasks included giving the contractors layouts for how deep to dig and what elevation to set the pipe, then take as-built measurements of the construction and send them to the engineer.

If you want to be in the thick of it, you kinda have to have a job in the field (ie a reason to be on site in the first place) otherwise you'd be a liability and, lets face it, a nuisance to the workers because frankly they just want to do their work and go home.

>>2534546
Its been almost a year since I left that job, and I haven't spent that much time in industry, so take my answers with a grain of salt. And for context I'm a leaf.

>Any ideas for getting a temp job then?
Generally the position I had is offered to those either completing education or is educated and is building experience towards certification. Engineering firms would rather trust someone with ANY civE education than someone who "just like the field". Proof of education shows some level of commitment and employers (the good ones) want to mutually contribute to their own productivity and to the growth of their emplyee's careers.

>What difficulties do you have with overcoming water table constraints?
Unfortunately I can't answer this question but what I have seen with ground water infiltration is that the workers will just dig out a sump pit, and have a pump running while they work.

Do you get leeway for using pre-fab components?
I don't know what pre-fab components you are thinking of, but sewer and water pipes are mass produced and I see the same company's logo on various jobs I've been on. Manholes are made of concrete and made to order because they need to meet a certain elevation when installed. Goes without saying but manhole covers, curb inlets etc. are also mass produced. Fire hydrants are mass produced, but the stack that connects to the main line is manufactured to lenth for the same reason manholes are made to order.

>Do you ever encounter any issues post-compaction?
Installed services must pass tests from the city before being in commission. Pressure test for water and flow test for sewer. One time we had a sewer being tested and they noticed a section of the line was bowed and the pipes were oval shaped. I don't know the exact reason this happened but this was in the winter and the solution was to use heated sand to tamp around the pipe and backfill as usual. This was after they had already backfilled before the testing fyi.

This is all stupid conspiracy theory bullshit, but chicken wire works for a lot of wavelengths.

The key to a faraday cage is the gaps between conductive material must be small enough to catch the wavelengths you're trying to block. Look those up, pick a sufficiently tight weave, line your house with them. Just staple that shit to the walls.
Should block most shit.

>>2523747
Doug would of course claim that that pic just shows how needlessly complicated a typical bermuda rigged boat is and that junks are superior on that count alone but a) that's not a typical bermuda rig even for something intended for singlehanding and doesn't *need* that many lines led aft...and b) junk running rigging isn't necessarily simple, especially when set up for singlehanded operation.
Picrel is the boat of the guy who did more to advance singlehanded offshore sailing and junk rig adaptation to modern/western hull forms than anyone, just as an example of what a proper setup looks like.
He was a legendary yachtsman and pioneer in offshore sailing techology and junk rigging who proved his ideas with multiple blue water passages, I doubt that Doug would even recognize his name if he heard it.
Also worth noting that after that boat was proven seaworthy and safe in a number of Atlantic crossings, it sank on an Atlantic crossing-

"Jester competed in the first OSTAR Transatlantic race in 1960, which was won by Sir Francis Chichester in Gypsy Moth II . Jester came second. She competed in every single subsequent OSTAR, but in 1989 was seriously damaged under sail and lost."
http://www.collars.co.uk/uk_galaxy/info/1/masts_and_spars/6/the_famous_modified_folkboat_jester

Oddly enough there's a recent post on Seeker's FB from a guy who has built an all steel 42' trimaran from an old piece of chimney pipe with smaller pipes for the amas...
He's had it on the water for a few years and actually sailed it, so he's ahead of Doug in that regard, and appears far more sensible and humble even though he tends to come to Doug's defense quickly based on having been called a nut.
But like Seeker his amateur build has been fraught with hurdles and re- re- re- configuring of issues that "haters" warned him about, and his original goal of travelii around the world in it is in limbo. The design is hydrodynamically questionable but I've seen worse and it appears reasonably well built.
It's kooky as hell but he's actually doing it (sailing) and rather than being a hostile asshole he took ownership of the criticism by naming it the SV Pipedream-

"This channel is mainly about my boat Pipedream. I built this boat out of an old cooling tower ( chimney ) some years ago and I am currently trying to complete a refit and finalise modifications so that I can do some sort of trip.

There is a lot of welding, grinding, plasma cutting and painting to do and in some ways this is an abject lesson in why it is easier to just buy a boat. But for those who like to tinker and do things themselves (and are masochistic) then building is an affliction that can not be avoided.

https://m.youtube.com/@SailingSVPipedream/videos

>mizzen
Why even have a mizzen mast?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531128
Split rigs in general allow smaller, easier to handle sails for
any given sail area, which is why they're popular for cruising boats.
Two masted schooners tend to be less naturally balanced (lots of power generated way aft) and harder to control and three masted versions can help balance the sail area out.
Marconi ketches and yawls can be made better balanced than a sloop with a mizzen and allow more sail combinations like jib and mizzen for low power in high winds or a adding mizzen staysail for more power and in light winds.
They can also allow sail/ rig configurations that take advantage of certain loopholes in racing rules, and some yawls are basically just sloops with a mizzen added for some advantage, while ketches are usually designed and masts positioned to use all the masts in normal conditions and may not sail or bslance well without the mizzen.
It's even possible to use the mizzen sheet and a bungee cord to make a ketch or yawl self steer.
In Seekers case much of this will not apply because the mizzen is pretty small and that pilothouse and bulwarks is a massive amount of windage.

I think is assumes a lot; it's never been publicly established that the doc was intended to show Doug in a favorable light. I can't imagine him cooperating if he didn't expect that, but these kinds of productions play into those kinds of expectations all the time for just that reason, when they know all along that the subject won't like the end result.
They certainly *could* decide to bail out and eat production costs, but there's nothing that requires them to and in cases where the subject strings them along and then tries to sabotage the production to gain the upper hand they usually don't just roll over and go away.
That kind of thing makes for an interesting documentary in and of itself, and it's pretty much a given that anything that isn't a slavish love song to Doug's personality and "accomplishments" will cause him to lash out bitterly at the producers, so they have nothing to lose and a fascinating look into a crazy train wreck of sociopathic hubris if they just use what they have and make the film about a lunatic who monkeywrenches a film about him before even doing the thing he's allegedly interesting for, namely building a sailing vessel.

if it's plastic? novus plastic polish, but be careful old plastics can melted by things modern plastics shrug off like rubbing alcohol.

for wood radios, furniture polish, or anything that is compatible with varnish, lacquer, or shellac.

These are sister ships. Both built as steel origami about 75' long. The top boat was done first and was the inspiration for the bottom. The top boat creates buoyant volume by having a tall rounded bow and a flat wide stern. This vessel has sailed to Europe and back using two shitty junk sails. The bottom example has limited buoyant volume due to the low deck at the bow (as shown by the red line), and a steep narrow stern.

>>2535903
This suggestion is really good. As someone that has done some amateur confectionery, I really see the resemblance thanks to this anon.
Caramelized sugar will naturally be yellow/brown-ish. So you'll need to tweak to add the red shades with dye. But you can also adjust the carmelization even after setting, by using a blow torch or heat gun (just remember it will also melt the surface).
It might also end up with air bubbles trapped into it. Which kinda does work with the magma thing, but might mess with the effect of back lighting it. But if you add titanium oxide colorant, that will help make it opaque (and it's a massive color-enhancer).
One thing about sugar though is that it's hydrophilic and will deteriorate from exposure to humidity. So the shelf life of what you make is more "school project" than permanent art piece.

Another thought I had is what about phosphorescence? Like taking the dye from a highlighter and use that to get the glow under UV. Not something I'd ever think of for candy, given the edibility requirement. But might work for a display piece.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2477882
Induction doesn't require material to be magnetic, just conductive. Energy transfer is more efficient when magnetic, but steel will become non-magnetic when sufficiently heated. If anything you would prefer a non-magnetic, non conductive crucible such that the metal is directly heated rather than indirectly through walls of crucible. Big challenge in getting up to temperature is all of the heat losses due to radiation and convection. For cast iron / cast steel graphite-based crucibles are most commonly used. Not straight graphite but don't know the exact formulation.

>>2478010

posts.name: Anonymous

Oh, it's you. You need to learn thermodynamics. The steel furnaces are lined with ceramic liners (usually some cementatious clay). This + the steel's ability to be cooled by air is enough to avoid melting.

Whe the clay liner fails you get all the molten metal shooting out the hole in the now-melted steel.

The lid and liner are very thick relqtovely speaking; this insulates the melt inside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2488793
Most of the iridium on Earth (probably) ended up bonded to iron and is still molten beneath the crust, which is the reason there is so little accessible to us.
We do mine it, it does occur naturally, it's just rare stuff.
There's more of it in meteorites than in the layers of Earth we have access to, that's not unusual, that's true of numerous elements.
This makes it useful as one of the indicators of large meteorite impacts, one of many valid and observed indicators.
That's about it. It's useful stuff, been produced and used commercially for just shy of 200 years now.
It's just uncommon in the top layers of the Earth's crust where we can access it.

In the scale of the universe, it's an element with a fairly high atomic number (77), so it's going to be relatively uncommon compared to "most" elements with lower atomic numbers. This isn't a perfect rule, but it's a decent rule of thumb.
The reasons why are complex, you'd be wanting to read up on cosmic nucleosynthesis to get an idea of how various elements were formed by the Big Bang, exploding stars, merging stars, cosmic rays, all kinds of neat stuff. Isotopes and stability play a big role in this, certain elements don't have known stable isotopes, and are so "unlikely" to exist in nature they may well not exist anywhere in the universe they aren't actively being produced by an intelligence with the intention of producing them, like we do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2490205

The most viable iridium deposits on Earth are massive, fuck-off huge ancient impact craters from around the time the crust was forming an stabilizing. those are actually a big part of the reason Africa has so much mineral wealth in general. Outside of that, you find a some in old volcanic complexes that have eroded away.

You can pull "native" iridium from copper and platinum refining in minuscule amounts, or in very rare igneous deposits as microscopic bare nuggets alloyed with other metals. There's a couple iron-iridium minerals and one copper-iridium mineral that forms naturally as inclusions in deposits of other platinum and iron-group minerals, but they're vanishingly small - 5 - 10 micron in diameter, and very very sparse.

Basically, the tiny amount that we currently produce is all produced "accidentally" as a byproduct of refining other rare metals. most of the viable sources occur as a "side product" of mining gold conglomerates in Africa and gold sands in North America.

it's a damn shame, as iridium complexes might end up being some of the most compelling phosphors and catalysts ever discovered, but no one in their right mind is ever going to suggest large scale industrialization of an iridium-based chemistry. Even metallurgical uses are basically all luxury items at this point, with some very low volume extreme-condition industrial uses.

>>2496976
The power requirements are MASSIVE. Always used for small batch metallurgy or low melting temp metals that need VERY carefully controlled temperature profiles. Large batch Induction heaters are almost always used as reheaters or preheaters these days. Arc heating or gas fired is still preferred.

Induction smelters are great for fine control and quick batching but are more expensive than any other heat source.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2499296
Heat red hot. Oil quench with pliers no swishing (firing tip down). Heat at AT LEAST 500°F (more like 600 if you can) until it shows a good darkening yellow color.

That should give you a proper hardened profile with enough tempering to not explode.

Google search (O1 tool steel tempering graph) and aim for 50-55HRC if you want more info.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2508422
Easy recipe: take some generic 1020 or 4140 or something (a proper quenchable tool steel if you are brave) and cut it into small chunks (or buy some steel shot if lazy). Take some cast iron powder. Pack the chunks VERY WELL and tightly into a crucible and seal it or at least borax the shit out of the top. Bring to half way between the melting temperature of the cast iron and of the steel.

The cast iron melts and diffuses into the steel. Eventually the chemistry of the steel and castiron average out until it is a mass of solid chunks and intermingled semi-solid mushy not-quite-cast iron. Consistency of a concrete that is a little too dry. You need to only heat it long enough to get this diffusion about half way - if it becomes 100% solid you went too long. Allow this to slowly cool so that everything diffuses well together but maintains a distinct pattern.

The steel you used is mostly the original steel (now higher carbon) but is all bound with a web of very carbidic pearlite, carbides, and other high-Si intermetallics.

Anything that is carbide forming (tool steels, bearing steels) resists carbon diffusion through martensite (huge Ni/Cr atoms + small Mn/V atoms fug up the diffusion) so you can develop a decorative oxide layer but maintain strength and hardness.

Look for "impact grade" tool steels if you're making a sword.

Acid reacts with and rapidly corrodes the surface of metal. Can be used in combination with a resist to make some sort of pattern or just applied generally to expose virgin metal, as for weld testing.
You can get both sulfuric and hydrochloric acid from a well stocked hardware store. Sulfuric is sold as drain cleaner, and HCL is sold for cleaning concrete and masonry labeled as muriatic acid. Even the acetic acid in cleaning vinegar will work, albeit more slowly. Copper sulfate, which is sold for horticulture and aquaculture can also be used for etching, but I'm not sure of the specifics of the process.

>>2518598
With PLA I've had the best luck turning the mold upside down and melting at 400C. Then turn up to 450C which will cause anything left to burn out. The kitchen oven won't quiet do it, so I made my own out of a stovetop heating element, inswool, PID, and a washing machine drum. I found a 3D printing filament "Mold-Lay" that is low temp enough to be melted out in the kitchen oven, but still makes a smoky mess and more expensive than PLA. I usually use 50% sand 50% plaster. The 45 minute plaster works better than the 15 minute plaster (and is cheaper too). Use a paint brush to paint the mixture on the surface before fully submerging to make sure it fills all the nooks and crannies. Using 356 aluminum rather than potluck aluminum will give much better results (found someone on Ebay selling for $3/lb).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521382
Instead of just putting a model in plaster and burning it out you make a multi-layered shell of porous ceramic glaze and essentially sand. You then can preheat the entire mold after burnout and fill with metal then let slow cool in the furnace.

The finer the model (wax is historically used for ease of burn out, modern SLA works great but takes longer to burn) the better the end product.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2522066
I think some of the defects I am getting are related to formation of steel during melting out the PLA either due to excessive water or incomplete curing. Molds will often show cracks and the solution is wrap them in duck tape so they don't fall apart due to incidental contact, though I've never had a cracked one break. Perhaps I would be well served by a low temperature curing step. I'll also try using less water next time and mixing water in as needed. (1 plaster : 1 sand : 1 water was too much so I mixed more plaster and sand in; next time I'll start with 1 plaster : 1 sand : 0.5 water). Though maybe something a little richer in water for the first coat on the casting only to make sure it sticks well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
Not sure if it's any use but I have a bit of experience. You shouldn't be seeing blue with just the fuel on, you also don't have to make a huge acetylene flame before lighting the oxy, I'd say once the flame has volume and is putting out thick black smoke then you're good for the oxy. When you're tuning the flame people talk about a neutral flame but it's kinda hard for a beginner to grasp what that means, basically you watch the little flame needle (or needles depending on your nozzle) sticking out the hole (or holes) in the nozzle tip, you want that needle to be as long as possible without the flame flickering or changing color, the base of the flame should be blue with the yellow and orange further out, if you try to make the needles too long the flame will become a bright white and jet out of the nozzle in a sort of thin beam so that's a good way to tell you that you went too far. Sometimes gauges are weird so I can't really help you there, used to have a gauge at the shop that would correctly read the oxygen psi at the pressures we needed but the needle would never drop below 20 psi even when we turned it off. Make sure you have a welding/brazing tip and use good filler, keep the filler shielded by the outer flame not the the inner needle and don't dip that needle into the puddle, that's pretty much it for mild steel, it's kinda like tig when you start going.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524823
>>inb4 don't weld with it

Whoever told you that was a moron. The little torches are great for sheet metal and light work. OA was the only way to weld aircraft parts before TIG was invented in WWII.

Get a copy of the Oxwelders Handbook, no later than 1939 which was peak OA welding era. They're about ten bucks online.

This forum is one of the last with quality OA welding and related equipment posts. It's noob friendly. https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/2-MIG-TIG-Stick-And-Oxy-Fuel-Welding/

Blacksmithanons will also enjoy this place: https://weldingweb.com/vbb/forums/121-Sticky-Forum

A shade 5 face shield is most comfy. Goggles are shit. Your local welding supply has them. Sunglasses also work well but I wear glasses and prefer shields which protect the face.

Determine what make/model torch you have. I buy tips via Ebay and only use US-made torches. Torches are typically cheap and I've got several from the 1930s I pressure tested (with clean compressed air) that sealed perfectly. Ivory soap is fine leak detector and recommended in old factory literature.

Don't sweat the gauge so long as you don't run too high a psi which for OA welding there is no need anyway.

PSI info and some background:
https://forum.millerwelds.com/forum/welding-discussions/7731-pressure-regulator-setting-for-o-a-cutting-and-welding

>>2504840
i'm an arborist by profession.
Even modern high quality chains break from time to time. either from misuse, accident or material fault. on average a chain snaps on me every one to two years. luckily modern chainsaws have a chain catcher under the clutch so even when a chain should snap it will immediately arrest on the catcher as it leaves the bar on the underside and be stopped at the catcher immediately - if you are lucky - just dropping down from the catcher harmlessly or slapping the hand guard on the rear grip where it will lose its momentum.
in the worst of cases one of the chain links will get caught and the rest of the chain will come whipping around on the underside of the bar - miss the hand guard and slap the underside of your rear arm, upper leg or your hip if you are holding the saw sideways.
in any case its going to be like a 35mph whip with teeth but it wont keep running and actually be pulled through your flesh as it hits you. wounds from this should be superficial due to the chain loosing most of its energy on the catch.

should you ever pick up a saw with this safety feature missing or damaged, do not use it!

Grandpa once made a circular table saw. Solid steel, the table itself is at least 1 cm thick, height is adjustable but usually somewhere above waistline. Comes with a planer as well, circa 40 cm wide, adjustable depth. Come think of it idk how much power it draws but it hooks up to a triple-phase 380v and once you're sawing everyone within at least 1 km and outdoors knows. It definitely weighs over 200 kg and putting it indoors for after having been used it usually takes two to push&pull it up a ramp made just for it.

Anyway, over the years he's lost a total of 4 finger phalanges to it. I think there were 3 accidents total and a part of a finger was once put back on but not sure anymore, gotta ask some time. It's still his most prized possession and he worries that we will sell it when he passes but I honestly intend to have it moved to my place, mostly for the planer, at least until I learn how to use the saw safely.

>There's a higher chance of error over an entire career than someone who makes two cuts.
You are conflating opportunity with probability...the opportunity to run your hand through a saw or vice versa exists each time you use one...that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable, but the opportunity to use that tool *without* an accident exists each time you use it as well. The total number of uses doesn't change that.
>>2523437
>Turns out when you do the same thing over and over as a career, you get complacent and overconfident.
Maybe you do, but witnessing the repercussions of bad decisions and truly unforseeable mishaps like tool and material flaws creating instantaneous danger and havoc makes lots of people far more cautious and methodical in their work, and far less likely to succumb to ridicule or pressure from higher ups to cut corners.
>And it also turns out that when you do something for a job, you get tend to get tired and your mind wanders.
Again, speak for yourself...if anything people with lots of experience know better when to take breaks or stop when fatigued, and understand better than anyone how to stay focused and why it's important.
You're just pulling stuff out of your ass to support your personal biases and assuming that correlation equals causation when it comes to experience and industrial accidents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523532
>that larger pool of opportunities might seem to make doing it more probable
yes that is literally how statistics work, if you have a p chance of not cutting your finger off and n number of opportunities to cut your finger off then the probability that in your life you cut your finger off is p^n. This function approaches 0 and for a sufficiently large n always ends with you cutting your finger off. Having a larger number of times where you don't cut a finger off is not going to undo the one time it does happen.

>>2505565
Jack safety is easy with cribbing as you go, I use my forklift jack to raise shipping containers when I add one to my shop (whose foundation is suitably large I-beams) and to put pipe rollers beneath. I also use classic Simplex mechanical jacks, the best being an early 1900s 329 telephone pole jack they still manufacture today. The chain grab is insanely handy:

https://www.ebay.com/itm/155277421886

6x6, 4x4, 2x4 and misc flat steel stacked as I go mean the jack could vanish and I'd be in no danger.

Wood cribbing has excellent traction on steel (the reason for placing a board between forklift forks and milling machine rams when lifting) and doesn't crush. The Air Force stores Mark 84s on wood dunnage in the field.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
This thread went on way too long without mentioning pic related.

Most other tools have one way to fuck you up. The pole saw will fuck you up in many ways.

1) It’s a heavy saw on the end of a long pole, puts you on the end of a really long lever mechanism, so you get up on a ladder and reach for a branch off to the side and lose your balance and take a fall

2) If you remain on the ladder from #1 and get the saw on top of that branch, you cut through it and as soon as you get through the branch, the heavy end of that sharpened chain comes falling down from the tree

3) You cut a big branch at the wrong angle and get the blade wedged in there, now you have a half cut tree limb and a piece of equipment precariously hanging until something gives

4) You aint got time to trim little branches all day, and it’s a chainsaw so you can go through a limb just as thick as the bar on the saw, and you end up dropping 1/4 of a large tree from 15ft above you right onto your dome.

#4 almost got me. I actually cut most of the smaller branches off and then chopped off a log like 6” wide and 3’-4’ long, forgetting how heavy wet wood like that is. The corner of the log clocked me in the forehead.

posts.com:
When that initial covid toilet paper thing happened, I got some Brondell bidet off Amazon. It was about $30 then. It's the bolt on kind, where you take the seat off to install it.
Works pretty well, I like it. Only two settings: spray your ass, and self-clean. That was more important to me than multiple nozzles, multiple water input/temp control, etc.

There's a "splatter shield" in front of the nozzle, and the nozzle only extends when you're using it. Uses the line pressure to extend, when you cut the water a return spring pulls it back up. The self-flush/clean does a good job, it's been low-maintenance.

Didn't use the toilet supply line, I ran off the sink's hot water. So there will be an initial room temp spray, then HOT lol. I did get toilet seat bump stops that are slightly taller (maybe 1/4"?) so I don't stress the seat when I'm sitting on it.

>>2531643
If the city water is turned off (depressurized) then the poop water could be siphoned back into the city water system, leading to contamination. Certain weird cases such as fire hydrant use can also cause negative pressure in the pipes in your home.
You'll find that a lot of the codes, including the electrical and building codes, have to do with addressing edge cases where several unusual fault states are present at the same time.
>>2531683
I'm not that anon, but there are several code sections like Universal Plumbing Code section 603 which talk about back flow preventers. IDK if it's applicable to bidet hoses, but its an oversight if they haven't addressed it specifically in the code. The exact same mechanism of action that could lead to contamination from a pull down sprayer in a commercial sink or a garden hose could be found in these bidet hoses.

2 Professional solutions that are probably not what OP is looking for because they are expensive:
-Get a "tap" for bathing tubes or showers next to your toilet and connect it with a very small shower head (some hundred bucks for the tap, some hundreds for the work and pipes, tiles and shit need to be removed and made new)
-Get a toilet with integrated ass-shower (several thousand bucks)

My /diy/-advice: Get 2 multi-angle-valves where your wash basin is. It is usually near the toilet. The Kinda valves that you put an additional outlet for washing machines. Then do some /diy/ plumbing (you could even use a garden hose) from the 2 valves down and pull them next to your toilet. Then connect them with 2 1/2" "connector panels" (one for warm, one for cold) that you fix on the wall (you can use the tile joint so you don't have to drill into the tiles. Enclose the /diy/ piping with cheap drywall shit and put picture related on the connector panels.

That would be the /diy/ way of making your own ass shower.

If your landlord don't like it you can tear it apart and none of the tiles will be damaged. If the piping leaks you can just turn it off at the angle valves.

Here we discuss microcontrollers, SBCs and microcontroller accessories, such as Atmel mega and tiny AVRs (Arduinos), PICs, ARM boards such as blue/black pill STM32, ESP8266/32s, RP2040, Raspberry Pi, and others.

For general electronics questions (power supplies, level shifting, motor driving, etc.) please ask /ohm/.

>where can I find verified quality microcontrollers and other electronic sensors or parts
digikey.com
mouser.com
arrow.com
newark.com

>but that's too expensive
aliexpress.com (many parts here are fake, particularly specific parts out of stock in the above sites)
lcsc.com

>I need a part that does X and Y, with Z specifications. How can I find it?
use digikey or mouser's parametric part search. Then purchase from one of the sellers listed above.

>how do I get started with microcontrollers, where should I start?
There is no defined starting point, grab a book and start reading or buy an arduino off ebay/amazon and start messing around. There are a plethora of examples online to get started.

>resources:
https://github.com/kitspace/awesome-electronics

>>2535428
No, as far as I can see there aren't any technologies that let you print both a strong insulator and a good conductor at the same time, not to mention be heat-resistant enough to solder on.
But you can use an MSLA resin printer to expose photomasks using UVtools. Bolting a laser to any old CNC machine like a 3D printer and ablating an etch resist also works, so does bolting a router to one to cut copper away directly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523042
>Let's see what happens.
So after 3 days in a warm place it was still very sour, but the acidity definitely got less offensive/sharp. I let it sit for 3 more days but I didn't leave a sample to compare to so couldn't really tell how it's going anymore. But the overall taste turned out rather meh, like there's something missing. With some sugar added I actually liked the original more, even though it almost gives you a chemical burn in the mouth haha.
Treating it with pectic enzyme helped removing most of the haze but it's still not perfectly clear.
In the meanwhile I also made another batch using different (clarified) juice with zero pectin and way less perceived acidity. The recipe was pretty much the same, there was absolutely no foaming, ended up with FG of 1.006 after 5 days. I didn't wait for bubbling to come to a complete stop, but the jar weight pretty much stabilized so there was little point waiting further. With some bentonite it cleared right away, and the taste is oh so much better, specifically there's very little acidity.
Interesting that unless I did something horribly wrong while measuring it, the two batches have TA pretty close at 5.2 and 4.8 g/L respectively, which I believe is pretty tame. pH is around 3.6 in both cases. So I'm pretty confused why do they taste so different.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531384
Not him, my experience says 5 weeks to remove the worst volatile alcohols and make it drinkable, 3 months to really mature it (for almost everything). I drink like half of my stuff at 5 weeks and keep the rest indefinitely (until Christmas or birthday or whatever).

But it’s also (probably more) important to keep it in primary for long enough so that the yeasts will eat most of the less volatile heavy alcohols. Once it stops fermenting, give it 5-7 more days before going to secondary.

Letting it ferment dry helps a lot with clearing (low gravity drops the solids more easily) and you can backsweeten it after. Filtering is kind of difficult using a home set up (without sterile pumps and plate filters etc) and almost never really necessary imo

Best is to visit your supermarket or green grocer and check the "Old fruits and veggies for half price" section, because you really want soft bananas with black skin. If you don't have enough, put the black ones into the freezer and start collecting and ripening bananas over a couple of months.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531375
You should get the fruit out after 1 to 1.5 weeks, raspberries can start to decay under absence of oxygen which creates sulfuric compounds which in turn spoils your wine. Just strain it while racking it into a second fermenter. Press the pulp, because the largest amount of your yeast will sit in there and you don't want to lose them. After that, you can only wait until fermentation is done.
Testing for sweetness while fermentation is still going will result in you throwing out your entire batch, because it will only taste of yeast and sourness. (Which is completely normal but might give the wrong impression to someone new to this hobby)
Let it ferment completely dry, until no airlock activity is visible, rack it and let it sit for 2 weeks to let it clear. Then you'll get the first impression of where the flavor of your wine is heading.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531406
EC1118 should go to 18% but don't be fooled by the SG of 1.020, honey has some unfermentable sugars, it's really rare to get honey to ferment completely dry, even though you should end up around 1.008 at least. Are you really sure that fermentation is completely done?
Normally you should measure the SG, take note and measure again one week later to see if the gravity dropped further.

Also you have your terminology wrong.
OG (Original Gravity) is your starting point. FG (Final Gravity) is the value you end your fermentation with and with which you bottle your wine. SG (Specific Gravity) is just the "unit" of the gravity.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2533531
>tastes like crap
Blueberry and cherry is a really difficult combo, I can't really imagine those two working together properly.

I think most people don't really understand that fermentation fundamentally changes the taste of what you put into your fermentation vessel. Cherry wine will never taste like cherry juice and the wine will always taste shallower, that's in the nature of it and the exact reason why so many combine it with mead to give it a proper background or foundation.
Also, I can't stress it enough, buy yourself an acidity testing kit. I bet my arse that your acidity is nowhere near where it should be to allow the flavors to come to shine. For a simple fruit wine without any fancy extras I'd at least go for a 7.5g/l.
And in the end it will help to just let it rest for at least 2 months, it will taste like a whole different drink. But with your combo that's not as easy as it looks. Blueberry wines love aging, after a year they will develop a lovely complexity but you can't do that with cherries. Cherry wine will finish developing after 1-2 months and it won't get better than what you have at that time. After a year the flavor and aroma will start to decay and the cherry wine will slowly start to taste bland and hollow.

https://www.thehomebrewforum.co.uk/threads/how-to-make-turbo-cider.69059/

Turbo cider is very quick and simple. Bear in mind you CAN make it taste nice, but like any cider within the first 6 months it's likely to be pretty shit

tl;dr:
>get apple juice (ideally pressed apple juice but you can use juice from concentrate too)
>get yeast (in theory anything but in practice best to get a cider yeast or some kind of champagne/beer yeast)
>make a strong cup of black tea (to replace the tannin you'd get from the apple skins in normal cider)
>put them all in demijohn with airlock
>some guys put in more sugar (to increase alcohol %) or yeast nutrient but I've never done either
>just leave it for like 2-3 weeks, it should start bubbling due to fermentation
>that's basically it

Think of it like dogs. Greyhounds are bred to be fast. Mastiffs to be strong. Shepherds to be protective. You can be assured of these things with these breeds.

This anon is right >>2536774

Every brew will be flat after fermentation finishes, so as long as you don't want a non-carbonated brew, you need to add sugar before bottling.
>Light carbonation: 6g sugar per liter of brew
>Normal carbonation: 8g sugar per liter of brew

As to the rest of the equipment, that's basically everything you'll need, except for a vessel to rack into. But you can use a bucket as well, as long as you add the sugar and immediately bottle your brew.
Proper sanitation is a given at this point.

>>2530735
It's still garbage. The ring pull tab isn't ancient, it was invented in the 1950s. It was discarded because drunks could swallow the tabs and they could cause cuts when sat or stepped on.

Prior cans used "can openers".

A can in collectible condition will be straight, externally undamaged with at most minor scratches or fading. Best are those left so long they dried out without the tab being pulled.

BRO, I have some bad news...
I just saw this exact same can on Antiques Roadshow, all cleaned and perfectly restored.
The appraiser was visibly upset, turns out that collectors value originality and patina over looks and what would have gone for upwards of $500K at auction if just left alone was now worth less than a typical soda can's five cent recycling value.

Also, the reason that can't pull tab was placed inside the can is because it wasn't the vastly superior tab design with the notches that let you twist off the sealing flap portion and stick it in a notch and use it as a spring to launch the pull ring part like a Frisbee into your friend's eye.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I own about a dozen ryobi tools, the 18v line
Leaf blower is underpowered, only works well on loose completely dry leaves
Hedge trimmer works well but snags and seizes on 1/2" twigs (not that its built for those)
Branch saw is ok but telescoping parts are awkward. Can't cut much more than 1.5" thick
Chainsaw is ok for chopping up 1-4yr saplings and anything under 4" thickness. Anything bigger and you need two batteries and cut it from every side. Chain loosens too easily
Air pump is shitty and the attachment holder clips for it are bad design
Weed wacker is fine for small yards and normal edging, completely fails at real weed growth and anything wet/thick. I need two large batteries to do my lawn. The feed mechanism is CANCER. It auto feeds every time you pull trigger, so if you want to spot trim areas, you can't just release and pull, you have to just keep it pressed or else you'll be constantly feeding line out
Brad nailer is fine
Drill and impact drill are fine
Dremel is good not great, a little underpowered. Used it for polishing feed ramps on some guns
Batteries are overpriced as fuck. Chink shit from amazon 1/4 the price and work good enough.
I have two sanders i havent used yet but i presume same case of "good enough" for small jobs but not for big ones.

look up basic stick framing. buy 1000$ worth of 8' 2x4's. Build tiny cabin, super easy, side with 3/4 inch plywood. Wrap in tyvek house wrap. add used door and add a window or two. Its super easy. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535503
>functional parts
As with LITERALLY EVERY FUNCTIONAL THING, this depends entirely on the function in question.

>if they could be left outside for some time?
ASA is very weather resistant but prone to warping. PETG is decently weather resistant but easier to print.

>some mechanical requirements
Neither ASA nor PETG are suited for use as a tire, which has different mechanical requirements than, say, a planter. If you have specific mechanical requirements in mind, you can check for materials which have useful properties.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535503
I find ABS-PC pretty stable in exterior (PETG, not so much) and with very good mecanical properties.
you also have POM, PA12, PA11 and glass/carbon fiber mixed materials. all of those are hard to print and require an enclosed printer with an all metal extruder.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2535553
There is no "set your nozzle to this specific height and it works" unless the person telling you has the exact same machine, build plate material, print material, and a lot of other settings. The paper trick is just to get you in the ballpark without going so low that you crash the nozzle into the plate. After that do a test print, adjust as needed, test again, adjust again, until you get the results you desire.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535548
If you've never done so, then you need to CLEAN the build plate using at least isopropyl alcohol, or preferably acetone and a kitchen scrubby pad.
When I first cleaned mine, a lot of weird oily yellow residue came off of what appeared to me to be a 'clean' plate.
Follow this up by washing it well with soap and warm water and then don't touch it with your oily fingers again before printing.

Level it one good time after its back in place (again, avoid putting finger spots on it) and you will probably get really good adhesion. It worked for me

plan to airbrush on extremely thin coats of paint and clear coat a top layer, but some thing that are kind of meant to look statue like, would probably just leave it unpainted, I think if its matte or clear seeing a smooth reflection would hide almost any hint it was 3d printed while adding some modicum of structural rigidity to it and hopefully some amount of layer peeling protection.

my main fear is if I don't do this and the paint likes to stick to the layer lines the paint will make them stand out far FAR more than they should, think of painting rust onto minis buy heavily diluting the colors and letting it settle in corners, but instead of it doing that, it wicks into every layer line.

the problem with paint primer though is I don't want a thick enough layer of that that it would cover details, I should preface this with I have never used a primer with an airbrush, so I don't know if it can get really thin or not, but everything I have used tends to be significantly thicker than the paint.

how does it work? I mean is it just enough to get in ridges wo is it something that minor details may get lost once used?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536001
>how does it work?
magnets. my guess is it's extra thick and self leveling in a non-level sense. if you prime, even if you prime heavily the paint goes on evenly and your ridges are preserved. If you use something like nail polish or some /wip/ paints they will try to settle with a smooth surface. This is designed to do the latter, it settles smoothly filling in the valleys instead of preserving the ridges. You are going to lose minor negative details, especially if they're even. If they're positive they shouldn't be that affected (corners in a name plate for example). In that sense better than acetone smoothing actually. But also I'm guessing that being able to dig out those details whether when wet, semi dry or dry would be possible.

In something like picrel it should pool on the faces effectively chamfering the lower edge but bubbling on top to give an enamel type profile.

>>2536001

whichever dickhead it was earlier that bitched at me about a primer being "patently false" for the job of smoothing something out obviously never heard of a smoothing primer and needs to be on idiot mitigation meds before mouthing off.

I have never used the stuff "specifically designed to smooth 3d print layers" but I would double check that it isn't the same exact compounds as an existing smoothing primer marketed to basement dwelling funko pop pirates for triple the cost.

In either case, you WILL need to be careful during application as to not lose details. A substance designed to smooth something doesn't have nano-machines in it to determine which details you want and which details to smooth. It just smooths based on the number of coats you apply.

I've never used a spray smoothing primer before (like out of a spray can) but i suspect they exist. If they do then it would be ideal since you can get really thin coats and work your way up, or just target certain areas.

Alternatively, just use a filament that can be smoothed with solvents. Polymaker has one.

posts.name: Icarus
posts.com:
>>2536060
>I've never used a spray smoothing primer before (like out of a spray can) but i suspect they exist. If they do then it would be ideal since you can get really thin coats and work your way up, or just target certain areas.

It exists and it's fucking rad.
You can indeed work in thin layers, or target where you need filler and sand down any excess. You can tape off parts you don't want sprayed or do something low-effort like hold a piece of cardboard over the spots you don't want to spray and clean up any ragged edges later.

I've found that I usually don't even need to sand after using this shit. It fills layer lines in pretty nicely and lays down primer at the same time. Sanding seems useful for when layer lines or other features are big enough to show through 3 passes.

posts.com:
>>2536211
I have a drop in amhe (just replaces the hot end tube itself) and the direct drive conversion that uses all stock parts. mine once in a blue moon will jam with petg but quite often with pla (this is expected and warned with most amhe's) so I don't bother with it anymore. never had a problem with the small amount of nylon I've done (with dd only). tpu was a god damn nightmare even with dd, gave up on it and hucked the spool because fuck that shit. so yeah a Bowden would probably give you issues. luckily the dd conversions are like 30 bucks on scamazon and imo the weight and speed tradeoff is SO worth it because 1) the bed will always be heavier and 2) being able to do 5x faster and 3x shorter retractions saves SO MUCH FUCKING TIME it's unreal. also you don't need an all metal for petg, just Capricorn tube and run 240c gtg. also if you want to run warpy filaments I'd look into a reverse flow heat break fan shroud that sucks air past it instead of blowing into it causing much less of a draft across the part. the one in particular I use you can find on thingyverse, easy to print and works great.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536345
The regular springs work fine, but after I installed Klipper and started to squeeze more and more performance out of it, the high accelerations on Y would compress the springs and caused the bed to rock on direction changes. Yellow springs are too stiff to allow this and they dramatically improved input shaper results. Now I run 5k accelerations on my Ender.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536424
Forgive me, I didnt understand what you wanted at first.
I dont think you can do what you want with the pulley. There is no way to fit an 8mm ID ball bearing in those types of pulleys. Youd need a larger pulley, which would change your teeth count or belt size, and wont match the rest of the mechanism in your assembly.

See pic attached. The smaller bearing I could find in McMaster is an 8 by 12. Even if you could perfectly bore your GT2 pulley to 12mm, youd be left with 0.365mm of material between your bearing and the pitch of the pulley. Itll break.

The only way to go slimmer is to use an 8 by 10 sleeve bearing, which is basically what you want to replace.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536629
The diodes built-in to the MOSFETs would just shunt the induced voltage to the rails, where it would get damped out by the filter caps. The voltage it charges up to is going to be a volt or two at maximum, since it's not enough to feed through the voltage regulator into the logic circuitry and turn it on. In other words, not a problem unless you REALLY crank on the motor, in which case it just turns on for a split second. I'd trust the brownout detection on the ICs involved.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536725
It's all relative, .98 is just 98% of what your extruder wants to naturally work at. I usually only bump it up or down 1-2% during a print, but that's after printing some calibration rectangles to see where that filament prints best (it depends on the actual width of your "1.75mm" filament, and the thermal expansion of that type of plastic), for example I run ABS around .93, PLA at 1, TPU at 1.01, and CF-Nylon at something ridiculous like .78 IIRC.

Purity, consistency, water content, storage conditions, quality control, quality of additives, age, etc. You might get lucky, but you might not. I've used Siraya Tech Tenacious, which is fairly flexible. However, it's not very rubbery like TPU, but more like TPU crossed with oobleck. In terms of hardness, it's like a very hard rubber, nominally 65 Shore D.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536845
Cubic and other infill patterns with continuous internal planes produce a stiff infill that can help make a part stiff, but which does not flex without buckling. Gyroid does not have continuous planes, and instead flexes about evenly in every direction. This makes the part more flexible overall, and can help reduce internal stresses that may cause problems like a part peeling. Gyroid has relatively small gaps for a given percentage infill, which influences how many top layers you need to look good (not as good as line but better than cubic). Gyroid also has a single interconnected internal void, so it's preferred for things that get filled with liquids.

I usually use grid for small/stiff structural parts and gyroid for things that need flexibility, or which have weird thin areas of infill that I want to have relatively consistent reinforcement.

nylon does that. it contracts as it cools and it really wants to rip itself off the bed. the bottom ones stay warm, but as you put more layers on top, they get cooler and cooler and contract more, and eventually they pull hard enough to lift the bottom off the bed. you might need it to be hotter inside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536981
>stronger material etc
PLA is the strongest common printing material. Polycarbonate is about on par with PLA, with specific brands and printing parameters having overlap. You don't get into things clearly stronger than PLA with merely "engineering" grade plastics, you need "superpolymers" like PEI or PEEK. "Higher end" plastic may be more expensive and more difficult to print, but they're not all-around upgrades mechanically. They have various properties which are better suited to some tasks rather than others, and making proper use of them involves knowing what those properties are and how to optimize strengths and minimize weaknesses for a particular use case.

For example, TPU is tough, flexible, grippy, and abrasion resistant, but it's very weak by the standards of printing materials. Nylon is impact resistant and springy, but it's prone to creep deformation under sustained loads, and it's weaker than PLA and some other common plastics. Polycarbonate is more or less an all-around mechanical upgrade over common plastics, but it is vulnerable to some chemical and environmental effects that some more common plastics are not.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2531818
I'd say your thought is on the right track, but this ain't it chief.
Gravity forcing the heavier cold air rushing out and get replaced with room-temp air that then needs to be cooled when opening and closing a side-operated door, and the seal having to fight the same cold air even when closed, should in theory make normal side-operated fridges much less energy efficient than top-operated ones, especially with frequent use. This assuming everything else about the two units being equal, indeed we see this in freezers where top-operated 'chest' freezers are common and consistently more energy efficient than their side-operated counterparts.

But things aren't always equal, and electric coolers have problems. First the simple inconvenience factor from having to stack things on top of each other instead of putting them on a shelf. Then theres that coolers have very very varying build quality, even more so than mini fridges which are already a mixed bag compared to standard fridges, chances of getting one with shit insulation is high. Coolers also generally have weaker compressors cause they're made for portability (and some have peltiers which are even worse), so on a hot day (or just a normal day if you live somewhere fairly warm) you might not be able to get down to fridge temps.
If you want anything half-decent, you're going to be spending at least $300 for a 45L/48 quarts cooler, maybe $400, and best case scenario the energy savings will make it break-even in 10 years, provided it doesn't shit itself at the 5 year mark.

You're probably better off spraypainting your existing fridge grey and not opening it as often.

>Also, feel free to use this thread as a general discussion about lessening your energy bill. Do have any advice about energy saving practices?
Insulate your house, this is the most important one passive improvements would always be better than active ones, if you are renting and you are in a shit situation, food plastic wrap can be used to make a shitty but working 2 chamber in your windows, it would look bad, but it works.

If you don't have humidity problems, every time you take a shower, bath, clean your hands with hot water, close the drain until the water has gotten cold. That hot water would be wasted down the drain, in this way you get back the warm to your apartment.

>>2531552
The selling point of Evolution is that their products are designed for multi-material cutting. This also means that they're not particularly good at anything. So if you want to make precise cuts in wood for furniture, it's not especially great. It works as long as you don't use the slides, the slides in mine are not aligned with the blade with about 1 degree error, and this is impossible to adjust without machining as far as I can tell. The slower blade speed for metal cutting is also not a good thing for wood.
The steel cutting works, but will eat up the blade and the results aren't as good as a dedicated steel cold cutting saw would give, Though that also eats up the blade.
The TL;DR is that you get what you pay for, it's better than ultra-cheapo garbage brands, but it's not a replacement for a $1000 pro miter saw and dedicated metal cutting saws. If fine woodwork is your priority and want to use the slide, I'd probably go for something else.

>>2531577
ICF is much quicker to put up. ICF is completely airtight which is obviously a boost for saving energy. You also get some amazing sound insulaiton

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2524059
I built my house using full ICF (footings to trusses). Overall very happy with it but there's a number of things to consider.

You need to plan every single wall penetration in advance, not that you can't drill after the fact, but it gets expensive quick, especially if you hit rebar. Just putting a piece of conduit or pipe through the styrofoam beforehand works much better.

For really large openings like double garage doors, oversized windows, patio doors with side light windows, etc. there's a bunch of extra engineering to ensure the lintel is strong enough.

The efficiency has been really great, especially since we also insulated to R60 in our attic, you'll notice the house will be really quiet for things like storms, traffic & noise pollution.

For moisture control, I would recommend using a membrane tape made by 3m (similar to bluskin) and going over every foam block joint or open foam-concrete transition on the exterior. It's not strictly necessary, but the peace of mind combined with my coastal climate was well worth it for me.

Running any electrical on exterior walls is kind of a pain, but not a huge deal, I used a small pruning chainsaw with a clamped on stopper to cut a channel in the foam for any of my cable runs which worked well, also it's a different type of electrical box.

I'd recommend making sure all of your doors & windows are also high efficiency to get the biggest benefit.

Blender is not capable of creating a live environment. Let's just establish that.

Unity is probably your best bet, or Unreal engine. They're designed to take input in a real time environment. But you have a steep slope ahead to get what you want.

There are simplistic platforms to get into for virtualized robots, like CoderZ, which is for teaching schoolkids how to learn robotics in a virtual environment, or the Virtual VEX Robot platform. Virtualized robotics are an active field of research and development.

I don't think you know exactly how much work is ahead of you, building it all from scratch. I would dive into the simpler forms of it like CoderZ and get a feel for how they build their platform, and then scale off that.

Anything beyond CoderZ and the like is going to be expensive and proprietry, because you could literally base an advanced degree on designing an environment you're describing, and could sell the results on the open market for quite a bit of money.

So the bottom line is, how much experience in coding do you have? If the answer is none, or a little - focus on that, there's no point going further.

What you are describing is a CAM simulation. They can be as small as a single tool in material, to a production cell or above. The only real limit is hardware for simulation, and is it really feasible to simulatate to that detail. Mastercam is one, and FANAC makes another for their robot systems and cells.

They get very expensive, very quickly. The reason you only find very specific limited packages is that the amount of information you need to do a simulation can be eye wateringly specific.

As the anons said before, unity or unreal is where you are gonna wanna look, sonce they have the structures to get close the simulations you need, though the accuracy of calcs is gonna bite you in the ass if you are dependent on it. Take a look at the unreal assey marketplace on the epic store, and start saving every free file you can get your mits on, since they cycle what is free every few weeks. Some is optimized for simulation work that you can use for a starting point. Not sure on unity though.

Honestly, the more you learn, the more you will find there's a reason this is not mainstream yet, due to the web of computing power available in genric industrial environments, the web on IP bullshit (thanks Disney), and the simple fact of does simulation of more than just the tool paths make sense?

I quite like bum spots for bmx trail/mtb riding. And I really like building/maintaining them.
One time we built a spot on city land, a little spit of land where the river was redirected by a dike. Very sandy soil, and we used "geotextile" to make it work. I didn't pay for it, a friend who worked at a concrete/landscaping place hooked me up with the remainder of a roll. It was kinda similar to "blue tarp" material, similr woven pattern, but this was black & narrow.

I think this guy has an annoying voice, but the visuals here get the point across
Practical Engineering - Sand Castle Holds Up A Car! - Mechanically Stabilized Earth
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0olpSN6_TCc

>>2532351
Looking at your sketch, you could probably get reasonable results using some kind of fabric with that technique.

You can also mix in "some concrete" as a stabilizer. Like a 10:1 soil:concrete ratio. It kind of acts like glue for the soil, and it's quite hard once you tamp it & it sets. That was useful for smaller features, and stuff that wore down fast. Doesn't feel good to land on, it's like the hardest packed dirt.
You don't have to mix it well (like with a wheelbarrow or something), cutting the cement powder in with a rock rake is good enough. Where I am, the natural moisture in the soil made it set.

>>2536304
Yeah, dirt jumps.
You tamp the sand/soil/fill during construction, to minimize future settling. The tool looks like a shovel handle with a square steel plate at the bottom. It's not pleasant to use. In the same way that digging by hand is a shit load of work, tamping is the same.

I'm in the midwest, and the soil I'm talking about is river sand. I'm sure there's a real name for it, but I'm not expert. It's pretty dark, and it will almost keep its shape if you smash it in your hand. Not at all like sand at the ocean or up at the lakes. Maybe your sand is different, I don't know.

We used pre-mixed cement from Menard's. Partly because it was in 60lb bags, which was easier to haul in. We used "just dirt" & that fabric for the insides, and the dirt/concrete mix for the "shell" of the ramps & berms. It's all held up pretty well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532679
Short answer, yes. Long answer, welder is your best bet for international shit, specifically multi process multi metal pipe welding.

For stick welding this means uphill and downhill capable with cellulose electrodes, 7016 roots (dcep and dcen), 7018 dcen roots, 7018 hot fill cap, 8045 hot fill cap, and dual shield welding hot fill cap

For tig you need to capable of welding multiple metals and skilled with dealing with argon purging and flux coated tig filler for non purged scenarios

For mig you need to be capable of running downhill roots, uphill hot fill cap with short circuit, pulse mig, pulse metal core, and dual shield, you may even need uphill mig roots though in my experience I've never seen it.

All that shit is just basics too, there is of course alloy stick and mig welding, branch welds, 6GR and a bunch of other shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532679
It depends. Pretty much all countries will require that you get a work permit and a visa. Securing those might be hard if there is no shortage of labor. Then, you will need to be in touch with a local company that works in this industry because you cannot just go abroad and work as an individual without being registered as a company. Once this is established, you will still have to negotiate payment methods as it might be a lot more complicated for the company to pay you directly because of tax regulations than to have your company invoice them for the work.

All in all, unless you are super specialized, it's hard to find work at the international level. There are programs for road shows and international tours, with easier procedures, but for trades this is often not the case.

The best way to work abroad is to get super specialized and instead offer consultancy and training. The specialization means that getting work permit will be a lot easier.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536900
Just to elaborate a bit more, factory work is a lot less regulated than construction trades when it comes to licenses and having your certification recognized, but unless there is a labor shortage, it's still hard to get hired. It will be a lot easier if you can get hired by a company that operates in your home country, and get them to fly you to one of their factories abroad, but then again you still need to get a visa. Thing is when the factory does that, they can often just get a dozen (or some amount) of visas from the government and you would only need to pass basic screening to be eligible (mostly having no past convictions and no ties to terror groups and other undesirables).

>>2531891
A planer has the cutterhead on top for reducing the thickness of a board. A jointer has the cutterhead on the bottom to establish a flat and true surface. The thing about jointers/planers/tablesaws is that the length of board they can precisely cut is dependant on the length of the infeed table. These benchtop models have short infeed tables so I would face a board longer than a few feet on one.

Personally I'm just going to invest in a series of handplanes and figure them out.

It's a simple process to square and flatten a board.
1. Joint a side
2. Joint a face
3. plane opposite face
4.Use table saw to square last side.

I pretty much soak small items in a sink of hot water and washing powder, stiring or 'agitating' occasionally. Squeeze out and rinse with cold water one or two times. It's not perfect but low enough effort with only a sink, draining board and kettle to use.
Drying I just squeeze out water then line everthing up on a wooden rack, placed infront of a radiator in a 'wet' room.

Heavily soiled items are soaked in hot water and washing powder, then run through a washing machine as usual.

Most of the time I avoid handwashing larger items like towels, trousers and heavy tops as they're much harder to squeeze and take days to dry. I've even tried twisting them 'roung a tree - it works, but not well enough.

This winter has been pretty bad for washing, to be honest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Dye and scent free detergent
>wash all darks
>wash all lights
>shirts in dryer for 10m warm
>pants in dryer for 10m warm
>hang shirts damp
>hang pants damp
>all the way dry stuff in dryer hot 120m (underwear socks towels)
>walk away

Hanging prevents shrinkage, batch hanging skirts and pants separate allows for consistent work flow. Separating before drying prevents mistakes and is easier outside the dryer. There is a slight time loss if you have light shirts before the first dryer cycle, but it's small compared to the effort saved by isolating tasks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527235
Lots of kids end up in humanities literally just because math and science are so poorly taught in high school. By the time they are in high school, most kids dislike math and science because they think they're too hard. They aren't hard, they've just been failed in one or more topics. Failing is a normal part of learning any subject, but schools don't give kids time to go back and retry things they didn't master the first time. So kids just accept that they "don't know" x subject and have to leave it at that because it's time to move on. Teachers have curriculum goals that they have to meet so that when standardized testing rolls around, enough kids can give enough right answers to keep the school funded.

Subjects like language arts and history are a lot harder to fail, because there's less to get wrong, so kids end up thinking these subjects are the only things they are "good" at. These subjects are often tested with essays read by human proctors, which are way more forgiving than multiple choice math and science.

When it comes time to graduate high school, theres enormous pressure on kids to go to college and pick a major. They, logically, want to pick a major they are likely to succeed at, so using their limited window into education and job training, they arrive at the conclusion that they have to take humanities.

In an ideal world, kids would learn hard subjects at their own pace, and take as much time to master subjects as they need. For many reasons this is extremely impractical for a system that needs to educate thousands of kids per county, but that's the result you get: kids who just think STEM isnt for them.

Some advice from me:
1. You need to become a man and seperate yourself from your mother
2. Which means you need to get a job and move out from your mother to become independant

If you want to get into building houses become mason, go into "civil engineering" as construction worker, become a roofer. Just some examples

example red connectors are supposed to crimp 22-16awg but they are actually sized for 14awg or larger, good connectors will not accept a wire that is larger than they are rated for. same with blue rated for 16-14awg and they will take 12awg or larger wire.

when measuring, dont measure on the hole, since the burr from punching skews the result,
The outer and inner ring diameter are different, the chink ring is hair thin

The thing is, the brand one is made to spec, to handle the current of a fitting size wire.
The chink one is at least 30% less meat, so using them at the max size conductor is overloading the connection

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not sure where you are/what your climate is. In northern NA vapour barrier goes on any exterior wall/ceiling in order to prevent water vapour from condensing inside the insulation batts. That's why it goes on the warm side of the insulation. People saying "how is water going to get out" are fucking retards, if water is getting into your insulation it's because it's condensing there. Unless something's leaking, in which case you're fucked long before the poly will exacerbate the problem.

Poly isn't required on interior walls because there's no cold side to cause moisture to condense. Just make sure the ceiling is taped properly at interior wall junctions, acoustic sealant is another very messy but effective option

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Also, add substantial vertical framing at the outside of the tub on both ends. If you put a shower door in now or later, you will appreciate have actual wood to fasten to instead of hanging a 40 lb sheet of glass off of 2 drywall anchors

Again u don't need a vapor barrier

>Inspect walls for finished product. Do you need any shelf knockouts, places to mount sliding doors /etc, put studs in to reinforce. Put a light in the shower stall and a fan.
>Install tub, then cover to prevent damage. Make sure you have sure footing.
>Put up a cement fiber board up using self tapping screws.
>Fiber tape together using thinset as mud compound. Have the fiber board come half a width out of the tub stall so you can add more tile than you will ever think you need.
> If you are doing floors, raise the toliet flange to match the height of the finished floor.
>Put down some type of fiber barrier on the floor to prevent tile cracking.
> do a dry layout of tile, number the grid and mark tiles that need to be cut. Start tile out less than half a tile width from the tub. This will let you rip tiles in half and use a single tile for two colums. Leave the whole tile on the most exposed wall. Finish the tile so that it sits under the door when closed. Leave <1/4" between sheetrock edges and tiles, fill this with caulk.
>if you have large format tile use levelers. Big tiles go up fast.
>Put the floor board/bullnose down and join it with the tub.
>Lay the first set of tiles on the tub wall, rip these to height so that about 1/4 a tile is above the tub. Measure out heights of other things so that you can minimize cuts. Leave 3/16" gap at the edges between shower wall tiles. Recess the largest wall tile with other smaller walls Infront.
> Grout the tile. 1 bags of grout covers a shitton of tile, use a grout sealer it inhibits mold growth. Don't fuck with caulk in edges that shit molds so fast. Just grout everything.
>After tile is done, paint then install fixtures/vanity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536185
Vapor barrier goes outside the framed exterior walls on both sides to prevent building decay

If it's an exterior wall, moisture barrier goes inside studs and outside the sheathing
This prevents the framing and insulation from molding/rotting.
If it's on the outside only, the wall rots during the winter, if it's only on the inside, the wall rots during the summer
It's not to prevent moisture from the bathroom from going into the wall, it's to control where condensation forms
Your rub surround should be caulked to prevent leaking as should your floor to the trim and around your vanity

>>2536185
>What kind of vapor barrier should I install behind the tub surround?
I'd drywall up and use paintable liquid protection seal for bathing areas on the wall. Picture related. That's all you need - if your room has no windows a ventilator is mandatory anyways.
>should I lay plastic down first or coat the plywood in something like redguard?
Both works. How high can you go up starting from the plywood? Best solution is always: Basic structure (concrete or OSB on beams), EPS/Tempex and then screed/special concrete floor fill. But that will need alot of space.

Easy solution for your problem would be a thin isolation that is used for underfloor heating systems right ontop of the wood. Don't forget to put it up the walls as well (cut it off after your concrete floor fill is done) so your floor doesn't have direct contact with the wall or you can hear the every steep in the entire house.

I do this professionally, and can walk you through it with some additional info. What are the specific alloys of the drum and ports? Is this for a sanitary application? How thick is the drum wall (I'm assuming you have thin wall ferrules)? What temperature and chemical exposure will this need to handle? What size ports are you putting in, and are there any constraints on location (e.g. some need to be close to each other or to one end of the barrel)? Will the ports need to bear any load?
