posts.name: Turbro
posts.com:
>>2531856
I've only done stick and TIG for stainless, but I imagine flux-core would be best. In theory, it should be no better than stick, since there's slag and you can't control the rate of deposition, but that's not the case.


>>2531867
Thin stainless is tedious to weld. If you use stick, you're basically putting down a tiny bit of metal right where the center of the arc is. The surface of the puddle is just slag, so you can't rely on it to tell if your welds are dimes or dogshit.

>>2531861
TIG requires a lot of prep to get clean welds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533156
>the drum is 304 stainless steel, no idea about the ports yet.
From the heat and chemical situation (just avoid cleaning stuff with chlorides), 304 fittings and 308 filler should be appropriate. 1/16" filler would probably be easiest to use.

>just boiling water
Which means you won't have to grind the interior. The back side of welds should still be purged with argon or protected by flux, though.

>don't know what a wall ferrule is
Triclamp ferrules come in two general forms for applications like this: thin and heavy walls. Thin wall ferrules are for low-pressure applications that just need to seal, and small ones are just over 1/16" thick. They're easy to weld in a single pass with full penetration on a comparatively thick shell/whatever. Heavy wall ferrules are for pressure vessels, and have significantly thicker walls. They're typically welded in multiple passes on much thicker material.

Regarding fittings, one option is to use triclamp caps with various attachments welded on. I make these sorts of things custom at work as needed, but it would probably be more economical for you to buy something premade unless you have a decent metal workshop. Compared with threaded fittings, they would be more expensive, but access and sealing would be easier. The general connection sizes you mention mean that distortion should not be much of a concern.

>wiring, hoses etc no.
Then the most practical fitup would be to cut a hole the size of the fitting, cope the fitting to match the curvature of the drum, and do a full penetration weld from the outside.

>>2533200
If you want the steam to move somewhere, there has to be pressure to drive that movement. And 22KW of heating can spike the pressure quickly if steam flow is constrained. With a proper setup, it shouldn't be a problem, but drums like in the OP aren't made to contain significant pressure.

posts.sub: Does anyone use long range Wi-Fi? Why is download so slow but upload fast?
posts.com:
The first three paragraphs are information, the 4th is the question.

I have a wifi antenna reaching about 1/3 mile in an urban setting. I am connected to university wifi while off-campus, because I have a line-of-sight to the highest power wifi transmitter they own. A weak gigabit-speed signal outpaces closer free-wifi options and I have the benefits of not needing to verify my identity and access library materials using school wifi.

Only an area the volume of a baseball gets the signal I can't find it anywhere else as reliable... Someone had suggested local weather conditions (fog, wind, temperature) may affect connection dynamics but really the biggest thing is finding the signal's g spot, and fixing it there...

I have a signal between 29%-42% and the weather's entirely different now than last night. I use a simple aluminum foil reflector/shield and my window's aluminum blinds are pulled up. I notice I frequently switch between two wi-fi channels when connected to the tower thus the difference in speeds. One has download speeds of 0.1mbps to about 7.0, and the other one does between 5 and 18mbps... Both have upload speeds in the 30s so the downloading is the problem.

THE QUESTION: Assuming a fixed antenna, proper polarity, 1,676 feet distance (+/- 10 feet) line-of-sight signal to Wi-Fi channels 54 and 140, that can maintain a 13-65mbps connections (represented as 29-42% signal), what do you believe may be causing me to have such low download speeds, when the upload ones do just fine? Can I fix the download link to be as fast as the upload? My background is in FM/TV/CB radios so it loosely translates to Wi-Fi.

P.S. The university antenna I am connected to is practically empty of users because of winter break. And, I have established connection at 2/3 mile with line-of-sight, and detected signal from 3 miles with line-of-sight. I have thought about those factors

posts.com:
>>2534166

Your antenna is shittier than theirs, simply. You are able to receive packets transmitted to you, but with a significantly higher error rate than the other way around. This necessitates more retransmissions of lost packets, resulting in a lower overall speed. If you have LoS, using a parabolic antenna significantly better speeds in both directions.

Technically, it could also be a result of a symmetrical connection where most users are downloading, not uploading. Given the relatively small proportion of the school's total bandwidth that you're actually using, however, I seriously doubt that would result in such a large discrepancy for you.


>>2534349
>wireless ethernet.

"Ethernet", by definition, uses a wired (either copper or fiber optic) connection.

>connections that despite being wireless have the same low latency

Low-latency wireless data links do not magically become "wireless ethernet" simply for having low latency. You could, technically, spit out an ethernet signal between a pair of transceivers, but this is a horrible idea for numerous reasons and nobody does this because it's retarded.

POE powered dishes generally have less losses over the various cable runs and adapters and are weather-tight. You will want to mount any dish outside and high to avoid interference.

https://a.co/d/6ESvfUL

If you can connect using this I bet you won't have any performance problems. The 100Mbps connection will be more than enough.

If you insist on using RP-SMA those dishes are generally cheap and easy to find.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534561
Good to see you got some improvement. I am going to guess your antennae are not covering the whole spread of channels - you got a high Q, narrow bandwidth response that happens to coincide with the uplink channels.

Multipathing can also be a problem where you have reflections and nulls causing dropped packets and a high re-transmission rate.

Urban environments are hell on GHz signals, hence highly directional antennae with wider bandwidths and medium gain may give better results.

You may be better off with a repeater mounted externally in an optimal position. A number of WDS devices that can be configured to do this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534738
>>2534739

Glass, especially dual pane and UV coated, can have up to a 10dB drop in signal in both directions. If you insist on mounting it indoors you need to find a way to adjust the distance to the glass and test your antenna at varying distances to the pane. I had similar issues when I put radios indoors in highrise buildings and spents hours tweaking the aiming to get an acceptible signal.
Ubiquiti will work with other vendor hardware you need to turn the "Airmax" options off and select the specific frequencies they are using. Using a flat cable to go above or below a pane of glass on a double-hung window and sticking to the glass on the outside using suction cups or double sided tape always gave us the best SNR.

> they're either corroded
I had forgotten about the almost magical ability of Torx, Allen and other non- phillips/slotted drives to prevent corrosion in metal, and how much easier they are to clean out to a useable condition when painted over or filled with dirt, road grime and other debris, glue/mortar/stucco, etc. Super tight tolerances and tiny inside corners that lock that shit in are just the ticket when you want ease of removal, and Iike you said, only Phillips and slotted screws corrode so you don't have to clean that shit out just to get a driver into the female portion of other drive schemes. What was I thinking?
> or made of the weakest shit ever and it was a miracle that the screw made its way into the hole in the first place
Again, how silly of me to ignore the fact that as the relative shear resistance of metal decreases due to the type selected or deterioration in the field, the better it is to have a close tolerance drive mechanism that locks in and applies maximum torque and keeps it as centered as possible rather than spread across the head of the fastener so it gains leverage that can be finessed to gently break the fastener loose rather than instantly snapping the head off, or snapping the driver bit in two if the fastener is strong, or smoothing the corners/splines off of the bit or the hole like an end mill....or possibly all of the above. GREAT point.

Finally, who hasn't had a screw head deteriorate or be so full of garbage or just be too soft a metal to where it doesn't function for removal, and then used a file or Dremel or hacksaw blade to cut a superior Torx or allen or square drive hole in it as a last resort that saves the hassle of having to drill it out?
Or needed to remove a screw in a pinch when no real tools were handy and breathed a sigh of relief when the screw head was a Torx or square drive?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528132
>The biggest problem is autistic faggots assuming that one or two drive configurations can and should cover every possible combination of other factors

But there SHOULD only be a few. Ignoring security fasteners (which are homogay to begin with), there really should only be like four, max:

Spline has the highest torque capacity of any internal drive, but requires tight tolerances in order to work properly. If it slips, it's ruined.

Hex/torx are almost as good as spline, but is slightly more forgiving on tolerance.

Robertson/square is, again, slightly less capable than hex/torx, while being more usable in the case of fastener corrosion or damage.

Slotted is objectively fucking terrible, and should never be used. Its only saving grace is that you can easily turn all of the other really shitty fasteners into slotted, obviating the need for special drivers that you will never use again.


The rest should not exist, don't @ me. If you've got some niche scenario in which you "need" some other kind of screw, it's probably because you made some shitty other design decision. Fix THAT instead of making a new meme drive type.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2529235
>torx screws
>one bit is a perfect fit in all

WTF?
The main drawback of Torx is the need for separate drivers for each size and the extremly limited-to-non-existant ability to substitute anything else.
If all you ever do is bench/garage type work in controlled conditions then needing a complete set of graduated tools may not be a big deal, but in the field and/or in extreme conditions shit happens; tools break, fall over the side of a boat or into a tiny crevice , you need more than one at the same time, etc.
Three sizes each of straight blade or phillips drivers can handle a wide size range of both fastener types, and the straight ones can often work on the phillips too...AND sometimes will even work on a square or Torx or allen drive fastener in a pinch.
Although it should also be pointed out that all those drives being praised as superior because "they don't strip" also make it FAR more likely that careless morons will drive them in way too hard and often without any lube/ anti-seize or pilot hole or other considerations that make screws easier to install and remove without over torquing them and damaging the drive mechanism.
Straight slotted screws are used in precision mechanisms like watch movements in large part because they force you to be hyper aware of what you are doing and to have your tool in perfect alignment at all times and to never over torque the screw.
Phillips were designed to cam out rather than snap the heads off or damage the workpiece or gall when installers were moving fast.

But in any case, when fasteners are hard to remove without damaging them it's more often than not the result of careless installation, and the people whining about Torx and square drive being superior in all cases are crying because the fastener industry and product designers won't accomodate their laziness and lack of skill and PATIENCE that causes them to be defeated by the two simplest and most user friendly screw fastener drive schemes ever made.

posts.com:
Philips heads are more moden, they're harder to machine, harder to machine drivers for. But are centering and still decently rounding resistant.
Slotted is the grandfather of them all, dead simple to cut a notch in the screw and file/hammer down a driver. However it is not centering like the philips is and prone to having the driver slip. It is the single most rounding resistant aside from the spanner which doesn't even interface with the cuts unless properly engaged.
Slots still shine in very tiny applications. Like watchmaking where accurate machining/stamping of screws that tiny is not practical, and you generally have a machine putting the screes in anyways.

Chances are im entirely incorrect but this is what I've gathered in the thread and in real world experience

If you ate doing a repair or wall modification that requires taking g down drywall, even if you cut/break out the panel itself you still need to remove screws and if the wall was taped and finished they are all covered in drywall mud. Besides being fast to index and drive in an application where you only use a fraction of available torque anyway, phillips also has the advantage of the pointed nature of the bit naturally working to displace and eject the dried mud in the slots enough to get a bite, unlike other drives that engage in their hole like a piston and just pack that shit in tighter, and require a pick to remove debris.
Phillips is the perfect drive for drywall screws, which need removing pretty regularly.

Better question: How often do you need to remove the roll cage in a Mopar era Jeep, or the front and rear bumpers?
And why, in discussions of the rare occasions where this is necessary, do the words "torch", "grinder" and "air hammer" come up so frequently?

Here's a hint: the answer rhymes with "dorks".

When I was a young child my father had a screwdriver he brought home from work, and he called his magic screwdriver. It was obviously a flathead in a previous life, but he had filed the end into something new altogether, a driver that he claimed would turn ANY screw. I am currently 24 years old and I'm yet to find a screw this driver can't handle, no matter the shape, or the amount of stripping. I genuinely believe this screwdriver can never be replicated, not by any other man, or machine, one driver to rule them all. I know where it lives even to this day, in my dad's "various useful junk" drawer, in his kitchen, waiting for the next challenge, maybe even an old rusty allen bolt, who knows.

I love my father, but sometimes I sit up at night, wondering how much longer I have to wait. When I will get the call or the letter, informing me that I can finally claim what is mine, my birthright, and destiny. The greatest screwdriver that has ever been, and ever will be.

I've used auto-feed screw guns both for phillips drywall screws and installing wood and composite decking with square drive screws and in real world use the ability of the phillips to cam *in* as the fastener is indexed and locks into the drive makes for FAR more trouble free operation and less need to replace bits that aren't in perfect condition.
When you're doing fast repetitive driving, even with a clutch the pressure and motion on the square drive bits as they come out of the hole tends to round them off in a way that makes them more likely to not register with subsequent fasteners and misfire, which fucks the top up more.
The tapered nature of the Phillips profile can get spun smooth at that entry point and still let the tool pop right into its slot.
Also in non automated settings square drives used to back out tight fasteners can develop a twist that makes them harder to engage and weakens the tool.
For all the frustrations Phillips can be a part of, having a tool snap off in the slot and be galled in place because of the effort applied to try to back it out isn't one of them. Can't say that for Torx and square drives, that can snap off flush or below the head's surface and become their own project.

No, you literally can. Tort participation and many other problems can jew you out of your money if you're dumb enough to have your personal name visible on filing documents.
>If you are this fucking scared of having tenants, you are a huge pussy who NGMI in the real estate world.
No, I'm not scared because my personal name isn't attached to those liabilities on public documents. The corporate veil has to be pierced and Wyoming makes that incredibly difficult to do.

>>2530328
The secret is that those wood pilings are submerged all the time. Without any oxygen able to get to the wood they last perfectly well for decades.
Other examples are the pilings houses stand on in the Netherlands or those supporting the Speicherstadt in Hamburg Germany.

For wood pilings it is vital that they're submerged all the time. The oxygen starvation prevents or heavily delays the decomposition processes.

Best example is now in the Netherlands those same wood pilings. Due to the heavy dewatering of the low laying areas for pasture the soil itself drops down exposing the pilings themselves at the top causing them to rot right under the brick walls.

There's an old dude on Ambergris Caye who's the last remaining fisherman in the area permitted to harvest live conch from the reefs. Every day he goes out and gets a haul of conch, then putters his boat over to the same spot where he's been cleaning them for decades. He pops them out of their shells, and tosses all the shells overboard, to the point that the spot is a shallow area from the tens of thousands of accumulated conch shells.
He makes middling money from selling the meat to restaurants, but the wild thing is that he could set up a 20 sqft stall in San Pedro and sell these shells to tourists for $50-100 apiece, easily. Could probably make 10x his current income, even accounting for the retail space rent and the cost of hiring someone to staff it full-time, but he just throws the things away. My mom traded him a cold soda for a shell the size of her head.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531929
>Is this really that easy.
If you want to do this legally then no. It is not.
You have to get the truck. Gas. Oil changes.
You'll need commercial insurance
You'll need a DOT inspection and cert in each state you plan to operate in
You'll also need a USDOT number before you can get a sticker in CA.
You'll be required by law to keep an accurate log with your mileage, hours, and stops. You'll also be required to inspect your vehicle daily and keep a record of it.
If you're driving long hauls you are required to take mandatory breaks after a certain number of hours driving.
You'll need to register as a business (I'd suggest an LLC) and obtain a business license in whichever state you plan to be based in. Probably want a lawyer to help with that.
You'll have to keep detailed financial records for everything from gas to expenses, payments, receipts, etc. You may also have to file taxes in each state you operate. You'll definitely need an experienced accountant.

This is just the shit to get you started, I'm sure I'm forgetting stuff.

The good news is with a box truck that size you might be able to get away with not having a CDL unless you plan to haul hazardous material.

>>2535727
The veneer on the out side of the neck of these instruments acted like an external truss rod and allowed them to use a lighter softer wood for the neck and reduce weight since the tied frets would dent those softer lighter woods and make tuning the frets a pain. They also often had a fixed hardwood truss rod like your Harmony's steel bar. Their concern was more the long term effects of string tension, even low tensions will slowly bow a neck given time. Those old necks were insanely stiff and still many bowed. I assume you are not attempting to make an instrument which will last a century or more but I would either leave it or stick a good stiff hardwood in that slot, cheap insurance.

I love the old parchment roses which some of these guitars had and become fairly common in the baroque guitars, someday I will make one of these instruments just for the challenge, maybe something like the Belchior Dias Vihuela without the busy inlay, love its scalloped back.

Are you sticking to six single strings or going more traditional?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2536284
>A Renaissance guitar uses 3 courses
Ahh, I was thinking it was they were generally 4 course and 3 was rare and debated if they even exist. Romantic and late Baroque instruments are more my area of interest, I got lost quickly when I go back much before then.
>>2536356
Outdoor and interactive generally means either electronic instruments triggered by sensors or percussion instruments, most other things either get overly complex or have issues dealing with the abuse they will see. For percussion instruments you have 3 main types, bar supported at one end (kalimba), bar supported at two ends (xylophone) and membrane (drums or more suitable for your needs cajon). Between these three types and combinations of them you can get a surprisingly wide variety of sounds.

For example; a kalimba with very long tines attached to a cajon will allow the kalimba to modulate the sound of the cajon (assuming you pay attention to your tuning) when plucked and sound on their own when struck, etc and the tines will vibrate sympathetically and reinforce the sound of the cajon. These sorts of instruments work well in installations since two or more can play them and what they do directly alters the sound of what the others do. Essentially, every instrument has a resonator, your job is to make that resonator as much an instrument as the instrument it is a resonator for.

You can also manage some wind instruments through the use of bellows, cranked blowers/electric blowers, etc. Essentially just pipe organ pipes of various types and you can get the sound of most wind instruments this way, but things get complex quickly when you go down this path but it extends the way in which you can use the resonators of other instruments.

Having some knowledge of harmony and the harmonic series is a good idea if you lack it, will help you understand how sound sources with a shared resonator will interact.

I will skip going into electronic since the web is overflowing with that stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536505
>For percussion instruments you have 3 main types
I should probably also mention that each of these have two subtypes, stretched and unstretched, drum head versus cajon head is the obvious example here, the drum head is under tension, the cajon head is not.

A stretched bar supported at two ends is essentially a string, generally not great for such installations but you can make them thick enough that durability is not an issue and they have some advantages over an unstretched bar supported at both ends, they can have greater coupling with what those ends are attached too so you can effectively connect two resonators together and get three distinct instruments which influence each other.

A stretched bar supported at one end would be a hung weight, generally not useful here, does not add much for the added complexity and cost.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2536512
That is a fixed trussrod, it can not be adjusted. The adjustable truss rod is a fairly recent addition and in acoustic instruments is only really needed in 14 fret longer scale necks and even then can be skipped if your wood selection is good. In a 12 fret 24" scale neck like this Harmony, a non adjustable rod is all you need and even that is sort of overkill but they making these to be as cheap as possible so wood selection was just grab a stick from the pile and call it good. The vast bulk of lute famility instruments have managed without adjustable truss rods and some of them have much longer necks with far greater string tensions than the steel string guitar. picrol.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525741
Generally you can look at the pH.
Mild Akalines for organic stuff like food stains and microbes.
Mild Acids for inorganic stuff like limescale, rust, all the oxides. But you need to rinse/neutralize those surfaces after because microbes thrive in mildly acidic environments.
Strong Akalines aka Bleach kinda works on both.
Strong Acids are too destructive for regular household cleaning, imo.

The fancy OTS cleaners have surfactants mixed in that makes scrubbing far easier so don't dismiss them completely.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2526545
Yes. Jacks aren’t made to hold cars up. They’re made to lift cars and then you use the jack stands to actually hold the car. Any jack is going to slowly lose pressure and drop, and a well used jack is going to drop faster. The Chinese steel teeth on a $30 pair of jack stands are far more reliable than the Chinese rubber seals inside the jack.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>2526554
Layer it bra. Long johns on real cold days, decent pants, good socks, and then your choice of undershirt, a hoodie or fleece (the hoodie hoods are always more comfy than big jackets), and then whatever jacket that isn’t too puffy and thick.

You gotta strike that balance right before you start to sweat. 25F with the sun and manual labor, you will be good in the hoodie. 0F with wind and clouds just standing around, get your top layer jacket. Something about shells, the swooshy sounding jackets like windbreakers that don’t suck up water, those are good for top layers.

Look for gloves with thinsulate if that’s still around. I used to love these mittens where the 4 finger cover flips up and you get those hobo looking gloves and can use your fingertips.

posts.com:

Is there a quick and reversible way to block a sewer pipe? (other than Mexican food).

The reason I ask is that my house has a really funky and not-code sewer drain, with a total of four sewage reflux gullies that are too high to do anything. I don't want to go to the expense of doing the right thing and installing a sewage reflux valve, but I do get very nervous about the sewer main blocking up and my house being the first one to fill with shit.
I've been putting it off since I bought the house, but I had a bit of a shock last night when a small clog inside one of those gullies made my shower backflow with sewage when I tried to drain some water from my pool.

So my idea is I make (or buy?) some kind of device to manually block off my entire sewer line as close to the mains as possible, just in the situation where I do suddenly have sewage rushing into my house.
I'm thinking a similar concept to pic rel, but on some sort of stick or flexible hose which I can jam down the closest point to the mains (probably one of those gullies) and then completely seal off the sewer pipe.
Does such a thing exist, or is there a way to make it? And is it a terrible idea?
My current idea is some kind of inflatable ball on a hose, where I jam the ball down the pipe and then use compressed air (probably from a CO2 cartridge) to fill it up. When the mains blockage is cleared, I would just release the pressure and pull the ball back out.

>tl;dr how do I make an inflatable dildo for my sewer drain?

the time of picking up good deals on vintage tools ended when everyone had access to the internet in their pocket
if you're just getting into the hobby, buy cheap crap from harbor freight little by little. as you work, you'll begin to get an idea of what tools are okay when they're cheap, and which ones you need better versions of.

>>2527705
Different purposes Anon. Trigger clamps are useful for joining boards so you use many of them over the entire length and don’t put them extremely tight. F clamps are more useful for putting a lot of pressure on a few points. If you put a few f clamps very tight while glue laminating the wood will warp around eg knots and the result will be less flat.

the two black wires on the right are connected inside the switch. the black wire on the left is connected to the other two when the switch is closed. the ground is the bare twisted wires back in the box.

I figured, it confused me when I pulled it out, but now it makes sense. it's just an ungrounded switch and there are other outlets on this circuit, so one of the wires on the right is hot and the other one the right continues to the other outlets, and the left is the neutral, right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529052
>so one of the wires on the right is hot and the other one the right continues to the other outlets, and the left is the neutral, right.

yes. this is known as a "circuit tripper" switch because it is a convenient way to trip the breaker without having to go to the panel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous

I turned the breaker back on and used my voltage pen to find the hot one.

>>2529084

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529102
Ground on a switch doesnt really do anything because the load isnt in the switch but in the lamp, and the switch is itself a breaker for the flow of current.

Im not a burger so things may be different in the EU, but we never ground switches. Only at best the metal parts of the lamp itself. Its also normal to just have both hot/phase/plus cables in the same colour. With a switch you can usually tell which is which because one goes upward toward the lamp. Code also says supplying wire needs to be mounted on the bottom side of the switch.

This is bad juju anon. The point of a circuit breaker is to isolate the circuit line conductor.

Now if this is all just on the bench and connected to your house by a plug or something then ok maybe that's different, but it will still leak current and perhaps be very dangerous.
It also wont necessarily work at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Can anyone recommend a good stud finder?

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2532606
They all kind of suck. Look at the reviews, the <$15 Zircon to the $50+ Franklins are all the same… inconsistent.

The basic magnetic ones that find the screws in the drywall are the most reliable. The more expensive electronic stud finders all have extra shit like a laser to mark the stud or the ability to find wires behind the drywall, but they all use the same exact system to search for the studs and it’s always like 60% accurate no matter on the model. I recently went through thie when I bought a Zircon with some fancy features thinking it would be better than my old 10-15 year old guy, and it’s just as reliable as the cheaper Zircon that was dying and the really cheap Walmart B&D that had batteries explode inside.

So get the magnet, or get an electronic one, but don’t expect the $70 electronic one to locate studs any better than the $12 electronic one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532608
Thanks for the tips. I'll just go for the $20 Zircon then.

posts.name: Kevin Van Dam
posts.com:
>>2532620
Yea honestly just find a spot where you get a good, clean, consistent hit with the stud finder, try to mark the center, and measure from that one stud.

I think that blue Zircon was still like $30, and I would’ve gone with the Franklin if they were any more consistent but they’re not. The blue one has the laser to mark the middle of the stud, it’s a nice feature but it only works half the time just like all the other stud finders, and it’s easy enough to find the center with the cheaper ones when they actually locate a stuf. The electricity sensing things are goofy, I would never rely on them for safety, just see if you have any outlets or switches in line with where you’re trying to drill.

Read the reviews of all the Home Depot and Lowe’s studfinders besides the magnet ones and they’re all the same, like 3.5 stars average. I don’t know why nobody can make a good one.

This a story. I live in a trailer. My kitchen sink is clogged. It fills up with water almost instantly as soon as you turn the knobs. I assumed that somewhere between the sink and the grinder, there was a clog. That's reasonable? I tried a drain snake but it was only 20 feet long so I hired a plumber.

He came over with a 100 foot drain snake. He put it down my drain and it looked like the water ran through. Then it filled right back up. So he ran it again. And it filled right back up. He ran his drain snake 8 times and each time he pulled it out, it looked like the pipe was draining (though I do understand that the snake itself was simply displacing the water into the bucket under the out).

After he had done this five times he became baffled and began asking me to go out to the grinder and look inside. I did. The drain head was all the way into the grinder.

None of the other drains that all empty into the same pipe and all flow into the grinder are clogged. My toilet runs fine. I shower. I wash my hands and brush my teeth daily. My washing machine does not flood the narrow hallway.


After two hours he left, completely unsure why my kitchen sink does not drain; His snake unclogs many restaurants and retail stores with far higher usage than my sink. Eventually he left, but did not charge me for his time and effort. He just did not understand it.

I don't understand it.


Can you determine WHY my kitchen sink does not drain is every thing else is fine and he even pushed it all the way through to the other side? I have included a simplified version of my trailer, plumber and pipe setup to, I hope, convey what is wrong and help SOMEBODY tell me how it can still be clogged.

>>2532818
That's what needs to happen to properly support the lean-to.
If you just set it on the eaves(the overhang) it would fuck the existing roof and the new one. You have to set the high side on boards that run down to the sill plate so up aren't just relying on rafters.

So remove the lower sheathing, attach the lean-to roof framing to your existing roof framing running past the outside support wall
Cut boards to run from the boards down to the sill plate (custom framed roofs are offset so your vertical boards might sit on the boards that make your ceiling, if they're premade trusses, they'll be in the same plane so you can run down to the top sill plate of the wall)

Then sheathe the lean to
Then resheathe the roof down to the lean-to's new sheathing
Then put a moisture barrier if you aren't sheathing with zip-system or similar, check to see if you need frost guard
Then flash and shingle

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529102
Most articles/videos are going to assume that you are looking for instruction because you are not an electrician so they will over explain things usually to what the newest code would be for simplicity rather than explain what the different wiring methods would have been used in older houses since they vary so much. Ideally modern buildings yes they would have the ground wire on each device (switch) but it still isn't necessary as it just prevents the mounting metal from getting energized. Which doesn't matter much in this case anyways since the part you would be touching during use (switch) is plastic.

> now I'm annoyed that all three wires are the same color with zero markings or tags to indicate what's what, fuck whoever wired this house
You have all of the information right there in the picture. Grounds (bare wires) are tied through as they should be, neutrals (white wires) are also tied through as they should be, the only ones that look different are the black hot lines. Two on one pole so that one line is always connected and then one on the other side that only activates when the switch is in the "on" position. Essentially the feeder line is getting split up into 2 outgoing lines, but only one of those lines is controlled by the switch. This is a common wiring technique for switches so that they don't have to pigtail the hot line (instead they are just using the one screw on the switch as the pigtail if that makes sense).

When in doubt, if you are just trying to replace the switch to say change the color/style/it's broken take a picture like you did and hook every wire back up to the new one the exact same way as the old. However, if you are looking to get more ambitious with projects (say adding a stack switch or adding a 3way for some reason) I strongly recommend researching wiring methods further.

posts.com: How do I comprehend whether this can 'pull' 29 inches of mercury? thats the recommendation for silicone degassing, but I dont understand how these units convert because apparently 29 inches of mercury is 100kpa which sounds mental when this thing says it will do 5pa

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536112
Vacuum is measured either "from a perfect vacuum" or "from atmosphere". A perfect vacuum is about 29.5 inches of mercury "from atmospheric", so 29 inches is a very good vacuum. 100kpa is atmospheric pressure, so 5pa "from vacuum" is -100kpa "from atmos", or 29.something from atmos.

It'll do fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536123
great explanation, thanks for that

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2536112

You have it mixed up. 29inHg of pressure differential is ~100kPa, but that's GAUGE pressure. Vacuum pumps are specified by the ABSOLUTE pressure they can achieve. That is to say, pressure relative to 0Pa (total vacuum).

In other words, that pump can achieve a vacuum just 5Pa above a perfect vacuum. This is plenty for degassing resins or silicone. I have that exact pump, and have used it for degassing resin before (needed to repair a magnetic clutch in a lathe transmission). Works just fine, as almost any vacuum pump would. If you only need a dial gauge, you don't need much of a vacuum, let's say.

>but I figure there is some sort of thermocouple that senses when the pilot is lit, right? How do I trouble shoot this?
A lot of times they use a sense bulb if they don't have a thermocouple. Regardless, they can go bad and I've had to replace one before in a situation exactly like yours.

Trouble shooting--- are you sure there is enough gas pressure reaching the valve in the first place? If so, then suspect the sense bulb/thermocouple. If replacing it doesn't work, then you can replace the entire valve.

UPDATE: OP here. I just wanted to than the anons that helped me. I fixed the pilot light issue with the replacement of a $10.00 thermocouple. The HVAC guy who told me that the valve was bad and that parts were unavailable for this unit will be reported to the Better Business Bureau. Reminder, he wanted $3700 to fix it.

The heater is still a bit wonky but it totally works on manual mode. I think there might be another sensor that is bad or maybe a relay. When on auto/thermostat mode the blower cycles on and off. When the temp drops, the furnace switches on audibly. The main burner lights but no blower. Then after 2-3 minutes its like it senses the temp getting too hot and then the blower turns on as a failsafe. What ever sensor is picking up the overheat cools once the blower runs for a minute and so it shuts off. Wash, rinse repeat. This is pure speculation of what is happening but it feels like a reasonable guess.

There are two switches labled on the schematic. A "lower limit" and then an "aux limit" not sure what the difference but I think they might be involved. I'll spend some time giving it a looking over with my volt meter on the weekend. Any further advice would be most helpful.

posts.com:
For many people and projects, they are a poor source of lumber.
However, they are not useless.

The GOOD - They are often free for the taking and they are often hardwoods

The BAD –
Their size limits their usefulness.
They are often aged or damaged.
They are more awkward to haul home than a stack of boards.
They require disassembly.
They do not all use the same sized boards, you have to find matching pallets to get a bunch of boards that are all the same dimensions.
They sometimes are treated with Methyl Bromide, which is a health risk.
They have nail holes, often quite noticeable.
Sometimes they have unknown substances spilled on them from leaks.
It is a hassle to make them not look like pallet wood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallets are stamped, but not on every board.
Only some pallets have risky chemicals, many are plain wood.

Pallets stamped HT are heat treated and safe to burn.
Pallets marked MB contain Methyl Bromide and should NOT be burned.

>Methyl bromide is a fumigant used to control pests in agriculture and shipping. Methyl bromide also depletes the ozone layer. Therefore, along with other countries, the United States has phased out production and consumption of methyl bromide with important exceptions for critical uses as well as quarantine and pre-shipment.
https://www.epa.gov/ods-phaseout/methyl-bromide

Is there a safe way to get these carcinogens out/off of the wood? Not to my knowledge.

Easy rule of thumb if they are MB or you don’t know for sure.

Don't Burn Them!
Keep the sawdust out of your lungs and off of your skin. This applies to all sawdust, actually.
Don't make cutting boards or other things that touch food.
Paint will seal them if you are still worried about excessive contact.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Using pallets intact has some applications, especially if you can find them the same size. I have seen furniture, animal pens. and greenhouses made from them. (The furniture is usually pretty ugly.)

MB-treated boards make decent outdoor planter boxes and other rustic things like shelves for your shipping container shed to store imitation crab meat.

Taking it apart isn't hard if you have the right tools.

If you are going to salvage a whole bunch of pallets, consider getting a specialized prybar. I would prefer to get one locally, so I could try it out to see if it is worthwhile, then be able to return it easily if it is crap.
https://www.1001pallets.com/top-7-best-pallet-buster-pallet-breaker-reviews/

https://www.99pallets.com/pallet-projects/diy-storage-shed-from-pallets/

This is unlikely to become a Sticky, so please help it stay on the board by posting pics of your projects and links to pallet idea websites that might inspire others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pallet Parts and Terminology

Annular Ring Nails (also called Ring Shank) – These are one of the most common types of fasteners used in pallet design. In essence, it is a nail with circular ring threads on the shank.

Banding Groove – Dunnage with a groove cut into the length of the lumber. It is used to protect unit loads from damage when banding is tightened down to secure a load onto a pallet.

Blocks – A square or rectangular piece of wood that is placed between the pallet decks or beneath the top deck. Some blocks can even be cylindrical. Generally, blocks are located at each corner of a pallet, centered on each of the four sides, and in the middle of each pallet. Placement is crucial to ensure block pallet strength.

Block Pallet – A type of pallet that uses blocks to form its base instead of stringers.

Bottom Deck – The deck boards on the bottom of a pallet that are sitting on the ground or floor.

Butted Deck Board – The name given to an inner deck board that is attached to an adjacent deck board during assembly to help strengthen it. These are often used when recycling pallets and pallet parts.

CAD – Stands for Computer Aided Design and helps pallet designers design packaging solutions.

Chamfered Deck Boards – Deck boards with the edges beveled. They are usually only beveled on one or two faces, and allow pallet jack wheels to enter the pallet more easily.

Collar – A wooden container or bin that turns a pallet into a box.

Container Bin Pallet – This is basically a crate, box, container, or four-sided structure mounted on a pallet base.

Deck – The boards or panels that make up the top or bottom surface of a pallet.

Deck Board – The component boards or panels that make up a deck.

Deck Board Spacing – The distance between deck boards on a deck.

Deck Board Span – The distance between the deck board supports. Could refer to the distance between stringers or blocks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Deck Mat – The assembled deck boards and stringers that make up the deck of a block pallet.

Deflection – The amount of bending or deformation in a pallet under load. Could refer to the whole pallet or a specific pallet part.

Double Face Pallet – A pallet built with both top and bottom decks.

Economic Life (of a pallet) – The number of trips a pallet is expected to make in its serviceable lifetime, provided that it remains properly repaired.

EURO Pallet – Block pallets built to European Pallet Association specifications. They usually have a branded logo on them.

Fastener – A component used to join pallet parts together, such as nails, screws, bolts, or staples.

Flush Pallet – A pallet where the deck boards are even or flush, with the stringers or blocks along the sides of the pallet.

Fork Entry – The opening between decks and beneath the top deck of a pallet where forklift forks can be inserted to lift the pallet and load. Sometimes stringers will have notches in them to allow for fork entry.

Four-Way Block Pallet – A block pallet that has openings on all four sides of the pallet to admit pallet jack entry.

Four-Way Stringer Pallet – A stringer pallet that has notches cut in the stringers to allow for pallet jack entry.

GMA or Grocery Manufacturers of America – Thee GMA has its own specific pallet requirements for its standard pallets.

Hardwood – The type of wood that comes from deciduous trees. Generally, these are the trees with leaves instead of needles, but there are exceptions. Although called hardwood, that doesn’t necessarily mean that it’s hard or dense. It depends on the species of tree the wood comes from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Inner Deck Board – Any deck board that is positioned between the end deck boards.

Joint – The point at which the components of a pallet intersect or connect. They are often identified as the end joint, center joint, and corner joint.

Length – In general, this is the first dimension given to describe a pallet and refers to the stringer or stringer board length. For example, a standard 48” x 40” pallet length is 48”, and is also the length of the pallet’s stringer.

Line Load – When the weight of a unit load is concentrated in a narrow area across the full length or width of a pallet.

Load Bearing Surface – The area of a pallet in contact with and supporting the weight of the unit load.

Multiple Use Pallet – A pallet designed to be used for several trips with different unit loads.

Non-Reversible Pallet – Describes a pallet where the bottom deck boards are configured differently from the top deck boards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Notch – A cutout in the wood of a pallet part. It could refer to something like the notch in banding groove, or the notch in a notched stringer.

Notched Stringer – On a pallet, this is a stringer that has notches cut out of it to allow entry for forklift tines. The notch is usually ½” to 1” in depth and 9” long, depending on the size of the pallet.

Opening Height – This refers to the vertical distance between decks on a pallet. It’s measured from the floor to the top of the stringer notch, or from the floor to the underside of the top deck.

Overhang – The distance that the pallet deck extends past the outer edge of the stringer or stringer board. It’s also called a wing or lip. Overhang can also refer to the distance that a unit load extends beyond the pallet deck.

Pallet Life – The length of time that a pallet remains useful. It’s usually expressed in the number of one-way trips that the pallet is expected to make or in units of time.

Panel Deck Pallet – A pallet constructed with some type of paneling product (OSB, composite, etc.) for the top deck.

PDS – Stands for Pallet Design System and is a computer aided design program that helps engineers to design pallets to safely carry a load and maximize the supply chain.

Recycled Pallet – A previously used pallet that is recycled and has been repaired for reuse with replacement pallet parts as needed. It’s also referred to as a refurbished or reconditioned pallet.

Remanufactured Pallet – A pallet that’s been built from reclaimed pallet parts. Sometimes they are also built from a combination of new and reclaimed pallet parts.

Skid – A pallet with no bottom deck that rests on the stringers. It’s a little like a sled on rails.

Slave Pallet – A support base for a palletized load in rack-storage facilities or production systems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Softwood – Softwood comes from evergreen trees. Generally, they have needles instead of leaves, but there are exceptions. The term softwood does not necessarily mean that the wood is a soft wood.

Solid Deck Pallet – Refers to a pallet that is constructed with no spacing between deck boards.

Span – The distance between block supports, stringer boards, or stringers.

Stevedore Pallet – Designed for seaport shipping docks, this pallet is designed with heavy-duty, double-wings.

Strapping – Flat, thin bands that are used to secure a load to a pallet. Often used with banding groove.

Strap Slot (also called a Banding Notch) – The notch or cutout on the bottom edge of the top deck board or the top edge of a stringer. It allows for strapping or banding to tie down a unit load.

Stringer – A solid or notched piece of lumber that is used to support the deck components on a pallet. Stringers run perpendicular to the deck components and there is usually one on each side of the pallet and one in the center.

Stringer Board – Refers to the solid boards that extend the full length of a block pallet and run perpendicular to the deck boards. Stringer boards are placed between the deck and the blocks.

SYP – Stands for Southern Yellow Pine, and it’s the wood most often used in wood protective packaging.

Take-It-Or-Leave-It Pallet – Refers to a pallet with fixed cleats on the top deck that provide a location for forklift tines to get under the unit load and lift the load off of the pallet.

Top Cap – A panel that is placed on top of unit load to protect it from strapping.

Two-Way Entry Pallet – A stringer pallet that does not have any notched stringers. Forklift tines can only enter the pallet on the ends.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Unit Load – The palletized goods sitting on a pallet.

Wing Pallet – A pallet with the top and bottom deck boards extending past the edge of the stringers. Can also be a double-wing pallet if both sides extend past the edge of the stringers. Wing pallets can be single wing or double wing.

>>2526784
My fees broke down to cars being one price and SUV/Van/truck being a different price. I would either do the interior, the exterior or both. Interior I could usually do in 2 hours maybe 3. and exterior would take almost 4 hours. car interior was 100 and exterior was 125. For the van/truck/suv the fee was interior 125 and exterior 175. But this was 8 years ago, no idea what I would charge now

I had basic wash and wax stuff, and a machine buffer. For interior I had a vacuum and a steam cleaner. All my products were either meguairs or Griots. I always used microfiber cloths never rags. Microfiber cloths were thrown away after jobs I never washed them. On a full inside/outside I could usually get done in 6 or 7 hours. But if I had a van or something that was really fucked up it might take 8 hours.

Biggest tip is to take some before and afters and use social media as your word of mouth advertiser. Make damn sure that every single customer you work with posts something about you on either facebook or next-door and puts your phone number out there. Also get 500 flyers for your services off vista print.

No an LLC is a waste of time for the money you are gonna make. Just have them pay you cash and don't put the cash into the bank.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525332
I started a mobile auto detailing business. I use a Rigid 5HP 4gal, one of their cheapest ones but the suction is great. You can get three uses out of each filter bag by cutting an end open, emptying it, and stapling it shut again. I also use Ridgid’s car cleaning kit which comes with an orange hose that is longer and softer, and a flexible crevice tool. These are essential. Throw in some kind of rubber brush or textured rubber glove for scooping up dog hair and you’re set on vacuuming.

For steam I use a McCulloch MC1375, great little machine. Saves a lot of time on cleaning if you learn how to use it. Takes 5-15 minutes to heat up depending on ambient temp and can last for two interiors. I’ve had a couple plastic bits break but it still works great. Be careful not to spray steak behind transparent plastic windows on dashboards and centre consoles. Oh and let the steam machine warm up before you start your vacuum or you will trip your client’s breaker.

I would also recommend you pick up a Bissel spot pro wet extractor for shampooing. Takes more passes than a commercial machine to get the job done but it works, and you can keep your vacuum dry and clean in the long run.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530090
If you're in a camper, where does the toilet flush to? Is it a tank under your camper? Is it hooked up to a septic tank?

Also, a toilet gets new water from pipes and flushes into a drain. Is water source frozen or the drain frozen? If you have a septic, it's very unlikely the latter.

If the entire system is localized to your camper, go to Home Depot and buy an electric heat gun, preferably battery-operated. Then get on your hands and knees and modestly heat the waterworks. Do this every hour until weather improves. Don't overheat, you might loosen solder or gaskets. Just enough to warm things to a point that can melt ice, which needn't be very hot at all.

^This, the LP style using the BBQ LP cylinders works at all angles.

Then aim that beneath your camper (block off any air exits if you don't have skirting with cardboard, ,many stores give it away) and heat all beneath to the lines and because heat rises. I keep a Mr Heater of the style mentioned for local heating.

Collect things that make heat. Corded heat guns (battery units are too weak) used with care (put your hand between gun and target and if you can hold your hand there you won't overheat the target) are very useful. I collect those too at yard sales etc but they're cheap new.

Put together a simple bucket toilet as used for camping. Shit in bags, place outside to freeze. When ground thaws dig hole and bury or toss into burn barrel/fire. It's only shit, not nuclear waste. BTW burn barrels should really be tubes and have no bottom. That way you can kick them over instead of emptying them. Hunt one or several. Old 55 gallon drums work well.

Next time plan for cold weather during hot weather and remember every minute you spend on non-useful activities (like getting smarter about everything) you pissed away. Study all this shit instead of wasting whatever time you wasted. You're not poor due to being smart so stop being you and force yourself to do better.

Have gas. Collect BBQ cylinders all the time at every opportunity then fill them and stash them outdoors. I get mine at yard sales etc but obviously winter is a bit late so buying two (run one then have a spare to rotate so you're never out) is wise.

Underpin your camper which you should have known to do from the relentless study of how to live better in poverty.

You got your ass handed to you but it's a learning experience. Take (not kidding, I do) written notes. For example next time you expect deep freezing weather shut off your water and drain all your water containers which are subject to freezing. Drain your water lines.

What did you study to do before the freeze?

>>2531721
"Brick" describes a modular masonry unit, not one particular material...and the process used to make them goes from no firing (adobe) to low firing (terracotta) to high fired structural brick that's essentially vitreous and similar to igneous stone.

Also, while concrete bricks aren't fired in a kiln, the component materials in cement are, and the curing process is exothermic.
The cement in concrete is made primarily from sedimentary rock (limestone) that has been fired to a higher temp than terracotta bricks are fired at.

"The products of the chemical reaction aggregate together at their sintering temperature, about 1,450°C (2,640°F). "
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cement_clinker

What anon said. If there’s already an outlet there, you will be cool. An outlet needs 2 wires for power, the live and neutral, and any outlet you will replace has those 2 going to it. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531044
You typically don't just throw a bunch of GFCI outlets everywhere. Outlets are usually ran in a series from a breaker at your panel. And you put them in to trip those rather than the breaker at the panel. Our bathroom sockets run from the panel, to the second bathroom, and feed over to the master bathroom; so the second bathroom gets the GFCI. Yours is the last in the chain because you don't have a second set of wires feeding over to anywhere else.

Find the first socket in the series for that breaker, put a GFCI outlet on it, then put a regular socket where you've put this one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Actual glass fabricator here.
Tempered glass is not the go to material for table top whether in a frame or with floating edges, because it doest like edge damage *at all* and also doesn't like concentrations of heat like you get in typical table uses.
Tempered glass is notorious for shattering with small concentrated point impacts and tables get those all the time from dropped utensils, tableware, etc.
The other thing is that tempering has to be done after any edge profiling is done so doing it risks all that labor. It's also done in an oven and can leave marks where the glass is supported and other imperfections that don't work well with something that needs optical clarity like a display case.

The way you get table capable glass strength is by using thick annealed glass, and 1/4"-5/16" is perfect for that kind of perimiter framed box, but not thinner. 1/2" is adequate for free standing di ner table and desk tops up to about 48" in any dimension and after that it starts to sag under its own weight.

Bottom line is that if a glass table or desk or display case breaks from dropping something on it you dont want everything else on it to dump at once into a pile of glass bits. If you chip an edge with annealed glass you can re-grind it or polish it out or cut a strip off, tempered just explodes.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2528123
machinist at a glass company here. I am in fact cutting glass as I type this. listen to this guy, he gives good advice. further, when you support the glass pane in the tabletop try and distribute the supporting surfaces as broadly as possible to avoid high concentrations of stress at any particular point. avoid having any hard materials like metal touching the glass in the construction - plastic, wood, and rubber are among the best materials to be around it. I would probably even lay the pane in a bed of some sort of rubberized material (something like automotive seam sealer or a butyl adhesive comes to mind) as this will protect the easily-chipped edges and give an even, vibration-damped support surface. As others have mentioned, scratches and heat concentrations can also weaken the glass over time, so invest in/build some nice coasters to go along with your table to help prevent that

posts.com:
>>2534401
>How do I put the pattern on the fabric?
I use chalk. Tailors chalk is worth buying, and its dirt cheap.

>Would it be fine to draw an outline then cut pieces as I need to?
I am not aware of any laws that would violate.

>How would I sew the ends of the fabric so that they don't get frayed and torn?
Usually you use a hem. Your pattern will usually account for this

Some general advice:
Pick a small project to practice on, and use a dirt cheap material like an old bed sheet.

Iron your raw material, iron again after cutting out the pieces, and iron your seams/hems before sewing. Goes a long way to making your stitches look right.

Understand that just because you have a pattern, it doesn't mean that it will just magically fit you. You still have to tailor many garments. For this reason, I really recommend using a seam ripper and taking apart an old shirt that first you well, and make your own pattern from that. It's a good practice project too. There's tons of youtube tutorials on patterning, just don't forget your seam allowances.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534401
Typically patterns come on tissue paper that you're expected to either cut out and pin to your fabric before cutting, or use a pattern wheel (either the spikey one the dashed one plus carbon paper) to transfer to the fabric. There is a facebook group that has a bunch of info on using cheap projectors mounted above a cutting table to bypass that completely; I recommend that shit highly if you get into it, it's been great to just weigh fabric down, project, and go around it with a rotary cutter (you should use a cutting mat and rotary cutter even if you don't do a projector).

Go to a thrift shop and buy a few 100% cotton sheets / duvets and use them as fabric to make yourself some pillow cases and pajama pants and then go from there.

Your machine will have a zig zag stitch or an overlock stitch that you can use with or instead of various seam finishing techniques to prevent fraying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
there's a long line on each pattern piece with an arrow at one or both ends of it that's labeled "grainline" or similar. align the pattern pieces so that the grainline runs parallel to the selvage (i.e. the edges that don't fray) of the fabric. if you're doing each piece one at a time on a single layer of fabric, don't forget to flip the paper over before doing the second cut so you end up with mirrored pieces.
>How would I sew the ends of the fabric so that they don't get frayed and torn?
"edge finishing" and "seam finishing" are the search terms you want. what's appropriate depends on what you're making. french seams are efficient and tidy, look that one up.

>>2534912
straight stitch throat plate. straight stitch foot or walking foot. a straight stitch walker would be ideal but i'm not sure you'd find one. move the needle down manually before engaging the motor. frankly i'd skip the motor altogether and walk the whole piece through with the hand crank instead. this just a one-off job? given the small size of the work i'd opt for saving the wear on the machine over saving the time. wouldn't bother with the paper testing either.

careful light abuse can only compensate for so much. if still snapping needles after swapping out the throat plate i'd treat the whole stack of bullshit like leather and saddle stitch it. if this isn't a one-off, i'd check craigslist for either a cheap enough heavier duty machine or a cheap as dirt comparable machine to use/abuse instead. if set to become even a semi regular thing, i'd follow the suggestion to get a dedicated machine that's better suited to the task.

If she's making $150k a year, you can definitely afford a house. Life style creep is real and hard to deal with. I made 120k while my wife made 35k but now she's making close to 80k and keeps buying more bullshit. Most women are fucking retarded with money.

I use a budget tool, the one I use is You Need A Budget. I religiously tracked every expense and categorized them, and after 6 months I showed my wife what we spend our money on. Every month I sit her down and we go over what we want to budget. We can afford a $2700 mortgage and over $3000 in child care (2 kids now). We almost max out 401k's as well but have up on IRA.

It took some rough uncomfortable talks to get her to calm the fuck down with her money and make her understand that if we pay the mortgage every 2 weeks instead of monthly we will pay it off 7 years early. It took some time to show her how much we needed to save if we want to retire at 60.

You are her partner. Don't belittle yourself for making less. You can look for a higher paying job maybe on the coast where she "works" now. There may also be a tech bust sooner or later. It sucks, but you need to make her understand you're a team, have a discussion about what HER goals are, and help her reach them. If she's spending like this maybe she doesn't care about a house. Get your goals situated and help her come up with a plan.

Old Retiredfag reporting in.

I semi retired in 2018 and my wife just gave her notice recently. We took turns being the higher earner for most of our careers but in the last 7-8 years her annual salary + bonus was far more than I ever made in a single year. Easily more than 2x.

We were careful with our money over the years and are retiring with no debt at least 10 years before most working stiffs do.

The biggest "secret" to that is we paid ourselves first before spending the fun money. We made a list of our priorities and made sure most of the money went towards that: maxing 401ks, contributing to 529 college funds, paying down the mortgage etc... We determined who would pay for what and that's how the bills got paid. Short term savings in a joint account, but all remaining "fun money" went to separate checking accounts. That way we each spent on stuff we wanted without pissing the other person off. No arguing over spending in 25 years.

Don't base your worth on your job and how much you make. It's a fool's errand. As long as you make enough to live on and have the right partner, you'll be happy.

>>2528678
$3k/month in child care is fucking insane. That's more than my wife and I's total expenses in an entire month.
The key is to have your living expenses not exceed in net income of the top earner. $2700 on a mortgage is quite high (that's a $600k+ home), even in expensive parts of the country. Having no payment on your cars will also help a TON.

Being able to live on a single income will then allow you or your wife to stay home with the kids until they go to school. Also, by having someone doing domestic stuff, your expenses will go down even further. The partner at home with the kid(s) will have the time to do lots of cooking, which saves a ton of money on groceries/fast food/eating out. Transportation expenses will go down, and they'll even be able to do things like home improvement or general repairs on stuff that you'd otherwise have to pay money for.

Also, if you're fortunate enough to have family nearby, the kids grandparents can help out with childcare. Most grandparents certainly wouldn't mind having their grandkids for a few hours, every 2 or 3 days.

Sign companies, like cabinet companies, make their money on design and install. Anyone can order some shit online and install it but no one wants to deal with it when it breaks.

General woodworking is a tough gig because so many retired dudes do the easier stuff as a hobby.
You need to figure out how much money you want to make, figure out how to take in double that per day (for the business) and then figure out what you can do to reach that number.
If I had CNC machines, I'd manufacture small wood products to sell. If I found there was a market for my flagship product, I would have Amazon fulfill the orders

I'm getting into real estate because so many people will pay a fortune for stupid shit on a 30 year loan whereas it's super difficult to find someone who will pay $60k for a high end kitchen remodel

The big advantage internal combustion engines have is that they run at high compression "for free" - a comparable Stirling needs to be pumped up to pressure before running or be a sealed pressurized design. There's nothing stopping you from building one that uses higher compression other than the engineering involved.
Swedish submarines (Gotland class) use Stirling engines instead of diesels, so they're not just toys.
I could be wrong, haven't looked at the subject in a few years.

> I've toyed with the idea of building a stirling-driven drinking cart for the Indy 500.
Sounds completely impractical and I love it already. Think of all the (You)s!

>>2509786
There were lots of small improvements made in the 1930s and 1940s when they were more widely used. Unfortunately it seems like most of the knowledge is spread out among communities that don't talk to each other.
For example, there are a few people in Sweden who drive gasifier-fueled cars, and every single one of them use a "stacked pancakes" fabric filter (a large "sock" that is tied off around wireframe discs; used to be canvas cloth in the 1940s, nowadays it's fibreglass). I've never seen for example Americans use fabric filters. Burgers all seem to use the Wayne Keith design, but the details are a trade secret and nobody outside of the US has heard of it.
The basics should be the same though, and there are some obvious things like insulating the hearth (firebox?) and using a heat exchanger for the air intake that I would do.
Another thing would be to convert a modern electric hybrid car. The pros and cons of a gasifier and a battery vehicle means they would complement each other pretty well.

Cyclones filter out particles; they are heavier than the gas and get flung to the outer wall and fall down. The intended use is that they catch most of what comes out so that the filters clog up less often.
Dealing with tar is mostly done, from what I've seen, by minimizing production (right fuel, right temperature) and cooling the gas before it reaches the engine.

>>2516964
I've researched a ton on steam engines, but I've slowly realized there are too many reasons gas engines are superior. Steam engines become very complicated when trying to make them competitive. Most people aren't going to mess with steam boilers (regardless of whether the design is safe), while steam generators require precise controls. Most burner designs have the flame quenched by the boiler/generator with a lot of unburnt fuel appearing as smoke. Ideally, only the exhaust should make contact with the boiler/generator. COGAS (Combined Gas and Steam) engines actually uses the exhaust of a gas turbines to heat a boiler and are among the most efficient combustion engines out there. Going back to using turbines for wood, you'd also use a separator like you would for wood gasifiers, the only difference is all the heat is concentrated in one operation for a higher thermal efficiency.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2517210
>What do you mean by efficiency here?
Power vs. fuel consumption

>having a cold gas at the start of the cycle increases the difference in temperature and therefore pressure.
Having a colder temperature would increase the efficiency of the Carnot cycle if delta T remains constant. However, delta T is purely a function of the amount of fuel burnt, heat capacity, and heat lost to the surroundings. A slower burn is going to lose more heat to the surroundings and an incomplete burn means less fuel burnt. In practice, a slower burn is also going to have less room to expand, and less work will be recovered from it, but a Carnot engine doesn't have any notion of a stroke or expansion ratio.

There's a 99.8% selective methanol synthesis from carbon monoxide and hydrogen with a copper and zinc oxides catalyst at engine cylinder pressures (750~1500 PSI) and kitchen oven temperatures (250C / 500F). It can also work with carbon dioxide and hydrogen or carbon monoxide and water, since CO2 and H2O are intermediates in the process.

Apart from methanol being a gasoline substitute, there's also a simple dehydration reaction with solid acid catalysts (such as gamma alumina) at the same temperature and pressure conditions to produce dimethyl ether. DME has very similar handling characteristics to propane, and is non-toxic and non-corrosive and can be burned for heating and cooking, but also works well in diesel engines (with some conversion required, obviously).

These processes seem like they should be simple enough for small factories run by an individual or small team. Not too much harder than the combination of wood gas conversions and moonshining, and you get fuels that can be handled, stored, sold, and generally used for all the same things as today's standard fuels. You can make them from fire wood in the countryside, coal in coal country, and if solar panels keep getting cheaper, eventually from electrolysis hydrogen and CO2 from chemical capture methods or biomass (you can still get CO2 out of biomass you can't easily burn properly for energy).

The toxicity of methanol isn't that much worse than gasoline. Its reputation for toxicity is mainly from people mistaking it for ethanol and drinking it with enthusiasm. DME is basically non-toxic.

Butanol is attractive in several ways (including its gasoline-like energy density), but since it's produced by fermentation, it's a much more finicky, picky process. You probably can't make it from coal or electrolysis hydrogen, except by complex synthesis no easier than gasoline. Furthermore, the fermentation process only works on cellulose, it'll do little to nothing with lignin, which is a major component of wood.

Not him, but offshore drilling rigs, fracking rigs, and refineries are all complex operations dependent on sophisticated industry and the cooperation of many people. In a breakdown of social order, they could easily cease operation.

Cutting firewood and strip-mining coal are relatively unsophisticated by comparison, and as a regular average dumbass, you can probably participate in them in an energy crisis. Even mining coal with a pick and a shovel is surprisingly productive, probably better than cutting firewood with a chainsaw and a hydraulic splitter. And because we've largely moved on from firewood, there's a lot of energy saved up in the trees we haven't cared to cut down. American industry ran largely on firewood through most of the industrial revolution, because of those vast pre-industrial forests, and they have recovered quite well since we switched to oil and coal.

We're pretty careless with spending energy because it's so cheap, but if things go to shit, we've got to at least be able to keep the farms running, and the trains and riverboats, and short-haul trucking to get goods into the stores. Wood and coal can do that, with far from ideal social organization, if we're smart about it.

>Can we get a description of what's happening here?
Sure. I guess I should add some reference number. Essentially there are 3 circuits:
- the air circuit (hatched) that cools the mantle before being diluted with exhaust and then is fed into the reactor (bottom right)
- the wood gas circuit from the reactor going through tar absorbers and filter before going to the gas turbine, while being cooled by water
- the water circuit that goes in opposite direction to the wood gas circuit, picking up heat throughout the path, before being superheated in the spiral at the bottom of the reactor and then powers a steam turbine.

Lots of details (condencer, recuperator, waste extraction etc) are missing but I hope those are obvious anyway.
Wood in the first tar absorber is fed to the reactor through the yellow square chute at intervals, thus recycling the tar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523152
The amount of energy it would require to run a wood chipper off your engine would almost certainly negate any advantage you'd get out of the setup. I think the most efficient way to to this would be to somehow automate or at least greatly simplify the process of loading entire logs into the combustion chamber.

As for wood pellets, a lot of the reason for their efficiency advantages don't apply in a gasifier. They're more efficient than a regular wood stove because they burn using a forced convection system, and as a result of the forced convection and their high density they burn at a much higher temperature than regular wood. Forced convection isn't possible in a gasifier and the heat of the reaction doesn't matter much when the process you're using relies on further chemical reactions downstream of the gasifier.

I also question if charcoal in a gasifier is a good idea. The process of making charcoal is essentially the same thing as what's happening in a gasifier, except by separating those processes you'd be losing out on the stream of volatile exhaust gases that come out of the charcoal and relying solely on the carbon monoxide to fuel your car. Using charcoal you're throwing away a good portion of the energy of the wood, and once again the advantage of a higher temperature burn doesn't benefit a gasifier like it would in a furnace.

Here in Sweden we explicitly used normal firewood. The government set standards saying that only specially treated birch was acceptable for cars (called bilved, "car firewood"), but in my parts of the country (very rural, even today if you don't work in forestry or paper manufacturing, you're a farmer) people were just using the exact same firewood they stockpiled for heat in winter, and by all accounts it worked just fine. Some of the wood gas converted cars stayed like that for decades, until the government got stricter about what you were allowed to drive on the road. Even when I was growing up in the 90s my neighbor still had an old wood-gas tractor. He never used it because he also had a modern diesel tractor, but it still ran. He drove it into town for the autumn market festival to show it off a few times. Using firewood probably produces more exhaust or ash than the bilved, because pine doesn't burn as well as birch in the first place, but I don't think that matters too much. Pine firewood is significantly cheaper than birch, let alone birch put through whatever treatment the government wanted people to do.

Here in Norway, Alder was the preferred kind of firewood for wood gas generators.
