>>2530812
I think I understand what you meant now.
Filtering takes place in several steps. The first one (above the gas generator) catches tar and some particles in the tar. Once the wood in the tar absorber is fully loaded, it is sent down the chute (yellow square) into the gas generator. The filter is rotated so right side wood is turned to the left side and more wood is added. This lock means you avoid CO poisoning.
The next filter is more tar filtering by wood chips, as shown in >>2504529. You could move that to the gas generator too.

The third filter is teh cyclone filter. And I guess you are concerned about carbon rich particles removed here. I would expect most of this to be ash particles rather than carbon rich particles. I don't know how you can separate these. Just feeding it all bak into the gasifier means you will have a lot of ash circulating.

posts.name: Turbro
posts.com:
>>2530831
Well your design is certainly more efficient than mine if paired with an Otto or Diesel engine. It could perhaps be simpler, lighter, and even more efficient if the engine was the detonating Quasiturbine type and the steam engine were replaced with pre-heated air. The EGR is potentially interesting if you are using the 2 CO2 + heat -> 2 CO + O2 reaction to feed + cool the gasifier, and provide some suction at the exhaust. However, the biggest downfall is what to do with the carbon particles (especially if you are feeding in pressurized exhaust).

>no energy to be obtained by burning carbonates.
CaCO3 -> CO2 + CaO (quicklime) would turn some of the heat into expansive energy (work). Quicklime is useful for many industrial applications.

>the gasifier operates at high temperatures
Two potential issues. First, there's a water coil cooling the bottom of the gasifier. Next, the CO2 + C -> 2 CO reaction is going to provide some cooling and expand the recirculated exhaust (taking back what I said earlier). A turbocharger could recover the work, but then it's basically my design with EGR and a high compression engine. The steam engine could be replaced with water injection before the turbine, and a condenser to pre-heat the intake and recover the water with extra for drinking and irrigation.

posts.name: Turbro

>>2532738
Replace combustor with a high compression engine, and it might be worth the otherwise pointless gasification stage.

>>2532811
>The gasifiers used on cars and buses during WWII are shown with coolers, also thee the first few images in this thread.
The designers were probably worried about the volumetric energy density of the gas, but all that goes out the window when you can put a bigger compressor to compensate.

>Would cooling really be a major problem?
The soot isn't going to damage anything as long as the engine is hot enough to avoid excessive deposition there, and it would actually lubricate if the engine was still cool enough to allow a thin layer of soot to form. (If we could do away with splash lubrication in an engine, that would probably be a significant gain.) However, the efficiency will go down if soot deposits are excessive anywhere in the system, which will require a cleanout as >>2532826 mentions.

Inappropriate cooling has plagued engine building since steam, where the flame was in thermal contact with the boiler in older designs, then again with non-regenerative cooling in IC piston engines which continues to this day.

see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

the protective gear part is a different beast. the orthopaedic gear is to prevent knee injury from missteps or non optimal posture. same goes for the lumbar belt.
even the cheap aldi versions do their job.

joint injury is the number one eliminator of modern troops.

for the fit: add a padded comfortable belt strap with some semi-rigid plate support. this way you circumvent the spine being loaded and free your lungs more. putting padding on the shin lower side, so it rests better on the shoe, can make the bug a feature.

some light knee pads could help with the armor and hard knuckle or sand gloves would add some necessary hand protection.

for the groin plate: try to cut it int an inverted trapezoid (basicly upside down chest plate shape). then it moves more easily when walking. the two removed pieces can be added as belt flaps/ armor skirt pieces.

>>2513688
For maximum efficiency, cut the fat out and chop it into ~1cm cubes. Put it in a pot with some water to cover and heat it to a simmer. After a few hours all the fatty acids will be rendered out of the tissue, then you sift the chunks out and let the liquids harden. The fat layer separates and floats on the water. To clean it just scrape the grimy bits off the bottom of the solid fat layer and put it back in a pot with fresh water and a generous handful of salt, bring it to a simmer and stir it a bit, let it cool and repeat until pearly white. Finally melt the fat down and insert a wick. There you go, odorless human candle.
Human fat is about 7700kcal/kg which is a lot better than wood pellets which generally sit around 4300kcal/kg. You only need a small fraction of that energy to refine it.

To make soap all you need to do is weigh your human tallow, then bring it to about 50°C. Take 26.82% of your fat weight in distilled water and 13.41% in pure lye and dissolve it in the water (do it with good ventilation or die). It will heat to almost boiling so let the mixture come down to around 50°C also, then dump it in the liquid fat and blend it with an immersion blender until it turns into a sort of paste. Scoop that out into whatever mold you like and let it sit for a day, then demold it and let it air dry for 2-4 weeks.

I wrote ZNA productions and techthisoutmeow multiple times, donated to their patreon. Wanted them to build and shoot test panels with my method. But thankfully a german hansguns offered to test it for me, I'll be sending him 2 such testpanels after xmas. I've gained some doubts of the success of my plates delivering what I hope for, because I did something different. I didn't vacuum press the plates during curing. So I actually made a plate like this when I was a teenager. I took a piece of polycarbonate, placed ceramic tiles on top and then laminated the whole thing with many layers of fiberglass and polyester resin. Then I went to a gunfag board and asked some one to shoot it for me.

The results were not good, basically the only thing that didn't penetrate fully was .22LR. I don't remember exactly what he shot it with but I recovered the jacket of a large caliber pistol, possibly 45ACP and a small rifle round, most likely .223. Simply put, ceramic tiles are not hard enough to stop rifle rounds and while they may be able to fragment pistol rounds, they then turn into shrapnel that blows right through the backing. The whole thing was too stiff to work even as 3A armor and while polycarbonate is very tough, it cannot withstand the high impulse of a bullet impact, it basically tore open like a flap and let everything through.

Thinking realy hard, I came up with something.

BAM! Shrapnel protection for children. Reading about it on https://wikipedia.org/wiki/Flak_jacket

During the Korean and Vietnam wars, the flak jacket was changed and the manganese steel plates were replaced by other materials.[5] The U.S. Army's vests (Body Armor, Fragmentation Protective, Vest M69) weighed under eight pounds and were made of 12 layers of ballistic nylon. The vests used by the U.S. Marines (Vest, Armored M-1955) weighed more than ten pounds and were a combination of ballistic nylon layers and fiberglass plates known as Doron.[3] Doron was made of fiberglass fibers placed in an ethyl cellulose resin under high pressure. It was named after then-Colonel Georges F. Doriot, then director of the Military Planning Division, Office of the Quartermaster General.[2]

The generation of armor developed in the 1970s through the National Institute of Justice incorporated layers of soft armor in the form of DuPont’s Kevlar fabric, which has since become synonymous with ballistic protection and a general term used for several similar (aramid-based) materials.[6]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526941
>Why do people not to this?
I've done it... like the other anon said they are inferior on carpet without a beater bar.
They're sized for large tasks/loads and for typical home use that creates a few drawbacks-
- Not easy to empty into containers smaller than a shop/ yard style can
- more effort and hassle to dump the large barrel, but if you wait until it's full it can pick up odors, especially if you have pets
- usually don't have any way to see fill level without opening, which makes a mess
- they usually have shitty exhaust filtration and direction for use in a living space compared to a dedicated residential vac...I had to make a snorkel to direct the exhaust up or else it would blow papers and small items off of desks and low tables, blow dust and lint further under furniture and into corners the second you turned it on, toss blinds and curtains around, etc.
-We have dogs so after a while even with careful cleaning/ disinfecting it just pumped out dog bed smell that made it impossible to take into other peoples homes when doing remodel/ repair work.
-Finally the tools tend to be pretty limited, expensive when they arent, and thevtools and especially hoses are sized for shop and industrial spaces and can be unwieldy in tight areas or where you have nice finishes you dont want to bang up.
I have both now and except for cleanup after doing carpentry or drywall work or using the wet vac after a leak or flood event, the shop vac stays in the shop.

I've got two of these vacuums, and I like them.

One is some 70s model I inherited from a dead aunt, no one else wanted it, the only problem was a bunch of thread and hair wrapped around the spindle.
The other is a 90s model I got from a thrift shop, with all attachements, for $50. But someone had stripped the hole where the 'head camlock' bolt goes, so there was no way to tighten down the head.
Funky little bolt, I took a bunch of measurements and an M10x1 was a good fit. Fine pitch because the aluminum casting was maybe 3mm thick, and I already had that tap (bicycle rear derailer hanger). Looks janky, works fine.

I don't think I would like them as much, if I was always having to switch the head/hose attachment. And it's not really reasonable to suggest everyone "buy two".

Yeah nah, the door-to-door sales are scams. I bought mine barely used on Ebay for $200 which is what it should be retailing for to begin with. Poor saps paying $1000+ New always fall victim to the "Last Vacuum Wins" trick where they have the sucker vacuum an area of their floor a dozen times or more then go over it with the unit they are selling and then show how it magically sucked up more dust/dirt that their current model "missed" without knowing that if the home unit did another pass, it too would also pick up a bit more debris that each preceding pass also still missed because you can never truly achieve 100% pickup especially if the carpet pile has some years of accumulation on it.

I would never pay high-$$$ or $$$$ for any vacuum even luxury brands like Rainbow, Electrolux, or Riccar. The only exception might be the Roborock's flagship S7 MaxV Ultra because it's the only fully automated total floor cleaner on the market right now (self-washing robo scrubmop, self-emptying vacuum container, self-charging, and sensors to switch back and forth from carpet to hard-floor vacuum/moping). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Buy some thick plastic sheeting or tarps, enough to cover your greenhouse twice over, and buy some rolls of standard household fiberglass wall insulation, enough to cover the greenhouse once. Lay 1 layer of the plastic/tarp over the greenhouse, gluing the seams together. Then attach the fiberglass insulation to that layer of plastic with some spray adhesive. Then attach the second layer of plastic to the outside of the insulation with more spray adhesive. Glue the two sheets of plastic/tarp together around the edges. You now have a waterproof insulation blanket comprised of inexpensive materials you can buy at your local hardware store.

You can make it in sections if having it be 1 large blanket is too big to manage.

And if you want it to last, make sure whatever tarp or plastic sheeting you use is UV resistant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Air is a pretty decent insulator. Build a second greenhouse that's 12-18 inches larger in every dimension around the original greenhouse. This way your greenhouse can stay warm all the time and the sunlight can still get in without having to cover it with a blanket every night. This is the same principle that makes double pane windows so much better at insulating than single pane windows.

>>2530239
I work outdoors often though I have garages and and collect things like large heavy cardboard boxes then remove staples and store them flat. Water is one thing but dirt and mud are far worse. Bin them after each job if you've no storage.

Europe likely has no trucks with them but if you can get a truck bed liner those are easy to cut up with a cordless angle grinder (every mechanic needs one) using a cutting disk. Rubber matting also works well and you can cut handhold holes into it. Have a strap so you can roll it up. Motorcycle friction style tiedowns work great for this.

For work off the ground I'd buy a folding canopy which are often used as sunshades etc in the Colonies.

A pail of water and jug of disk detergent makes it easy to clean your hands. Save small squeeze bottles like Sriracha and full with slightly diluted dish detergent for greater convenience. Plastic pails are great tool caddies and can be used afterward to clean tools.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533551
there is no such thing. many are outdated af, and a lot of options are missing hidden or moved. one of the shitty things about fusion360.

and there is nothing on the basic work loop:
1. start a sketch pick a plane
2. <draw 2d in the sketch tool on that plane>
3. "finish sketch" to exit the 2d plane tool
4. select sketch elements to extrude. use q or e key (they are slightly different)
5. change parameters for extrusion and type (join cut new obj) which are autoselected.
6. OK and you have a solid shape.
7. sketch will autohide. if you need additional operations use the eye under sketches.
repeat from 1.

working with new object even when you want a cut allows more functions.

you have to choose copy under the move option before moving, otherwise the option gets grayed out.

try to delay boolean operations until everything else is done. ditto with chamfers and filets, doing them early can cause errors and problems with future manipulation.

you can go back in the timeline and do things like add to a sketch or change the parameters of an extrude. this often requires redoing one or more subsequent operations.

after an object exists 'q' will stretch or reduce previous selections as a new step. 'e' will use the profile for a new extrude. operating on faces like this will have slightly different dialog choices between the two.

HTH fusion360 is powerful but pretty fucking convoluted.

posts.com:
I just want to say how immensely disappointed in SLA printing I am.
If you are thinking about getting into it and have experience with FDM printing, prepare to be shocked. The only similarities that these two processes share is that they both use a slicer and the printers make things. The slicers that are available are extremely limited, unless you want to pay money for them. This is completely against the open source idea. Well you can use Pr*saSlicer if you want but unless you have one of their SLA printers, you are going to need to convert it into the format your printer uses. You know why? Because each manufacturer has their own bullshit proprietary format. So you have to use a program called UV Tools to convert it to the right format.
With my printer (chinkshit especial) connecting the printer via USB does nothing.mi either have to use WiFi, a USB stick, or Cr*ality's cloud app. No thanks for that.
The software is limited and it's bullshit. But you know what else is closed source? The fucking hardware. Which means you aren't going to do anything like put custom firmware on your machine. Some of them maybe I guess but it's nothing like putting Klipper on a FDM printer. Not that Klipper would help anyways because the process is so different.
I've read some stuff about people working on a open source SLA printer. I long for the day. This proprietary shit pisses me off so bad and it goes against everything the RepRap movement stands for. Fuck Ch*tu, Pr*sa, Fuck El*goo, and especially, fuck Cr*ality.

>>2534011

Using the aux level option

Set the z offset at center using the provided piece of paper as a gauge

Then go to the corners, also using the paper as a gauge, but this time use the knobs on the bed to level that spot.

After this is done you run the auto level once.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2533975
>Question 1: what could cause these these lines in the layers?
Could be overextrusion. Have you calculated your esteps for your extruder? If not, you need to do so.
>>2533978
>What causes these dots?
Probably overextrusion or maybe flow. It's the same problem as the other question. Your printer is pushing too much plastic out.
>>2533980
>How come I have these ripples in the print?
Probably ghosting. Hard to explain but basically when your printer moves it vibrates and the vibrations get transferred to your print. You could try printing slower, you could get some dampeners for your steppers. Preferably you would get your printer set up on Klipper and then go through the testing. You can also adjust your acceleration if you don't change the firmware. It could be mechanical though so check every screw on your frame and tighten your belts. Get a carpenter's square and make sure you frame is PERFECTLY square (if you haven't already).
>>2533982
>all arches are crappy at the top
Might be related to overextrusion. If you set the slicing right, your printer will slow down on overhangs/bridges like that.

If I was you, I would go through this guide to get everything set up: https://teachingtechyt.github.io/calibration.html . Its quite involved but really important to do, especially on an Ender 3. Watch the guy's video and then go through the process. After you can print his test print successfully, try the Benchy again. If you follow his calibration guide, your printer will print great.
What layer height are you using? It's not obvious but your layer height needs to be divisible by 0.04 which is the size of a single step. There is also a relationship between the diameter of your nozzle and the layer height. Which slicer are you using?

Have you tried removing the nozzle and pushed a bowden tube through to push out any gunk?
And/or cold pulling?
>pull filament back
>remove pneumatic connector at the nozzle to reveal the top of the heat sink
>with nozzle at printing temp, push some filament in until oozing occurs at the nozzle
>dial temperature down to 60°C
>gently apply pressure while temp drops
>when temp hits 60°C, dial it back up to printing temp
>switch to gently pulling on the filament
>filament should pull free in the shape of the interior of the nozzle and heat block, along with any gunk that was in there, as it approaches printing temp

>what makes pla+ harder to work with
Probably from being a catchall category for anything various manufacturers want to add to PLA, leading to different optimal printing parameters. With PLA, you can get a generic setting that probably works decently for most PLA, but with PLA+, good settings for one might cause a print failure for another. And PLA is kind of the gold standard for easy printability, so any changes are downhill from there.

What's the adhesion like compared to ABS? Would an all-metal hot-end be recommended?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534777
240-260, I print asa at 250c/110c. You don't need all metal. It doesn't really like to stick to anything other than glass I've found. If you enclose your printer it doesn't warp. I print it on a bog standard ender 6 with top enclosure. Picrel is with vs without top enclosure. It's incredibly accurate stuff and tougher than aluminum. All metal hotends will clog up where ptfe ends don't. Your best bet is getting a ruby nozzle and an enclosure before anything else. Once you get it to print, cool inside the enclosure. You might want to build it out of wood to trap the heat. Print slow. 50mm/s max. Anyone who says otherwise is trolling you. You want to maximize ambient temperatures for asa for as long as possible. I put in my gcode to slowly cool the bed by 5c every 15 minutes. Just set it and once you get that first layer, leave it the fuck alone. Go play wow, go to bed, go fuck your so. It's best left alone until it's cool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534796
>>2534799
To expedite this, the offered sale price of a thing (anything) is what the seller thinks they can get for it. The cost to procure the item in question is entirely unrelated to this calculus, so put that out of your mind for now. Whether the offered price turns into a sale depends on whether anyone wants to buy the thing at that price, which depends on how much people want the thing (now how much it costs to procure the thing). The interplay of this over multiple sales determines a "market price", for the item in question. If the seller is a small fish in the market, there is little they can do about this price, but big fish can trade off to some degree between high prices with lower sales numbers and lower prices with higher sales numbers. Where procurement cost comes in is that procurement cost vs. market price is what determines whether the seller stays in the market or not. If the profit margin is nonexistent or too small to justify the endeavor, the seller stops selling.

Regarding the question of whether Prusas are overpriced, Prusa Research sells enough of them at current prices that they have been continually upscaling their manufacturing capacity, and things are still back-ordered extensively. Economically, this indicates that they are under-priced, but presumably they want to maintain customer loyalty by not jacking prices up, and that this is more valuable long-term.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2534844
No moving motors means that the moving gantry can be lighter than on a cartesian. The fastest current printers are small core XY ones where belt and other resonance is manageable. At larger scales, cartesian becomes more favorable. At even larger scales (e.g. industrial CNC machines) rigid drive mechanisms become favored over belts despite the even larger moving mass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534856
On this note I want to share a few things I found:
All metal hotends are fucking trash. All these higher end filaments print looking like shit compared to the likes of petg and pla.
Linear rails should be a requirement on all 3d printers.
Enclosures help a LOT.
When printing PETG and PLA, a heated bed might not always be your best bet, so turn it off after the first layer prints, and print with a brim. It will print cleaner as the cooling fan pulls less hot air in from the bed.
Printing slower can solve just about any issues. Going over 80mm/s offers nothing but headaches. You can't print faster than physics.

physically tramming the bed is meaningless if you have a crtouch installed, go into your printer settings and under start g code
on about the 3rd line down hit enter and make a space and put the following
G29; auto bed leveling
it will then level the bed with every print and all you have to do is make sure the middle of the bed is level with a piece of paper dragging on it. It solves all this. Let marlin (the printer's OS) do all the work bro.

>>2535215
>printing on the back of a PEI bed is a probably good way to stop nasty filaments like PETG sticking too hard
Unless it's double sided you're not printing on PEI anymore.
For PETG sticking too hard you should lower the bed temps. Typical is 80-85, for printing on PEI you should try 75 instead. Adhesion of PEI scales quickly with temperature so if it's colder it won't stick as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535394
looks like infill is showing through. you can fix that by doing more top layers.
that happens because when you're putting a layer on top of infill, it's sagging over the gaps. if you actually watch it when it prints, the first couple layers on top of infill don't even link up, it's like individual wires of filament instead of a sheet. like what happens on the bottom of overhangs.
so when the first layer goes down on top of infill, it sags really badly. then the next one is not as bad, but it melts the first one a little more, and as you keep adding layers eventually you get a clean top surface layer.
you could solve it by denser infill (not what i would do) or just more top surface layers.
however, you're always going to have at least visible lines (but not ridges you can feel with your hand) because your material is transparent.
one thing i like to do for stuff that has cards in it is iron the top surface. what it does is really slowly move the print head over the surface and lay a tiny amount of filament and you get a nutty smooth appearance.
pic related is from a card box i stopped mid print. hard to capture with a photo but it's nutty smooth to the touch. i stopped it because i didn't set my ironing settings right and it was ironing every top surface, instead of just the center of the lid. i ended up having to use a modifier mesh.
I was ironing at 5%, and i could probably do it a bit higher because you can see the lower lines poking through a bit, but it feels ultrasmooth so whatever.

tl;dr more top surface layers, also consider ironing.

>>2535301
>FYI I've only printed with PLA before
Makes sense then.
PEI is a thermoplastic, just like all the filaments you use in a 3D printer. As it approaches its glass transition temperature it becomes slightly rubbery and sticky. Heat it up by 10C from 50 to 100 and check it with your finger. You'll see what I mean.
PETG is in the range of bed temps to get good adhesion, and with ABS the adhesion is top notch. From my experience the problems with low adhesion are with PLA, as at 60C the PEI is not very grippy. 65 is the max you can use for PLA and at that point it sticks better, but still far from what I get from PETG at 75C.

>>2535306
No, PETG is a low warp material so it doesn't need fancy surfaces to print well. PEI is for ABS. At 110C bed temp that shit holds well enough that you can print stuff with a brim up to 150mm with absolutely no warping. Seriously, while it's hot I can't get the prints off. That's how well it holds.

>>2535150
Laser resin printers have been around for a long time. The advantages are that they have more control of light geometry, so they produce accurate vector paths rather than voxels; the very intense light can allow very thick layers if desired for drafts; and the lack of certain consumable parts that need replacement, like screens. However, their speed is limited in the way that FDM printers are (volume of solidified resin) rather than number of layers, so SLA printers are generally capable of a higher max volumetric output.

>>2535183
>the magnetic side of my PEI sheet?
No such thing. The PEI is stuck to a steel sheet, which is attracted to magnets in the bed itself, or in another layer sandwiched between the PEI steel sheet and the bed. The bare steel side isn't suitable for printing because plastics don't stick to it very well. However, it could be used with an adhesive layer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2535647
PLA is an acronym for Polylactic acid, a strong, stiff, brittle plastic. PLA+ is a generic term for PLA that has been modified in some way to change its properties in some desirable way. PLA+ is often less brittle, but that doesn't have to be the main difference. Silk PLA is PLA that has additives and processing changes that produces a shiny printed appearance. HTPLA is PLA that has additives that make it more heat resistant, typically by making annealing easier than it is with standard PLA. Their properties differ, but they're both modifications from the base PLA recipe with desirable properties that base PLA does not have. That is, PLA+, even if they may be marketed with another term.

>>2530706
What >>2530708 said r.e. sound booth. You're fighting an uphill battle against physics here. Easiest way to deal with it is management i.e. don't be loud at night, dumbass.

However if you really want to try some sort of engineering solution, I'll give you a test you can run which is similar to what we do when testing acoustically rated walls. First, play some 'pink noise' through your loudspeakers nice and loud. Go to the other room and listen - if you hear mainly a hissing sound, find the direction it's coming from and look around there for gaps and cracks between the loudspeaker and the receiving room. If it's a lower rumbling noise you hear, then the issue is mass so there's not much you can do without building a new or additional partition.

You could add some absorption inside your room, if so then get products which are min 25mm thick (so it will work better with lower end of human voice frequencies). Tack it to the wall at head height if you aren't covering the entire wall. This might help a little with reducing noise buildup in the room (and the amount of noise then leaking out), but I doubt it would completely solve your issue.

Easy but limited effect:
Put down rugs/carpeting
Hang heavy curtains around your walls
Put soft things around the room (I dunno, fabric couch? plushies?)

More investment:
Cover the walls and ceiling in foam panels or cardboard (cheaper but more accessible)
Put down a snap-together floor on top of your current one, and put one more layer of underlay in than normal

Renovation-tier:
Open the top of each wall and fill with noise-rated insulation
Go into the attic and replace with noise-rated insulation
Tear up the floors and use better construction with heavier or sound-rated materials, or install a false-ceiling in the room below

>>2523144
>Anybody here make their own cigarettes? Is its easy?
Yeah, it's easy to use the tube stuffing type machines if you don't want to hand roll them.
It's probably faster to use the stuffing machine too. I used the "topomatic" type machine.
>Cheaper then manufactured ones?
It's way way fucking cheaper. Do the math; you can get a pound of decent tobacco for like 15$ and tubes to go with it for another 5$ and make about 20 packs of cigarettes.
It'll probably average you around a dollar per pack or less.

One problem with doing this though is that the cigarettes won't be exactly like your favorite store brand. They won't taste exactly the same because cigarette manufacturers use a proprietary blend of flavors and treatments that is responsible for the distinct taste of their cigs. You can still find plenty of good quality, cheap tobacco (menthol, light, regular, extra bold, etc) but it will never be an exact match for your favorite brand.
Another thing is that these homemade ones will always burn just slightly differently than the industrial ones. Industrially made cigarettes are (AFAIK) made from a specially prepared reconstituted tobacco paper rather than shredded leaves. They do this to make things easier for their treatment steps, but also to make the mix have a 100% consistent texture and consistency that helps avoid problems with their processing and packing machinery. When you buy the cheap bags of raw tobacco, it's just leaves that have been cut/shredded to a consistency which is appropriate for rolling or tube packing cigs. So sometimes you may have a tiny inconsistency or packing error and wind up with a small void or an end of the tube that doesn't pack completely.

After you get familiar with the perfect amount of leaf to load in the machines chamber by doing a couple dozen cigs, you'll start to avoid this issue for the most part.

All in all, it's super cheap and easy to do and I'm always amazed that more smokers don't RYO

I have a hard time getting excited about 'em as I despise tubes and I'm probably faster with my rolling box (which isn't hand rolling, it's a fucking machine to do the work for you) than most faggots with a tube shooter.
If you want quantity though, a good electric filler is hard to beat.
It'll pay for itself anyway with the savings on smokes, and it'll pay for itself twice over versus the headaches of cheap shitty options.

Most out there are chinkanese, and some do actually suffer with longer tubes like you mentioned.
Handheld Plastic and Lever-Handle injectors are designed for specific sizes, and rarely perform well with any other size.
An electric that has adjustable pack/fill and has an oversized fill rod that can easily clear sizes beyond 100, that's what you want.
See if you have any local tobacco shops, as opposed to a smokeshop, decent chance they'll carry the same ones you find in the tobacco catalogs and you can actually get your eyes and hands on them instead of throwing darts online.

posts.com: I use to have a few hand crank rollers, they're shit the nut always loosens and there is no torque specs on it, has to be so lose but just the right tightness that it holds the bar together but they can still move to get it to work. They work great for a bit of usage then always have the same problem. I ended up buying an electronic one for a hundred dollars to test it out. Broke even in cost within 2 months, and actually had beer money left over after that. I kept having to travel for work and going out of town it wasn't practical to ever make enough to bring with and it was noticeable how fast buying packs would burn through cash. Even though it takes 5 minutes to make a pack worth of cigarettes with it usually it isn't worth the time compared to a tobacco pipe for me personally. Your mileage may vary. It was more than worth it for me the machines worked for over 5 years now (way more than I ever got out of hand crank ones) it's nice to be able to knock out a few really fast if I'm in the mood for a cig, and they're convenient when walking around outside and it's windy on the way between the bar to pick up a few drinks. It can be difficult getting consistency in how tightly they're packed, with hand cranks you can pack a tube so tighly you basically can't keep it lit, electronic ones will jam and you can't force it and have to break it up and go with much looser packing in cigarettes, so you want to smoke them if you got them otherwise they'll tend to shake loose while you're walking around. It's not a big deal if you got a hard case you can just throw the shake back into the machine and repack it, tear off the empty part of the tube that it fell out, it can be annoying if you got like 3 half cigarettes, but you get a sense for which ones will do that and to smoke them first. If you care to carry rolling papers on you, you can always just use that shake to make a rolley too, I like a rolley when no pipe but it's hard not to burn my stache with them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2524402
>The powdered stuff that you snort. Dont know the name, never tried it.
That's snuff, and it's fucking awesome.

Ozona is the most widespread brand in the US.
Their Presidential is pretty unimpressive in my opinion, the Weiss and English are much better.
The C-Type (cherry) is what I'd recommend to most first-timers as an introduction to the stuff.
You sniff a small amount, a very small amount, into your nostrils.
Just the nostrils, you're not inhaling it, just barely getting it up in there.

Of every tobacco product out there that I've tried, snuff is the closest analogue to cigarettes as far as the high they provide.
You use very, very little tobacco, and it hits you like a freight train, then wears off quickly.
It's convenient as hell, a little tin in your pocket is much smaller than a pack of smokes and won't be ruined by manhandling, and you can use it wherever the fuck because it sure as hell isn't smoke, and that includes wherever the kids with vapes aren't allowed.

Ever needed a smoke in the middle of an unimpressive movie you're sitting through with some bitch?
Ever really needed a smoke on a long flight?
Stuck in a meeting for a whole day with one fucking lunch break and no chance to take 5 and puff one?

Go buy a tin of snuff from any decent tobacco shop, usually costs less than a half-decent pack of smokes.
I'm a pack-a-day smoker, and if I'm on a business trip I won't bother with smokes, a 5g tin of snuff lasts me 5 days.
It may not replace your current preference, it sure as shit has never replaced cigarettes or cigars for me, but it is a fucking awesome addition to the line-up.

It's also worth noting, it's basically guaranteed to make you sneeze.
You get over it quickly if you use the stuff regularly, but your first few times it's pretty much a certainty that you'll sneeze some nasty tobacco-laden ectoplasm.
Be ready with a tissue the first time you try it.

>>2523144
I smoked packs, hand rolled and made them with tubes and loose tobacco like that.

I prefer hand rolled. Packs are good but too expensive and honestly the additives in those cigarettes make them like 10 times more addictive. Like how you crave another cigarette right after smoking the first one. Don't have that with handrolled because it's pure tobacco. Pack cigs also have a sort of chemical flavour to it that you only really notice when you're used to hand rolled. Also way too expensive.

Machine made is a decent option although very messy and also an annoying task to do. Having to take extra time in the morning/before you go out/when the pack is empty to fill up another carton may seem like not a big deal but it really gets annoying after a while. It's also not a guarantee that every cigarette is going to be perfect. There's a certain learning curve to it where if you use too much tobacco the cigarette is impossible to smoke and if you use too little you smoke it in 10 seconds. Also annoying

Hand rolled are king imo. I smoke a 50gram pouch in a week with about 10-15 cigarettes a day. Comes down to about 45 euros a month on cigarettes, which to me is doable. Taste better and once you get the technique down right you can roll a perfect cig in under a minute, which is more convenient (to me) than having to machine out a whole pack every morning. Get a bag of those little filters and the rolling is much easier and the cigarette smokes nicer as well, no tobacco pieces in your mouth. Also nice for rolling the ocassional spliff.

When I go out to a party or a club though I'll usually just buy a small pack so I don't have to bother rolling a cig and can share with others.

Mild steels above all else for high strength, low cost, ease of working, ease of welding, ease of repair, and availability. The majority of things are built from mild steels because it just plain works.

Aluminum can get fucked with it's brittle welds, higher cost, lower strength, and being harder to repair. It does have some use cases where it shines.

Wood is for furniture, houses, some buildings.

Concrete for floors, concrete pads, and foundations.

Basically they all have their use cases, but if I could only pick one to work with for the rest of my life I'd choose mild steel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2534336
My guess is your switch is used as a junction point to power both the light/fan and the switch in the other room. It’s pretty common to do so (though normally one wouldn’t use the switch itself for that, but a 3-way cable connector clamp or screw terminal).
There’s probably a splice in either the fan or the light box (whichever is closest to the switch, or some additional box) to power both the fan and light from the red wire.
If you want to separately switch them you would need to run an additional wire from your switch to that box.

Sorry if I messed up the terms, English isn’t my first language
